name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Today is the first plenary meeting after the horrific attack that hit us in Manchester on 22 May. Unfortunately, after this tragic event, the bloodshed by the terrorists did not stop. ISIS has struck in Egypt against Coptic Christians and terrorism has struck again in Baghdad and in Kabul, where dozens of defenseless people have been brutally murdered. On behalf of all of us, I condemn these acts of inhuman violence with the utmost firmness and express our closeness and solidarity with the families of the victims. These are innocent people who have done nothing and who have lost their lives because of the barbarism of which unfortunately man is still capable and against which the voice of Parliament has risen, rises and will always rise with force. I ask you for this to join me for a minute of silence in remembrance of all these innocent victims. (Parliament observes a minute's silence in memory of the victims.) I must announce in the House the decision recently made by US President Trump to withdraw his country from the Paris accords. It is a decision that does not find the satisfaction of the overwhelming majority of this House, of which I am the spokesperson, and I will agree with President Juncker and President Tusk on joint initiatives to be taken together as the European Union.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the decision taken on the mobility package [2017/2606 (RSP)].

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, today’s Mobility package is a major milestone, one which is very much needed for the modernisation of our economy and for making mobility in Europe fit for the future. This package was not developed in a vacuum. It is the result of a long process of discussion both within the Commission and outside. I would like particularly to welcome the work of the European Parliament and to thank you for your great involvement in this topic. I am referring particularly to the resolution on road transport in the European Union. I think it is particularly important to underline that this package affects many policy areas – and, together with Vice-President Jyrki Katainen, we have made sure that all aspects are well covered: first of all, transport, but also industry, climate change and energy, air pollution, urban policy, digital market policies, and employment and skills. I would therefore like to thank, in particular, the Conference of Committee Chairs, which invited me two weeks ago to discuss these cross-cutting links. That discussion and our exchanges were instrumental in crystallising the final proposal. I would like to use this opportunity to thank all the Commissioners for their contributions to this package over the last month, especially Commissioner Bulc, who will talk to you in a second, but also Commissioners Thyssen and Arias Cañete with whom we have been working very hard to deliver this package. Why is this package so important? My colleagues call it a ‘quadro-win’ – which means four wins – for consumers, for industry, for workers and, of course, for our planet. Consumers should benefit inasmuch as Europeans are pioneers in adopting new technologies and they have high expectations from a new, cleaner, connected economy, and especially from Smart Mobility. Secondly, our industry: we must make sure that European companies remain world class, and today’s package creates the opportunity for Europe’s transport industry to renovate, innovate and rejuvenate. Europe’s ambition must be that our transport and mobility sector remain world leaders, with world-class logistics, word-class infrastructure and, of course, world-class cars made in Europe, with world-class jobs and working conditions. We cannot afford a European ‘Kodak moment’, where we fail to embrace new technologies in time. Thirdly, workers: we are improving drivers’ working conditions and we want to make sure that our transport and automotive industries continue to create quality jobs and growth in Europe.  Finally, the fourth winner of today’s package is climate, with air quality and innovation. Road transport has a major role to play. It represents 20% of our entire CO2 emissions here in Europe, and we have to remember that three times more people die from nitrous oxide and other forms of air pollution than from road accidents. Our prediction is that mobility is going to increase substantially by 2050. Fortunately, transport is also one of the sectors that is seeing the most exciting technological breakthroughs. I am convinced that we can and will grow the transport industry while, at the same time, reducing our CO2 emissions. In conclusion, this Mobility package puts us on the right track, indeed the fast track. We had already delivered about 90% of the Energy Union legislation by the end of last year. With today’s package and with the final mobility part, which we will present later this year and in early 2018, the Commission will have delivered 100% of the Energy Union proposals. Concerning the news from the USA, I would like to assure you that we, as Europe, will continue on our path. We will continue to assume the leadership in the fight against climate change, and I am sure that the leaders of our three institutions will issue an appropriate statement in this regard.  I very much looking forward to our discussion but I will first give the floor to Commissioner Bulc, once again thanking her for her enormous work, her great dedication and the excellent results which we can present to you today.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a great privilege and pleasure for me, together with my colleague Vice-President Maroš Šefčovič, to present to you the Mobility package adopted by the Commission today. This House has, on several occasions, called on the Commission to address the challenges faced by the road sector. Earlier this month you adopted a resolution to that effect. Thank you very much for your clear messages and support. Over the past two years, the Commission has been very broadly and inclusively consulting all stakeholders on all the major issues that represent a challenge for the road sector in the EU. So what you have on the table today are carefully thought-out and balanced proposals. They address a broad range of issues. Let me point out three of the most important ones: first, fairer and more competitive mobility; second, cleaner and more sustainable mobility; and, third, connected mobility. I will address them quickly, one by one. With regard to fair and competitive mobility, since the very beginning of this Commission’s term of office, a fairer and deeper internal market has been at the heart of our agenda. President Juncker has also repeatedly underlined that there is no place for social dumping in the European Union. In this context, the Mobility package will provide a truly European solution, which includes the necessary protection of workers and, at the same time, aims to prevent fragmentation of the internal market.  One prominent and much awaited measure is the fight against letterbox companies, for which there is absolutely no place in the Union. I think everyone agrees that this is becoming a real problem. We must make sure that transport undertakings are established where they manage their business, and that national authorities are equipped to detect fraud. So these are the two elements we are stressing. Another important issue which we are addressing relates to cabotage. Almost all stakeholders have said that the current rules are too difficult to enforce. The Commission has therefore decided to simplify those rules and to base them exclusively on time. Very importantly, the new rules will neither open nor close the cabotage market, but they will provide more flexibility for operators, while also facilitating controllers in doing their job. We propose to increase the controls and make them more targeted at the same time. Today the Commission is also addressing the phenomenon of nomadic drivers. We propose to give drivers the possibility of returning home on a regular basis, at least every three weeks. Drivers must also be offered adequate accommodation when taking weekly rests away from home. Let me be clear that the Commission proposal does not require more or longer driving times, or fewer or shorter rest periods. On the question of the application of the Posting of Workers Directive to the road haulage sector, the Commission has always argued that the rules on the posting of workers should apply to road transport. The fact that workers are highly mobile is not a reason to deprive them of the benefits of EU legislation. Having said that, there is a need for sector-specific rules. We propose to reduce the administration burden for road hauliers and, as a matter of proportionality, to establish that national rules on remuneration apply to international services after three days of accumulated time in one Member State. Clean and sustainable mobility is the next topic. In line with the European Energy Union, and to meet the commitments we made in Paris, transport has to contribute by reducing its very high emissions of CO2 and pollutants. We therefore propose to adopt our common road charging principle to encourage the use of infrastructure in a more efficient manner, and to reward the use of cleaner vehicles. Very importantly, the Commission is proposing to bring passenger cars, vans and buses within the scope of the EU legislation on road charging. These vehicles are responsible for their share of CO2 emissions and congestion on our roads, and this will also address problems relating to discrimination based on nationality, notably for passenger cars. Implementation of the ‘user pays’ and ‘polluter pays’ principles is another key objective of the Commission’s proposal. The vignette system should be progressively phased out in road charges, and charging should be on the basis of distance. This is a matter of both fairness and efficiency. Distance—based charging is also a precondition for external-cost charging, which was requested in the recent resolution on road transport adopted by this House. It is also the precondition for rewarding the use of clean vehicles more effectively. For example, we propose to introduce a 75% toll discount for zero-emission vehicles. On connectivity, what will the road initiatives do for connected mobility? Digitalisation is a very powerful means of achieving our various policy objectives. If we are to bring about more efficient road charging, Europe needs interoperability of national toll systems. Currently there are many different and independent charging systems in the EU, which are complicating cross—border transport. The Commission is proposing new rules which will provide for one on—board unit, one contract and one invoice to users. Another important area in which we propose further to develop digitalisation is enforcement. At a time when enforcement capacity in Member States is being reduced, it is especially important to have modern and efficient tools available for controls. We propose to make better use of e—documents and digital tachographs, to improve the exchange of information between Member States and to ensure interoperability between their systems.  I look forwarding to discussing these proposals with you in the months to come. As we begin the discussions – in a spirit of openness and readiness to compromise, I hope – I would also like to urge everyone to keep in mind the actual problems which transport operators face on the ground. As you are all aware, these problems are quite substantial. So let us try to be pragmatic and find solutions that work and that are enforceable, for the road haulage sector and its workers on the one hand, but also for all our citizens – with reduced congestion and lower pollution and, above all, better road safety – and, last but not least, for the EU economy, so that relevant, efficient and competitive transport services can operate throughout the single market.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - The baby is born. It took a long time, apparently it was a difficult delivery, but the child is now in the world. I congratulate the Commission on this achievement. It is quite late. We are under tremendous time pressure, but we will try to finalize the package during this parliamentary term. The EPP group will study the proposals in the coming weeks. First of all, let me say this: strengthening the internal market, simplification and a better level playing field for all participants in the transport world are all very good. But this should not be at the expense of the social aspects. Minimum wages and cabotage will become big political topics in our discussion. The transition from cabotage actions to cabotage days will be particularly challenging. Commissioner Šefčovič has already said it: just because President Trump is leaving the climate agreement does not mean that we will not continue with sustainability. We are also keeping a close eye on the new European toll system. We are not going to burden citizens if it is not necessary, but one system for all of Europe seems a good thing to me. In short, we are positively critical, but we do have to work very hard.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner. Many thanks also from the Socialist Group for the work you have presented. For the Social Democratic Group, it is important that we have a balanced mix in terms of ultimately free access to the market and fair competition on the one hand, but also the implementation of social standards on the other. Acceptance within the European Union is essential when it comes to fairness and the social pillar. If I may just take a few points from you, Mr Šefčovič, from the press conference, I think it is good that you have included the transport sector in the provisions of the Posting of Workers Directive - that is crucial. The fact that the provisions of the Posting of Workers Directive apply from the first day of cabotage is also to be advocated again - for that, many thanks. As for the Eurovignette Directive, Commissioner: 75% off for zero emissions - perfect. We want that. In this direction we must try to make the baby even more beautiful, in accordance with what Mr van de Camp said.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! Dear Commissioner, The publication of the mobility package is indeed an event that we have been waiting for for many months. A common European response to the sometimes unilateral actions of some Member States in the field of road transport is very much needed and expected by both hauliers and truck drivers. Protectionism is a huge threat to the common market and fair competition between Eastern and Western European transport companies, for which the biggest price will ultimately be paid by entrepreneurs and consumers. Unfortunately, I have the impression that this legislative package only partially addresses the challenges that arise and fails to solve the most problematic issues. The Commission's proposal to recognize a driver in international transport as a posted worker after only three days of stay abroad does not correspond to the realities of long-distance transport operations. I have similar doubts regarding the rules of taking a weekly rest. Social dumping - a term you have used - is a very clever wording, but it does not reflect the economic reality of the European Union at all. I hope that thanks to the joint effort, it will be possible to include in the final version of the proposed solutions also the perspectives of transport companies from Central and Eastern Europe, which constitute a very important part of this market, and whose opinions and expectations have not been properly taken into account in this package. The Commissioner declared her will to compromise, I accept this statement.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you and to thank Commission Vice-President Šefčovič for the presentation. Wim van de Camp spoke about the ‘baby’ being born, so we will now see whether the baby is well developed, whether the legs are as developed as the arms, and especially whether it has a complex brain and if it is balanced for future development. The philosophy with which you have approached this, Commissioner, and the concept sound good. It is a concept I can subscribe to, even though you referred to Jean-Claude Juncker’s ‘no dumping’ statement. I would appreciate it if he had added a bit more about the market, and about the protectionism that we also see in Europe today. However, we need to give the package a chance and not only that: we need to develop it and make sure that it works in all the dimensions that you have presented. We also need to take into account that the backbone of the EU is the internal market, and the internal market has to function. There is no room for protectionism but there is also no room for misbehaviour or unfair treatment undermining the necessary social standards and environmental aspects. All that definitely has to be addressed.  I would now like to make a few comments to my fellow MEPs. This is a package – and we see on a daily basis various national measures which are, in fact, fragmenting the internal market – and it is high time for this package to be addressed, developed and approved in a balanced way. That means that we need to treat it as a package and we need to make sure the package is approved within this parliamentary term. There is no other way, because the consequences of any alternative would be to the detriment of the internal market, of the rights of our entrepreneurs, of our workers’ social rights, and of the European Union. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – The Council, that is helping you, should look in this room. They are not doing this, unfortunately. I would like to ask our colleague and the Commissioner: what are we going to do with the strategy when the United States has withdrawn from the COP Paris agreement? Do you not think this will jeopardise European competitiveness? Do you not think that we have to completely reshape this strategy?

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: blue-card answer. – This is far too fresh, but I have a problem. We keep looking at the United States all the time, regardless of the issue. We should be mature enough to have our own policies and to make sure that these policies work for us, bearing in mind the external factors. I really believe that this has to be given a chance and I am ready to work on it. On the other hand, I regret that, on the same day that President Trump made the announcement, the German Government, the legislature, just a few days ago enacted something that is foreseen in the package and should be left at European level. That is of more concern to me at the moment.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: for the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President! Thanks to the Commission for the initiative. Today's initiative on transport and mobility may be close to a disaster for the many working in the transport sector. Full liberalization and deregulation, well, that's a course towards poorer working conditions, and the Commission's proposal that we should have a so-called more flexible understanding of drivers' working hours, it will only make it worse. In fact, we need to take care of the workers. We should all be intimidated by the stories that are about drivers living in their driver’s cabs without proper breaks and without the opportunity to see their family. The only bright spot I can immediately see is that the Commission is actually prioritizing the posting rules. And I want to thank you for that. But there is no doubt that when you look at the overall package, the purpose is to increase mobility. That in itself is fine, but it must never ever replace the creation of local jobs so that citizens can actually decide for themselves whether they want to travel or whether they want to stay with the family and work where they are. is.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the share of road transport continues to increase, but so do the nuisances: pollution, climate change, road insecurity, social dumping. We must provide concrete answers to these scourges. First, we must stop degrading the working conditions and safety of employees through liberalization that does not speak its name. We see the consequences of the downward pressure on costs: driving times not respected, rest in inappropriate places, transport companies who use and abuse social dumping thanks to the low wages of workers from the countries of the East. There are even cases of human trafficking here in Belgium, with the case of the Jost company. It is urgent to put an end to this situation. It is urgent to take action. In the Commission, it is all well and good to have a social pillar on paper, but what we want is a social pillar in reality. The fierce and unfair business competition must be ended and, you are right, Commissioner, we must put an end to letterbox companies. Let us affirm the principle "for equal work, equal pay". Let's go further, let's be ambitious. Let's create a European road agency to guarantee compliance with European legislation. Roads contribute 20% to greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union. You are going in the right direction with the Eurovignette proposal by basing fees on distance and no longer on time. On this point, I greet you. But go ahead, don't be afraid, be ambitious! It must not be voluntary, it must be mandatory, because we are not playing with the future of our children. We are not playing with the planet, nor with the health of citizens. Finally, digitization must really allow the improvement of control for the respect of the law, but this does not cannot wait until 2034. The tachographs must absolutely be on the table tomorrow.The stake of this package is the survival of the European project.We have an obligation of result here and now.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: for the EFDD Group. - Madam President! For three years I have been talking about how easy it is to cheat with the current regulations in cabotage transport. Now you're making it even worse. I can tell you exactly what this will look like when you allow five days with a number of transports that no longer count. You can drive as much as you want. Monday morning, the cars will roll into Sweden from Denmark. Then you will have five days to perform domestic transports - as many as you want, for five days - before the car finally returns to Denmark on Friday night. From Denmark's side, it will be the same problem. There, the cabotage cars will go to Sweden on Friday night to return Monday morning. You have opened the gates to something that is, if possible, even worse than what we have had so far. You will ensure that the market is flooded with cabotage cars that will largely take over the transports from all reputable companies that try to pay contractual wages and have fair conditions for their drivers. The five-day rule is more or less a disaster!

name: Markus PIEPER
text: - Madam President, Commissioners! What takes a long time will finally be good, almost, dear Wim van de Camp. In any case, our mobility package is not a fall birth. Thanks to the Commission for the proposals on the Eurovignette. They are a basic requirement for toll systems that are harmonized across Europe. However, I can already announce that we will subject all proposals relating to the financial burdens from new requirements for environmental noise or traffic jams to a comprehensive bureaucracy and cost check. Because it cannot be that we are overburdening an already heavily burdened industry and also the users by constantly changing new specifications. As a result, the inclusion of these external effects must not lead to higher costs for the industry. My second comment on the proposals on company licensing and the posting of workers: We will examine this very carefully, but we are already pleased that the rules have finally been made clearer. The clear working time limits will help curb social abuse, and we must then coordinate this with the provisions of the Posting of Workers Directive. However, the Member States must then also monitor more closely, and the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, must monitor the Member States to see whether they do control. Because they do that really carelessly - I have to criticize that. In summary: warning of excessive toll costs. Call to curb social dumping. Many Thanks. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Pieper, you said that the industry should not be burdened any further - above all, you meant the streets.Does the same law apply to everyone?They know that every locomotive and every train has to pay a toll on every kilometer of the route, the amount of which is unlimited.Even after this resolution, it is a voluntary matter for the Member States on the road whether they collect a toll at all.I think that's unfair because 100 percent of the rail network is tolled and only a single percent of the road network.The environmentally friendly rail is made so expensive and the climate-damaging road so cheap.Is this okay?

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Dear colleague Cramer!We all agree that we have to do more for the railways.But I think that the road transport sector is also heavily burdened by eco tax, mineral oil tax and all the CO2 requirements and that many companies also face strong international competition, so we must not overstrain here.And if the external effects are added to the toll, then at some point a limit will also be reached where competitiveness is at stake.We will therefore check it out very carefully.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: - Yes, at first glance and as far as I can tell so far, I am actually positively surprised when it comes to the working conditions of truck drivers. The current case here in Belgium has shown how companies use every loophole to pay social security contributions and taxes in Europe. It is important that we ensure decent working conditions for all professional drivers in Europe. The good thing is that you are finally tackling the fight against letterbox companies. And in addition to national controls, we urgently need international work controls. However, it is also important for me that all truck drivers fall under the posting guidelines from day one. There must be no exception, because otherwise we will open up the next possibility of bypassing. And if the wages of the host country were to be used for cabotage, that would be a first step in the right direction, but only if the favourability principle is established. Important: Free passage for wage and social dumping must come to an end. I hope that comes out of it in the end.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: - Madam President, in recent months, we have witnessed several Member States, despite great talk of solidarity and a united Europe, preventing Eastern European carriers from entering the market in unfair terms. This is, for example, the minimum wage introduced by Germany and France, and the allowances paid must not be part of it. This puts foreign carriers at a disadvantage. Or, for example, a ban on spending a week's rest in your own truck. There are questions about insurance when the driver leaves the truck, and many more. Or, for example, various documentation in the national language, which no one had missed for twenty years. I would like to remind you that, for example, Slovakia opened its markets when it came to the food market, the land market, and the privatization of strategic companies. On the contrary, Western countries are closing their markets. They do so through various non-tariff measures, inventing barriers and administrative barriers and making it more difficult for Eastern European carriers to enter their markets. I find this very unfair. The European Commission should have acted a long time ago. She has had open infringements for two years and does not act, sleep or stretch time. Thank you very much.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: - The Commission spoke of extensive consultation with stakeholders. That's right. I did the same today with a few drivers and asked them what they thought of the proposals. The first reaction I got was: we just lose, soon we will drive completely for free. This is how it sounded from the mouth of an independent driver without personnel, who simply has to do with the increasingly poor working conditions in road transport. As for the controls, the driver said, these plans make me despondent. This is a license to screw things up even more. The meshes are getting bigger and bigger. I think that's true, those responses are justified. If we liberalize cabotage, things will not get any better. What we would have liked to see from the Commission is the use of the smart tachograph and good controls. It is indeed good to make agreements about this, but do not start working with a risk approach, assuming that companies that have done well in the past will continue to do well, because this is what the sector is currently facing. a lot under pressure. So on behalf of the drivers, I say: we have to rethink and start over with these proposals.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: - Madam President! In achieving the climate goal we decided on in Paris, the road transport sector is one of Europe's biggest challenges, as it accounts for over 20% of EU CO2 emissions and requires comprehensive solutions to make the transition to a sustainable transport system a reality. The proposed revision of the Eurovignette Directive recognizes that the road transport sector must consider the costs of climate change. It is a good first step, but the bold proposals for reducing climate impact are still shining with their absence. A principle for all EU legislation is the so-called polluter pays principle, ie. it is the polluter who has to pay. However, the Commission's proposal continues to want tolls to be voluntary. It is not reasonable that access fees for the railway are mandatory - but voluntary for roads. In order to enable the transition to a sustainable transport system, it is crucial to create a level playing field to deal with the unfair competitive situation in the sector, while enabling Member States to take the lead by taking the lead in the green transition.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, with a view to concretely wanting to combat unfair competition and the problems arising from the incorrect application of the cabotage rules, it is necessary to bring man and person back to the center. The work done by Tir drivers is highly demanding from both a physical and mental point of view. The drivers are in fact forced to work in difficult conditions, away from home for long periods, without the possibility of real interruptions; this, as we have seen, is close to the heart of the Commissioner, at least from the statement he made to us it is clear enough. Therefore, the proposals made to intervene on the current legislation on cabotage are welcome, but concrete measures are needed, especially feasible ones, which are not only on paper. Today there are minimum standards that are not sufficient because the authorities do not have the tools to be able to carry out truthful and safe checks. We have proposed, and the European Commission is carrying out, a pilot project on the use of GNSS systems for monitoring heavy commercial vehicles. Does the Commissioner believe that such a technology can be used and promoted as part of this mobility package or should we wait for future developments in the sector? For us, the priority is to concretely ensure that drivers can work in humane and respectful conditions, that they have the opportunity to return home. This must be done in conjunction with the means of transport that must return to the factories to ensure that the main activity of a company takes place in the State in which it is established and unfair competition is not practiced in other countries.

name: Andor DELI
text: - Ms. President! Recently, we have had a frequent debate here in Parliament on transport, and it is clear from these debates that there is a need to protect transport drivers, improve their working conditions, but also to use innovative solutions and the efficient operation of transport companies, especially SMEs. to help. Without knowing in detail the Commission's rules on the posting of road hauliers, the fact that it is treated as a lex specialis can give rise to confidence. However, it is unfortunate that the mobility package was presented late, only at an advanced stage in the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive, because it must be avoided that the general rules of the Posting of Workers Directive clog the legislators' hands when negotiating the mobility package. Otherwise, there may be legislation that deviates from reality and ignores professional and practical experience. For this reason, the Commission, but also Parliament and the Council, have a great responsibility to find solutions in the forthcoming interinstitutional negotiations that are viable, take into account all the specificities of the transport service and prevent further fragmentation of the transport market. the fundamental freedom to provide services.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: - Thank you, Chairman. Firstly, I would like to thank the Commission for this comprehensive and very important package that we in Parliament can now finally start working on. One of the principles is clearer and more transparent rules, their enforcement and the fight against fraud. This social aspect is extremely important to our group, we welcome it and we will support it very hard. The question is, of course, whether this will work in practice. That is the challenge. Does this package make it possible to really tackle social fraud in the field? We will certainly test that criterion. Let me be clear: this is not about a battle between Eastern and Western Europe. It's about making sure that our workers, whether they come from the West or the East, are subject to the same rules, the same wages and the same social protection. That is incredibly crucial for us. Secondly, on the day that Donald Trump leaves the climate agreement, I would like to say something about that. This package sends out an important signal. Transport represents 20% of emissions and that percentage is still going up. It is very important that we take responsibility in Europe and that we form alliances with the rest of the world, albeit perhaps without the United States, to keep the climate agreement above water.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her statement. CO2 emissions across the transport sector need to be addressed. However, in the road haulage industry, where margins are very tight, it is extremely important that small- and medium-sized businesses are not run off the road and out of existence through unrealistic targets. I hear dangerous talk on cabotage, but some reassuring words on dubious letterbox companies that exploit workers. It is action, more than words, that can only work. May I suggest you allow each Member State to tackle the individual companies who blatantly abuse this system across the EU? Fragmentation of the internal market should not be used as an excuse to harmonise road safety in Member States, especially when the UK and Sweden have the safest roads in Europe. The EU is constantly questioning the competence of national governments. May I state that the UK has been running very successfully its networks and transport infrastructure for many years, and certainly does not need any further interference from the EU? It will be a great day when we regain our independence and leave the European Union.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice President, Commissioner, a strong transport sector is necessary to support the economy of the European Union as a whole, to increase competitiveness in our industry and our global presence. Transport can have a great impact on logistics costs, and the road is king in this domain, since the transport of goods by road represents 65% of land freight, according to the Commission studies of 2014. The initiative of Road for the transport sector is essential for it to function well, be competitive, be fair, be clean, be innovative. In the European Union, efficient transport connections have facilitated the creation and deepening of the internal market. Investments in transportation infrastructure drive economic growth, create wealth, improve trade, geographic accessibility, and people's mobility. The demand for road transport has been increasing due to its competitiveness, its ability to improve accessibility and adjust to the demand of its customers. It is therefore our job and must achieve goals that adjust to the new times. Parliament is committed to working on all these reports, whether they are regulations or directives. It is going to be, ladies and gentlemen, a long road - sometimes even arduous - as this package is loaded with sensitive issues, be they social, environmental or innovation. But we must ensure that the result reflects a land transport policy that promotes fair, efficient, safe and environmentally friendly mobility, and also sustainable. America has a way; we will follow another that we believe is more just.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: - Madam President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, we have been looking forward to the publication of this mobility package. We asked ourselves how the Commission would decide after years to deal with such a delicate and complex issue as road transport; unfortunately, expectations were partly disappointed. The Commission's line of further liberalizing the sector certainly does not help the workers or even the small businesses that will increasingly find themselves fighting against unfair competition. On the other hand, flexibility is welcome in some areas, such as driving hours, in order to give the operator the opportunity to return home to rest. The fight against the "letterbox" companies installed in countries where the cost of labor is lower than in others is also good, but the wild liberalization of cabotage will not lead to any benefits, on the contrary it will turn into a further instrument of unfair competition. Finally, even this reform will remain a dead letter if we do not have more effective controls.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President, Commissioner, the structure of the package is a structure which, as such, answers all the question marks actually present on a complex debate such as that of transport, however we have some elements on which the work it will have to be very, very strict. The first was mentioned by practically all my colleagues who have preceded me: the issue of dumping, the issue of cabotage. Here, here we need to give ourselves a more precise answer to an actual question, the very concrete issue of empty returns that we often talk about in our discussions, very concrete. It is not by further liberalizing cabotage that the problem of empty returns is solved. There are empty returns because there is a problem of meeting supply and demand, so it is by strengthening the market that we respond to that problem, not weakening it or favoring those who do not respect the normal rules. And this is the very first point of content on which we should be absolutely firm and united. On the other hand, the issue of combining the strategy on low-emission mobility and the road package. We have a big challenge on the transport lot, we have the biggest responsibilities. Let's not destroy our industry even in the biofuels issue, let's make sure that there is a gradual transition that meets the right needs of all citizens.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Madam President! Mr Vice-President Szefczovicz, Commissioner Bulc! You are late with this package, you are late with the reaction, but this package is. I would like us to agree on the motto "without trucks Union stops". We must have an efficient road haulage system. However, we are in a conflict situation. It is an open conflict between the carriers of at least twelve, perhaps fourteen, countries and the rest of the European Union. It is about different understandings of, for example, social dumping. The question arises: why should the driver be paid differently in Germany or France? Does this mean that a Polish or Slovak driver who will go to Bulgaria or Romania is to have a reduced salary because there are lower salaries there? You have not yet proposed alternatives and answers to these questions, so we are facing a debate. We promise to cooperate diligently, but these will be really difficult discussions.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioners for coming to speak today on their new package. I very much welcome it. Clean, competitive and connected. I certainly share those ambitions, as we all do here in the Parliament, particularly in the Committee on Transport and Tourism. I am very much looking forward to getting involved and dealing with the various pieces of legislation and reports that will come through the committees. On competitiveness and supporting workers on the working conditions which they experience, that is extremely important. In particular, we hear so much about the difficulty that road haulage companies have in attracting employees and ensuring that they stay with the job. It is an ageing profession and a profession that does not have enough women, so I very much welcome the fact that you are addressing that. Regarding connected cars, Europe needs to be more ambitious, provide the necessary infrastructure and facilities to develop this whole area, and not let the rest of the world run away with it. It is very important that Europe is at the forefront in this whole area, while recognising that we also need a clean environment for all our citizens. It is a big challenge and they are big ambitions, but we have the capacity to do it. I am very much looking forward to getting stuck in and working in this area.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Madam President, the message of this package cannot be perceived as contrary to the European road transport sector compared to other sectors that are less clean, less competitive and even less connected. And even less can it be a message against professional road users. That is why I thank the Commission - the Commissioners present - for the offer for full cooperation. Briefly, the Eurovignette. First of all, we hope that the dispute with Germany regarding the non-discriminatory application of the toll will be clarified as soon as possible. Also in this sense and with regard to the application of a Eurovignette for distance, we demand clear and sufficient attention to compensation for peripheral countries, whose products have less added value, as they are poorer, and hence the added burden is unbearable. We are also concerned about opening Pandora's box in terms of driving and rest hours, as the agreement cost a lot and we hope not to make it worse. As for mobile workers, we also hope to improve their situation, but above all to keep their jobs and return home. And fighting as we fight social dumping, we would prefer to attack the guilty companies via blacklist, but without placing the burden of proof on the workers, on the truckers. Finally, an absence that I regret: road safety. Commissioner, when will the infrastructures and cross-border fines come by?

name: Georges BACH
text: - Madam President, Commissioner and Commissioner!I think overall we now have a positive impression for the first time.As is well known, however, the devil is in the details, and we have to analyze that a little more rigorously.For example the difference between cabotage and posting.You have made that clear.But we still have to analyze that.There will certainly be a loophole there again.Then the new rules on rest periods: Have the effects on safety been considered here or not?Improvement of controls: The whole thing depends on the controls.I would have wished that digitization, that is, the use of modern tachographs, intelligent tachographs, could perhaps be relied on here and that they would be used more.With regard to loopholes: A proposal must be made as soon as possible in order to stop the business model below 3.5 tons.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: - Madam President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, the roadmap debate has generated strong emotions in recent months, and I am glad that we finally have a set of measures from the Commission. I believe that the package published today is a step forward and I hope that it will shed light on fair competition but also on ensuring decent and fair working conditions for those working in this sector. Because we are just starting out, today I would like to refer to only a few general aspects: the road package must take into account the particularities of the Member States and give a chance to all operators, regardless of their geographical area. From this point of view, I expect that the final version of the proposals will not burden transport companies with a greater number of administrative obligations, nor will it punish peripheral states, which depend on cross-border and cabotage operations. I also hope that we will finally be able to focus on the real issues, such as phantom companies that exploit not only legislative gaps, but also our own employees, and I regret that we do not have and have not considered setting up that European Road Transport Agency. it could have led to an integrated solution to many of the problems in this sector.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Commissioner, yes certain proposals go in the right direction, in particular to guarantee the return of drivers to their homes, to fight against letterbox companies or to maintain the posting rules for them. cabotage operations. But others are sending a negative and contradictory message with your stated desire to fight against the continuing deterioration of working conditions in this sector. Excluding international transport from the directive on posted workers, which precisely guarantees the fundamental principle of "equal pay for equal work" in the same place, is to play into the game of unhealthy competition and social dumping, which crystallize today. hui the rejection of the European project. Making rest and driving times more flexible and taking rest in the cab also undermines workers' social rights. Finally, you have chosen - and I regret it - to go against the position of this Parliament, which adopted on May 18 a resolution calling for the rejection of any form of liberalization of cabotage, including through the abolition of the limit number. cabotage operations. As I have said on several occasions, beyond the sectoral issue, it is indeed our ability to implement social Europe that is at stake in this text.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: I now have many more speakers for the catch-the-eye procedure than I can take.I will take two from each of the two large groups and one person from each.I ask for your understanding.Above all, I will accept those who were actually present at the debate the entire time.Catch-the-eye approach

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Madam President! The priority for us, for the recovery of the labor market, for the real counteracting of social dumping, is the fight against illegal employment, which is twenty times higher than the legal posting of workers. We are not doing anything about this in the European Parliament. On the other hand, by introducing regulations that make posting more and more complicated - which almost 70% takes place in Western European countries and between these countries - we are killing workers' mobility, which, after all, contributes to the economic growth of the whole of Europe, which our European society needs today. Posting across a wide range of sectors is in itself very complex. International transport is as complicated as posting. I urge us to slow down the work on the posting of workers a bit and lead to a situation where we work in parallel on transport solutions and posting solutions, and finally we propose to the Member States the best solutions for both posting and transport without killing European mobility.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, during the last plenary session this Parliament insisted that the Commission's proposal on road transport should keep the ambitions of such a crucial sector for the material and social progress of the Union high. It seems to me that the package adopted is going in the right direction, albeit with some flaws, through the adoption of measures aimed at increasing the use of clean energy, increasing road safety and tackling unfair competition and labor exploitation. With regard to market distortions, particular attention must be paid to the issue of road cabotage, which remains one of the aspects that most threaten the correct execution of transport operations. It is essential to make local authorities responsible for implementing the mobility package and to encourage them to develop innovative and sustainable solutions with a participatory approach. The time has come to put in place a harmonious and ambitious plan on mobility, which leads to a renewal of the transport system that is in line with the real needs of citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, mobility is important for the Union and especially for Greece, which is at the southeastern tip of the European Union. This means that special measures are required, a special regime to strengthen the transport sector in Greece. In this context, it is necessary to take seriously the insularity, in order to have cheap air and ferry transport for the connection of the Aegean islands and Crete with mainly Greece. In addition, the need to strengthen Greek transport companies, air, shipping, land and OSE must be put on the agenda, in order to strengthen the competitiveness of the Greek economy, which is a huge distance from major European markets. Only with the institutionalization of a special regime for the financial support of the Greek transport sector can there be a reconstruction of the Greek economy which has been literally dissolved by the troika and the memoranda.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for the initiative and effort being made, and I thank her for the clarity of her intervention in order to face a problem that is fragmenting the internal market. Count on our collaboration to end social dumping, to guarantee that the working conditions of professionals are dignified, that the rest of professionals is encouraged at home and that the uncertainties that affect cabotage are resolved. We are here to simplify procedures, to reduce administrative burdens, to support the decarbonisation of the sector with specific programs and to help you take advantage of all the opportunities that digitization offers. And, of course, we are all going to work on this regulation with the affected sector, which offers a lot of employment and is essential for European competitiveness. I appeal to the responsibility of the States to cease their unilateral initiatives and to think, for once, that a good union is good for all its members.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, we would have liked to have more time to study the Commission's proposal on road transport. In any case, the transport unions asked for something very simple for drivers: their right to a minimum wage, their right to rest, and to fight fraud on the road. And yet, none of this has been collected. The new regulation expressly allows short breaks to be made in the cabins and long breaks to take place only every four weeks. Travel of up to three days and cabotage of up to five days will also be allowed without even receiving the minimum wage. But above all, we fear that the rules will still not be applied correctly for workers. It's okay to simplify the rules, make digitization easier, etc. But what needs to be done is to force states and companies to comply with the law and guarantee labor rights. We were expecting a much more determined action and are sincerely disappointed.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: - Madam President!Yes, we want to reduce bureaucracy, we want to secure controls - because a law without controls is superfluous - and we want to increase security.There is a measure for this, because there is the tachograph, and the tachograph must be set up on all new trucks.With the existing trucks, however, you take 15 or 20 years.So my question is: Has that been discussed?We can then say: ten or 15 percent of the week you can be abroad.Then they would have immediate control without bureaucracy, and we would have guaranteed security and prevented abuse.Because even with this law, which you have just submitted, the question is: How can abuse be prevented in practice?I don't see that yet.So why not a tachograph?That would be very easy, no new technical solution, that would simply be possible.Why doesn't this happen?

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: - Madam President! We've been waiting for the road package for two years - it's finally here. To my great astonishment, I have to read that you, Commissioner, stated in it that you now have to pay for every kilometer on the motorway. Well, that is really crazy. There are good examples that this actually only causes detour traffic. I do not hope that you already have any things in the drawer that you also want to use road pricing on communal or perhaps national roads across Europe. These proposed measures do not help the environment, nor do they help the residents - they can only be helped by better technology. Everything else goes into the pockets of the finance ministers. We know that: We have had mineral oil tax for 40 years. I think the finance ministers are cashing in far enough. Apart from that - and this is really a big reproach among many other things that might be good - the EU was not created to centralize any kind of green traffic education.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioners, I am sincerely glad that we finally have this package. I am also glad that the Commissioner said that you want a fairer and more competitive transport market. I believe in this, I come from the industry and I think it is needed. The growth of the transport sector automatically leads to economic growth, but I am worried about how you want to solve the problem of phantom companies. I do not agree with my colleagues here who said that each state should solve, I consider that a unitary proposal is necessary because if we have an internal market we must also have a unitary regulation for transport and I put a proposal directly: do you think those companies who open a so-called post office branch in a country where wages are low but do not carry out any activity with drivers in that country but all drivers are taken and taken to countries where wages are higher and paid with wages in the countries of east. Do you think you can find a solution? I would not give transport authorization to companies that do not have a fleet of cars in that country and do not perform transport in that country. Please think, I think this is the main problem, after which everything is solved.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Commissioner, Mr Vice-President!You have heard quite a few arguments, questions, criticism, but also approval.(End-of-catch-the-eye procedure)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members for their very open comments and questions, and also to for all the support that they have expressed by picking the right topics that need to be discussed in order to move forward on issues related to road transport in the European Union.  Addressing EU-wide problems with EU solutions is the right way to go, and the best way to avoid unilateral, uncoordinated national measures which fragment our internal market. With the proposal before you, we are trying to avoid that and to ensure adequate working conditions for drivers in a more enforceable way, while at the same time reducing administrative costs and burdens for operators. Let me now directly address a few of your concerns and questions and hopefully bring more clarity to the proposal and our further discussions. Letterbox companies are illegal and are used to obtain cost advantage by some hauliers. That is a fact. We define here clear criteria to avoid letterbox companies and to better enforce this, in particular through enhanced cooperation between national enforcement authorities. I have been asked on numerous occasions to do something about vehicles below 3.5 tons, especially the so-called white vans that are very often used to bypass European rules. My message here is very clear: yes vehicles and hauliers under 3.5 tonnes are included in this proposal, and the Commission is making sure that they are subject to certain European rules, as described in the package.  There were a couple of comments on a European road transport agency. At this point we are focusing on improving the existing enforcement tools and systems and on further enhancing cooperation between national enforcement bodies. I hope it is going to work. Experience to date with the implementation of social legislation does not show that cross-border enforcement is much more cost effective and more consistent when carried out by the Member State authorities within established framework structures. A road agency could indeed be helpful but for the Member States and the Commission, in assuring consistent and efficient cross-border enforcement, we would first like to focus on the solutions proposed. But I remain open to developing this subject further, in cooperation with you.  Tachographs were mentioned several times. We propose to accelerate the deployment of smart technologies and smart tachographs, which will further facilitate the enforcement of social rules and avoid fraud. For example, operators equipping their vehicles with these modern digital tachographs before the deadline should be rewarded with fewer controls on European roads.  On driving and rest time, I would also like to repeat that the limits will remain the same. The flexibility to organise operations can in no way go against road safety and social protection. On the contrary, they will contribute to facilitating returns home. This is the approach proposed by the Commission. These rules could be complemented by additional social measures relating to working time but, for those, from today onwards the Commission is opening a social dialogue and will propose legislative proposals in the autumn in the second phase of the mobility package.  On charging, Member States are still free to decide whether they want to charge or not. They are free to decide what they want to charge, which roads they want to charge for and which not. But, if they decide to use charging systems, we have given them enough time to readjust their systems to a compatible, interoperable EU-based system.  On cabotage, let me underline once again that our new cabotage rules do not imply further market opening or further market closure. Market access and business opportunities will remain as they are today, but more flexibility will allow operators to optimise their operations, and simpler rules will certainly be of great help to controllers or enforcement officers in controlling illegal practices much better.  On proposal and posting, first for cabotage operations, these are operations whereby goods are loaded and unloaded within the same country. There is a clear and strong link with that country and, therefore, the drivers should be paid according to the rules of the country from day one onwards. Let us say that a Slovenian driver drops a load off in Milan and reloads in Milan to unload in Rome. For the time spent on the cabotage operation between Milan and Rome, Italian rules will apply.  Secondly, for international operations – these are operations where the loading and unloading take place in different countries – we clarify that there is a sufficient link with the country concerned only to the extent that the driver spends at least three days a month in that country. To put it simply, international journeys lasting less than three days are excluded from the Posting of Workers Directive.  Lastly, I would like to urge you all to focus not only on these particular issues. The road initiatives contain a very comprehensive list of measures that are well balanced and represent a substantial step forward in the management of road traffic in Europe, making it much more modern, fair, sustainable and future-oriented. We really need to improve the road sector in order to stay competitive and to make sure that Europe stays a social place.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, once again I appreciate the quality of the debate and I think it has been very clearly indicated what the points will be that we need to take care of, and on which we need to start daily contacts so we can work with you on speedy delivery. First and foremost, however, I really appreciate, and would like to thank the House for, the positive spirit and the welcome for the package, and also for underlining the importance of attention to the bigger picture, and how much we are trying to transform this very important sector. We have 50 million people working in transport-related industries, and we need to bear in mind how important it is for the quality of life in our cities and our rural areas, and how big a contribution transport can make to modernising and energising Europe, and to a cleaner environment. I would agree with all the honourable Members who have been calling for consistency and for speedy progress in working on this package in Parliament and in the Council, and I would like to reassure you that we are absolutely ready to respond to those calls. We had good experience, on the Clean Energy for All package, in working regularly with all the rapporteurs responsible for various parts of this package. I was invited to the Conference of Committee Chairs where we had a very good cross-sectoral discussion. I know how important it is to cooperate well with all the committees because what we are doing here does not belong to one committee only: it has real cross-sectoral impact. To conclude, I would like to thank you for your strong encouragement and for the clear call to work together on providing leadership on climate change, because here I am absolutely convinced that we Europeans are on the right side of history. The calls for a clean environment, for energy efficiency, for renewables, for modernisation and technological advancement of the economy, and for a high level of public awareness and citizens’ support, are very strong in Europe. Now we need to use this ‘first mover’ advantage to demonstrate our global leadership. I know that the world very much expects this from us, and I am absolutely sure that Europe will deliver.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: written.- It is our duty to finally put a stop to the social abuses in the transport sector.The recent judicial raid on the Belgian-Luxembourg transport company Jost shows that the fight against social dumping in the transport sector is finally getting off the ground.The measures proposed by the Commission are a step in the right direction, but they stand or fail with effective control measures.All trucks that hit the road internationally urgently need to be equipped with a smart digital tachograph.This allows the inspectorate to quickly check whether the drivers are complying with the new work rules and driving and rest times, which distances they cover and at what speed.We do not want any erosion of the rules on driving and rest times and the collective labor agreements in the sector.Road safety is paramount.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- I agree with the positive opinions already expressed by the S & amp; D Group for the announcement of the new mobility package presented today by the Commission.We find proposals of great strategic breadth, which seem to me to set the conditions for a profound improvement in the regulatory framework, in many aspects of the sector.I find the attention to the social and corporate framework in the field of transport very relevant, given the numerous cases of abuse encountered and considering the gray areas that still exist in the internal market.It will now be crucial to ensure full implementation of the announced proposals.We will ensure that the control activities in the sector (in particular in the road sector) are effective, including through the establishment of ad hoc bodies.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: written.- In the fight against social dumping, the EU Commission threatens to turn wrong once again with its new proposals in the transport sector.We are aware of the sometimes catastrophic conditions on Europe's roads, and if the Commission now wants to exclude long-distance drivers with short-term variants from the posting directive, the situation could worsen massively.What the Commission is proposing is second class postings.This makes competition on Europe's roads more unfair again - that cannot be.On the positive side, letterbox companies that set up companies from Western Europe purely to erode workers' rights in Eastern Europe should be better combated.But that's not enough.We must finally make the principle of “equal pay for equal work in the same place” the standard in the industry.To do this, we must sanction violations more strictly and enforce high social standards for all employees.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing.- We have all been waiting too long for the so-called road package.It has been fraught with a number of myths and conjectures, but also with the nervousness and direct experience of drivers and hauliers who have been exposed to considerable uncertainty in some Member States in recent months, incredible administrative burdens and measures that have little to do with the internal market.Our goal should be to set fair, clear and, above all, enforceable rules that, among other things, will contribute to improving safety and the efficient use of capacity and resources.And last but not least, more dignified driver conditions, wherever they come from.Even today's debate in the plenary of the European Parliament has shown that the legislative work ahead of us will not be easy, but we finally have the European Commission's proposal on the table.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I welcome changes in the field of mobility, especially when it comes to changes in road transport and tolling.I believe that this is just another step towards deepening the single market.It is true that this area is regulated by each Member State in its own way, so we need to be careful with the changes, but still be effective.It is important that European citizens travel smoothly and that the proposed changes bring more benefits than obstacles in practice.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - I welcome the package of measures taken by the European Commission to modernize European mobility and transport. Improving transport is an essential component for the intelligent management of the territory and for improving the quality of life of citizens. It is also an opportunity for research centers and European industry to lead a new technological era, with the energy transition (for electric mobility) and the new digital society as pillars. Better transport means easier interaction between people, more fluidity in the movement of goods, more economic competitiveness and better air quality, while also reducing noise and protecting people's well-being. I also underline the impact of these measures on the multimodal and cross-border articulation of transport systems, promoting interoperability and complementarity of solutions and alternatives. This package of proposals strongly mobilizes a new generation investment plan, which, quoting the Commission Communication, is "an important stimulus for the creation of clean, competitive and connected European mobility in the future".

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the new European consensus on development - our world, our dignity, our future (2017/2586 (RSP)).I would like to inform you that we have a first-time situation here today: as we know, Malta has elections and so the Maltese Presidency cannot attend this mini-session and it will be represented by the upcoming Estonian Presidency.I don't know if we've ever had a situation like this.I think it is very welcome that the trio is working together very well, and in this context I would like to extend a warm greeting to the Deputy EU Minister of Estonia, Mr Matti Maasikas.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: amtierender Ratspräsident. – Frau Präsidentin! Ich danke Ihnen sehr für diese sehr freundliche Einleitung. I would like to thank the honourable Members for giving me the opportunity to address you all on this very important issue. Some of you might be surprised to see me here some weeks earlier than the actual start of the Estonian Presidency, but for the reasons explained by the Vice-President, the current Maltese Presidency was not able to attend this session.  The new European consensus on development has been amongst the priorities of the Council and will guide the EU’s development cooperation for the years to come. As you know, our institutions have considerably accelerated the pace of the interinstitutional negotiations since February this year. You will probably also recall that five intensive, yet very constructive, trilateral meetings between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, paved the way for the adoption of the consensus by the EU Development Ministers at their meeting of 19 May. Similarly, I look forward to the vote which will take place in this House tomorrow, and hopefully allow for all the pieces of this complex puzzle to be in place ahead of the joint signature during the European Development Days on 7 June.  Let me stress here that the Council is very proud of this common achievement. It was only possible thanks to the high level of commitment of all parties to come to a common understanding and a shared agenda for the future of EU development policy over the next 15 years. The primary aim will be the eradication of poverty. In line with the Lisbon Treaty and the EU global strategy on foreign and security policy, the consensus will also help to achieve the priorities of the EU’s external policy.  As we all know, the EU remains the world’s largest development aid donor, providing more than half of assistance world-wide. The adoption of the consensus is a key EU deliverable in the commitment to globally implement the 2030 Agenda and support partner countries in achieving the sustainable development goals. The EU is sending an important signal to the global community, notably to the UN High Level Political Forum in July, on how it will support partner countries in their endeavour to implement the 2030 Agenda and achieve the sustainable development goals.  The new consensus for development is articulated around the ‘five Ps’ of Agenda 2030: people, planet, prosperity, peace and partnerships. Our top priorities will be to work towards the eradication of poverty, to reduce inequalities and promote social inclusion, to promote good governance, to ensure human and economic development, to tackle global issues such as the fight against hunger, to protect the environment, as well as to preserve the world’s natural resources. Social inclusion and gender equality will be central to the way we implement and define our policies.  In implementing these priorities, the consensus will have to respond to the main challenges that the world is facing today. The complexity and degree of interconnection between the economic, social and environmental dimensions of development policy – this can only be strengthened through a holistic approach.  The resilience of countries and societies should be put at the centre of our attention and the cross-cutting elements of the consensus – such as gender equality, youth, investment and trade, sustainable energy, climate action, good governance, democracy, rule of law and human rights, as well as migration and mobility – accelerate results, progress and transformation to achieve the sustainable development goals.  And this will bring me to the issue of implementation. The new consensus binds us all, the EU institutions and Member States alike. In this respect, we all need to work to the best of our abilities on its implementation. The coordination and coherence between the actions will be key. Effective results can only be achieved through a tailor-made approach with our partner countries, involving both state and non-state actors. Inclusiveness is therefore essential in order to increase the ownership of our development policy by our partners. Last, but not least, on behalf of the Council I wish to thank this House, and in particular the two co-rapporteurs, Mr Neuser and Mr Wenta, as well as the Chair of the Committee on Development, Ms McAvan, for their dedication and constructive approach which resulted in an excellent agreement that is of benefit to both the EU and our development partners. The Council looks forward to the signature of the new European consensus during the European Development Days on 7 June.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, over the past few months, since the Commission put forward its proposal for a new European Consensus on Development, we have been working together with Parliament and the Council towards a joint statement, a new collective vision and a common framework for action in development policy for the European Union and all its Member States. The task of bringing 28 Member States, the Parliament with its different political groups, and the Commission together around such a far-reaching joint text is, without doubt, a formidable challenge. On many of the points for which Parliament has strongly advocated, the Commission would be willing to go even further. We have all had to seek compromises, but this only underlines the significance of what we are about to achieve. This text represents a genuine consensus, crafted through common effort and owned by us all. The new Consensus endorsed in the Committee on Development’s resolution also received unanimous support at a recent Foreign Affairs Development Council on 19 May. I would like to extend my sincere and wholehearted thanks to the Committee on Development and, in particular, the co—rapporteurs, Norbert Neuser and Bogdan Wenta, their colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs, and the Chair of the Committee, Linda McAvan, who have engaged systematically and constructively in our interinstitutional discussions on the new Consensus. I also want to thank honourable Members for all their previous contributions, including the resolution on the revision of the Consensus adopted by this House on 14 February this year, which is strongly reflected in the joint statement. The new European Consensus on Development represents a profound shift in our development cooperation, guided by the vision of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The European Union, as the world’s largest development actor, has a great responsibility in making sure that this vision is turned into reality. An ambitious new European Consensus for Development is a very important step in this direction, laying down a strong basis for maintaining the European Union’s global leadership in development.  The new Consensus unequivocally reaffirms that poverty eradication remains the primary objective of EU development policy. I want to be crystal clear on that. We will work to reduce vulnerabilities, address inequalities and ensure that no—one is left behind. We will aim to reach those furthest behind first. With this clear objective in mind, the Consensus enables us to respond better to the more complex and interconnected challenges that the world faces today. It sends an important political message, namely that Europe is determined to work better together, making the most of the joint capacities of the EU institutions and the Member States.  Our new Consensus closely reflects the 2030 Agenda structured around the five ‘P’s: people, planet, prosperity, peace and partnership. It integrates the economic, social and environmental dimensions of sustainable development and also underlines the links with other policies to make sure they take account of development concerns, including peace and security, humanitarian aid, migration, environment and climate. Therefore it also represents a significant contribution to the implementation of the Paris Agreement on climate change and the United Nations’ efforts to build sustainable peace for all. As regards the Migration and Development Nexus, I am convinced that what we need to offer is more partnership and more cooperation rather than less. Migration is an issue of common concern, common responsibility and common actions, in particular with our African partners. The Consensus takes a comprehensive approach to implementation, combining aid with other resources – public and private – sound policies and a strengthened approach to policy coherence for development. It explicitly reaffirms our collective Official Development Assistance commitments and guarantees that realistic and verifiable actions will be taken towards meeting them. We put strong emphasis on better tailored partnerships with a broader range of stakeholders and partner countries, stressing the importance of fully involving civil society, the European Parliament and the national parliaments in the implementation of the sustainable development goals. Through this Consensus, Europe strives to be not only the biggest but also the best and most effective development actor. Your endorsement of the Consensus at this plenary will be a milestone for our development cooperation. It should allow for signature at the highest political level at the European Development Days next week and it will provide the European Union with a very substantial deliverable for the United Nations high—level political forum on sustainable development in July.  At a time when the values of multilateralism and solidarity are called into question and the commitment of some to sustainable development seems to be wavering, Europe must pull its weight and help to keep global efforts on the right track. This Consensus is proof of our determination to do exactly that.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
