text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Thank you, Madam President. And also thank my colleague Neuser, who cannot be with us today, for his great cooperation. Of course, I would like to express my special thanks to our President McAvan for her support during this long and complicated negotiation process, and to the shadow rapporteurs, the Presidency, the Commission and the representatives of the European External Action Service for their commitment and work on this document, which is crucial from the perspective of the Union's development policy and the Member States. As has been said here, the main political goal of the new Consensus - which is closely linked to the 2020-2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals - is the fight against poverty, discrimination and inequality. In this context, Parliament has made strong efforts to take account of policy coherence and effectiveness in the development efforts of the Union and its members, as well as of other donors and organizations. ODA is of key importance to the Union's development policy. Therefore, reaching the target of 0.7% of gross national income by 2030 by Member States is an important commitment. The new consensus also relates to increasing funding for development policy, including through increased public-private partnerships, and the importance of fair and properly regulated trade. The link between development policy, migration and security is undeniable, as we are strongly aware of by the crises caused by conflict and instability. The new consensus will indicate the direction of solving the problem of the root causes of migration. We will vote tomorrow on a resolution on consensus. Once approved, President Tajani will also sign this joint statement at the European Development Days next week. I am convinced that this will be an important signal from the European Union and the Member States to uphold international decommissioning commitments poverty and achieving the SDGs.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I want to join Bogdan Wenta in thanking Norbert Neuser, who cannot be here today, for the work he has done with colleagues to get the text and focus on why we need a new Consensus on Development. We need one because we have to find a way for the EU to implement the sustainable development goals. We need one because we need a recommitment by the Member States today to tackle global poverty, and I think we need one most of all, today of all days, because we are hearing that Donald Trump will pull out of the Paris Agreement on climate change. That is a blow to sustainable development goals, a blow to what we want in Europe. So, today of all days, we should give a signal that Europe is prepared to step up and give the leadership we need, and that it will meet its global commitments to our collective future on this planet. The important things for me and for my Group in this Consensus are that we recommit; that poverty eradication is the primary goal of European development policy; that we make the commitment again to reach our target of 0.7% aid; and, for the first time in the Consensus, that 0.2% of our collective GDP will focus on the poorest countries. We are hearing that Africa is losing out on aid. We have to recommit. I know there are colleagues here, and colleagues I respect a lot, who are concerned about the emphasis placed by some governments on security and migration, and I know there is scepticism about whether or not countries will meet the 0.7%. I share some of those concerns and it is our job to hold governments to account and to make sure the consensus is implemented in the right way. But, above all, let us remember the other paragraphs in this text which talk about youth, unemployment, getting jobs and creating a future for the young people in developing countries. We need to send that signal today, and that is why I hope colleagues will support the Consensus.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, the revision of the 2005 European Consensus on Development was an absolute necessity, as much has changed on the world development map with the adoption of Agenda 2030 and sustainable development goals in the face of the new challenges facing humanity. An agreement is always difficult and compromises are inevitable. Fortunately, the new consensus sets the framework for the common principles and values ​​to be applied, both by the institutions and the states of the European Union, to the common development policy of Agenda 2030, because of the risks to which the poor are exposed. from lack of resources, food, water, care, education and protection are huge and must be eliminated. Development and democratic stability, the protection of human rights and the elimination of corruption are key factors in improving the living conditions of the poor, tackling uncoordinated migration, giving hope to young people and leaving no citizens behind. , as the Commissioner said.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, the European Consensus on Development is like NATO press releases. Only those who negotiated them can understand them. Participation in the consensus trilogue was very revealing from this point of view, for several reasons. We were able to see, once again, the limits of the unanimous decision. These limits are dictated in particular by the lowest budget of one or more Member States. No wonder then that the objective of devoting 0.7% of gross domestic product to official development assistance has become an Arlesian event, namely the event always announced but which never happens. Would it not be appropriate, therefore, to change the method, since that has not worked for almost 50 years? Not a single essential demand of the European Parliament has received the agreement of the Council, which has been intransigent following the blackmail exercised by a minority of Member States, and in particular by one. However, the European Parliament had overwhelmingly voted for clear and verifiable commitments, asking Member States to report to it on their efforts in the area of ​​official development assistance. It will not be. The few cryptic sentences that deal with this issue in this document barely mask the way in which some Member States despise the European Parliament. Go understand why all our member states agree to comply with the development assistance committee of the OECD, to inform the ambassadors of Japan, Mexico, New Zealand, the United States of the content of their policy and, at the same time, refuse to refer it to our Committee on Development? The promises concerning the 0.7% only seem to bind those who receive them. The European Development Consensus establishes the commitment of 0.7% of official development assistance, while in at the same time several member states announced substantial cuts in their official development assistance ahead of the Addis Ababa conference. Should we therefore believe those who are in favor of 0.7% or should we believe them when they say they want to go significantly below 0.7%? Admit that we have a credibility problem here. In addition, official development assistance has an eminently political dimension. With Brexit, we will lose one of the few Member States that devotes 0.7% of its GDP to it. It is not enough to gargle all day long that the European Union is the only global player in development. If we want to remain so after the departure of the United Kingdom, we must leave behind this sluggishness which accepts the laissez-faire and carelessness of the Member States in this matter. You will therefore understand that we abstain from the consensus vote and vote on our alternative joint resolution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, there are several aspects of the document that have emerged from the tripartite negotiations that are very far from the position voted by a very large majority in this House last February. The new Consensus opens the door to using official development aid to control migratory flows or, in other words, to outsource control of European borders to third countries, to countries in need. In other words, aid is conditioned on countries acting as buffer states so that forced migrants do not reach Europe, instead of using it to combat the root causes that force people to emigrate. This is just one example where it is shown that Parliament's position has been ignored during the negotiations. Others, for example, are those related to the 0.7% target, the securitization of aid or the gender issue. In short: we consider that Parliament's position has been ignored; We consider that the text represents an enormous setback with respect to the previous Consensus and, therefore, we will present an alternative Resolution that underlines all these positions.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! Many thanks also to our colleagues Neuser and Wenta, who really put a lot of work and energy into this work. Nevertheless, I have to say that for us Greens it is very clear: we cannot support this consensus. The European interior ministers are currently determining our foreign policy. They turn development policy into a domestic policy instrument. The Commission allows the member states to do their thing, and the External Action Service even supports them here! It is primarily about the self-interest of the EU, more about escape prevention, more money for the military, more flexibility also with the regional priorities - but less for poverty reduction. That is reflected in this consensus, and we Greens cannot support that. For us, development policy is a means of defusing blatant inequality and injustice in this world - a means of fighting poverty. It was said: This is also stated in the Lisbon Treaty, in Article 208. There is neither migration management nor security policy. The advocates of the consensus have of course also mentioned it, it is in the text: Combating poverty. Yes, sure, it's in there too. But we must not forget that the Council and the Commission are masters at rhetoric. Together with ALDE, GUE / NGL and EFDD, we have tabled a motion for a resolution that rejects the consensus and also explains why. I call on everyone who really cares about development policy to vote in favor of this motion for a resolution tomorrow.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, while this resolution talks about the laudable aim of reducing poverty worldwide, should the European Union not first look closer to home? For instance, in the UK between 2015 and 2016 there were 12.8 million people regarded as being in poverty, and the UK is one of the richest nations. When we come to the poorer nations in your Union, Commissioner, the figures are much worse. In 2015, 118.7 million – almost 25% of your population – were at risk from poverty. With the nations in real trouble, you see Bulgaria at 41%, Romania at 37%, and Greece at over 35%. Should you really be taking money from taxpayers in your own nation states, many of whom are already struggling with dire need, to further your own globalist ambitions? Why do you not, instead of chaining poor nations to our wallets with aid dependency, liberalise trade with poorer nations and give them a chance to compete on a level playing field instead of punishing them with your customs union? (Mr Finch declined to take a blue-card question from Ms Grapini)

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- Today you can read in the Dutch press that the EU wants to gain more control.That is, of course, a panic response to recent events.Today we read that the United States is withdrawing from the climate agreement.That climate treaty was actually the only success of the EU in recent years.In addition, the United Kingdom is running fast towards the exit, while Hungary and Poland are sailing their own course and do not care about the EU's urge to regulate, and rightly so.In practice, that grip will mainly be a grip on the wallet of the Dutch taxpayer.Because this EU is out to get a grip on the hundreds of billions in Dutch pension funds, on the other Dutch tax money and on Dutch legislation.So I beg you, Mr President, to stop this hopelessly failed project.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Madam President, I think we have to congratulate ourselves on this tripartite declaration on this new Consensus on Development in the world, and it seems to me that the title of the communication is a very suggestive title: "Our world, our dignity, our future" . I think that in view of the figures - the European Union is the main donor of development aid, the main donor of humanitarian aid - no one can say that we configure ourselves as a selfish Europe, although it is also true, Commissioner, that Every euro that is invested outside our borders is one euro that is also invested in Europe. It seems to me that this framework is certainly an adequate framework that has to be developed later in time and that places the problem, both in the internal dimension of the European Union-Member States and in the external dimension in the field of sustainable development goals of the United Nations. It distinguishes very well between the short and the long term. And in this context, Commissioner, I would like to convey a concern to you about the situation in middle-income countries. I hope, Commissioner, that, as has been announced in your Communication, other criteria can be found, apart from the per capita income criterion, because in these countries there are also large pockets of poverty.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Mr President, development policy may disappear from the international agenda. It would not be impossible, in view of what just happened with President Trump's decision and his commitment to breaking the agreements on climate change. It could disappear, and the truth is that it is probably still more necessary than ever. It is, perhaps, the last of the possibilities to really change the order of things, which makes half of humanity live in a situation of extreme poverty. This is a consensus. Of course, it is not the consensus that the Socialist Group would have made. It is very far from what we would have wanted, but this is the consensus that has been built taking into account, in addition, the Council that we currently have, which is not an easy Council for this policy. So, making a virtue of necessity, our Group will support this consensus. We believe that we are at the key defining moment between those who want to end development policy and those who want to turn development policy into anything but development policy. And that is why my group will support this consensus, even if it is not the consensus that I would have wanted.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: - Mister President! It has been more than ten years since the first declaration on the European Consensus on Development was signed. The world has changed a lot during this decade. Foci of conflict right on Europe's doorstep have increased rather than decreased. Many millions of people have been forced to leave their homes as a result of wars, civil wars or natural disasters, and terrorism threatens peaceful coexistence around the world. Development cooperation is facing many new challenges. This means that cooperation between donor states must be more closely networked. But it also means that new forms of cooperation must be found with the developing countries - e.g. also in the area of ​​security, because poverty reduction also requires security. The new European consensus must create the framework for this. As a co-signatory, the European Parliament must be fully involved in the implementation of the development goals. Many Thanks.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: - Mr President, a lot has happened in the world since more than a decade ago we approved the current European Consensus on Development.We have changed the development goals: we have made them more global and more ambitious.We have seen long-term humanitarian crises and conflicts associated with climate change.We have verified that we lack resources to finance development cooperation.It is for such a long time to review that consensus and to leap forward with a new consensus.In this new consensus, we have to apply daily policies that go beyond consensus to preserve that development policy is aimed at fighting poverty, to ensure that we reach 0.7% and to continue working so that no conditionality of a security naturecould put aid to those countries that need it, to those populations that are in a situation of dependency at risk.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, we must ensure that eradicating poverty and fighting inequality remain at the heart of EU development policy, including in the new Consensus. The Member States must put every effort into the successful implementation of Agenda 2020 and the sustainable development goals.  I welcome the fact that commitments on agriculture are more detailed than in the previous Consensus and include support for smallholder farmers and pastoralists, recognising the role they play in combating hunger and malnutrition. I would also like to congratulate the negotiators for including commitments to promote decent work, corporate social responsibility and the importance of social and environmental standards for European investment in developing countries. Last but not least, the withdrawal of the United States from the COP 21 Paris Agreement will jeopardise the influence and power of the USA in the world, and unfortunately in the long term it will affect the whole of mankind in a negative way.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the revision of the European consensus on development offers us a great opportunity, that of defining a common and coherent position with respect to some global changes that have occurred since 2005 on the world, social and economic scene and environmental. The challenges we face are many. We must safeguard the values ​​and objectives of development policy through the primary objective of the fight against poverty and, in the long term, its elimination. We need to respond with foresight to the changes underway by ensuring policy coherence on peace and security, migration, trade, environment and development and, finally, we need to anticipate trends that may emerge over the next fifteen years. Here, if the reference framework is ambitious, if the logic of the defense of human rights, democracy and good governance prevails, if we strengthen our role of peace and global justice, we will finally be able to contribute to the sustainable development of all areas of the planet.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to start from where Mrs Cécile Kyenge, with whose speech I totally agree, concluded, to say that I share this document, I share this new approach to consensus and I find it a bit unfair, if I must say, some of the criticisms I heard here today are a bit preconceived. Maybe we all wanted something more and better, but this is the point we have reached and I would not want to demean it, I would rather enhance it. It is reiterated that the primary objective is the fight against poverty. It is reiterated that it is necessary to work on development in all its dimensions and implications with consistency with respect to trade policies, with the theme of all other aspects, including that of migration. I do not think we should be afraid to recognize that if we create the fight against poverty we will be successful, if we create development with all the attention to local authorities, NGOs, all processes that arise from below, we will also make a contribution to, how to say, making these migrations, which today are a tragedy first of all for those who are victims, not for the countries of arrival, but for those who are victims, to make them more natural phenomena that we will accept and I must say more human to the same protagonists. I am not afraid to see these implications as well. The important thing is that we know what the primary priority of this plan is, of this method of the new consensus, but we must also be aware, if we do not want to live on the Moon, but to live in this century, in this Europe with this Africa and this Mediterranean, which are also the implications, which we must govern and not suffer. Govern by putting human rights and population development at the first point. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Charles GOERENS
text: question "blue card".- Mr President, I would like to ask Mrs Toia what her judgment would be if she had attended these negotiations in which we have rightly supported the ambitions of the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament in this area.Indeed, each time it was a question of showing good will to follow the commitments, to see to what extent they will be achieved, to ensure parliamentary control in the matter, we have always had an end of noto receive.This is not to denigrate the goals of development but to denounce the unbearable behavior of one or more States at Council level.With all due respect to our two co-rapporteurs, I would like to tell you that Mrs Linda McAvan and I have hit a wall: it is sad that the European Union is proceeding in this way.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- I can only say to my colleague that, having followed the negotiations a lot, I know how painful it is sometimes to have to accept a toughness, a wall on the part of some Member States or the entire Council.I too have sometimes had to submit to certain very tough positions of some Member States.If this is the possible result, I want to take it for a good result, knowing it could be better.But I do not consider the game closed, dear colleague, and as regards the position of Parliament, the control of Parliament, as regards other points not all is lost with the end of the negotiation, because we will have to implement all this and we will be able to recover.United not separated, all united as parliamentary forces, we will be able to recover what we have lost in the negotiations.It is not a definitive match, there is always a second half and there we will work to improve what we did not achieve in the first half.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: - Mr President, I would like to say the following. The first fundamental point is that, for this consensus on development, it is essential that countries do not follow a purely nationalist logic and, unfortunately, what we see is that the United States still today has given a signal regarding the sustainable development of being just focused on your national agenda. Now we, more developed nations and with more economic capacity, must be open to development and cooperation with States where a large part of the population lives in great poverty. Eradicating poverty, creating middle classes in these states is our responsibility, not only as full-body human beings, but also as political actors, who can, with this, solve many of the problems, which are not only those of these populations, are also ours. If we are able to help them, we are helping ourselves and that is what this consensus that we achieve here will naturally enhance.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of growing uncertainty in world politics, the communication adopted by the Commission on the new European consensus on development sets out a framework for action to respond to the current challenges in which the Union will have to play a leading role. first floor. European cooperation policy must aim at promoting the economic, social and environmental growth of developing countries, with the primary objective of eliminating poverty and helping to support democracy, the rule of law and human rights. It is essential to act bearing in mind the goals of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, which represents the international community's response to global challenges and trends in sustainable development. The pursuit of the Sustainable Development Goals will have to take place in close coordination with the Paris Agreement on climate change and other international commitments, beyond the decisions taken by the new American President.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Mr President, the so-called new European Union consensus on development is very revealing of the limits, contradictions and perversities of the policies carried out in this area in recent years. We are faced with an overview that, instead of respecting specificities and legitimate sovereign options of developing countries, aims to impose models of organization of society and the economy. It is, therefore, with the defense of the role of the private sector, prejudice against public ownership and management or with the imposition of public-private partnerships, just to give a few examples. Models that tend to perpetuate dependency, subordination and backwardness. It is an attempt to impose subordination to the geopolitical interests of the powers of the European Union, to their so-called security and migratory policies, of undisguised xenophobic and neocolonial features. These are credit lines at the expense of genuine development aid. It is pushing for more debt, instead of recognizing the unjust and illegitimate nature of the debt, which requires its cancellation. A new consensus that points, however, to an old, very old path.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, in the 1980s, Western countries adopted the famous "Washington Consensus", that is, the rules under which international and domestic economic policy would be conducted. The Washington Consensus was based on banking, market liberalization, business relocation, globalization, privatization, the casino economy, and austerity. The Washington Consensus has led to armies of the poor and unemployed, dismantled societies, and inflated private and public debt. The new European Consensus we are discussing here is also based on the failed principles of the Washington Consensus that inflated global debt. So instead of changing strategy, insist on continuing poverty and unemployment, which cannot be stopped unless we write off the debt of developing countries and write off the debt of the countries of the European South, abandon austerity and violent fiscal adjustment.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, the new European Consensus on Development is aimed at responding to current global trends and the challenges of globalisation. It has aligned the development policy of the EU and its Member States with the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The Consensus has achieved one of the top priorities of EU foreign policy, namely increased coordination and coherence between the EU and its Member States. Furthermore, in order to achieve more effective results and make a greater impact, it proposes a tailored and differentiated approach when working with partners to promote joint programming and implementation, with the full involvement of civil society and other actors. It highlights the importance of development effectiveness, transparency, mutual accountability, and ownership by all partners involved. Therefore, I fully support the new Consensus because it is an opportunity to make the EU even stronger and more prepared to tackle today’s global challenges and promote sustainable development. Finally, let us be more ambitious.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the European Union has been a global leader in sustainable development and it is right for Parliament, the Commission and the Council to now formulate a new position for this changing world. We need to make sure we have policy coherence so that our development cooperation, our trade and our economic policies all work together and, most importantly, align with international human rights norms. Coherence also requires taking into account the contribution of culture as a pillar of sustainable economic, social and human development and of peace and resilience building.  It is tragic to see my country, the UK, wasting its time with the chaos of Brexit while the EU continues to work towards a more prosperous sustainable future for all of us. The UK must continue its participation in EU development policy regardless of Brexit, and I hope that a Labour Government in Westminster will do just that.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, the new European common vision for global sustainable development to eradicate poverty, as a financial instrument and toolkit, is not achieving the objectives set. We have to respect certain basic principles, especially when we want to be called partners. For example, development is only acceptable when it is not to the detriment of other peers, nor can it be done with an agenda that is abusively and extortionately imposed, indirectly or directly. In the case of developing countries, those who take ownership of sustainable development priorities must commit to the results in terms of understanding, with all that that implies for bilateral partnerships, if that mutual respect is disrupted. The goal is not a development based on the spread of poverty and misery, but solid, sustainable development between equal partners, for the benefit of the people and all stakeholders.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Prime Minister, Commissioner, I totally agree, from the very beginning I say, with the new European consensus on development and you have given me hope, Prime Minister, I have recently returned from your country and I have saw what you could do there. I think that what you said, the first goal, the eradication of poverty, of course, must go from plan to concrete. You also said that we need to find the key to connecting the plans we make with reality. I regret that some colleagues here have raised the issue in an absolutely extremist way and say it very openly. Poverty must be eradicated, people's lives are the most important thing, we have children in poverty, it doesn't matter where these children live, we have to see how we make it stop regional disparities, such big differences between people's lives from one country to another or even within the same country between rural and urban. I wish the Council and the Commission success, and we, the European Parliament, to keep in mind that it is important and nothing can be more important than human life and raising the standard of living of all those who live on earth.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, today’s intense debate underscores the political significance of the text that we have before us. The European Union was instrumental in shaping the global 2030 Agenda, which is consistent with our vision and has now become the world’s blueprint for global sustainable development. The world is looking to us to live up to this role and lead the global implementation efforts by taking full account of the sustainable development goals in the European policy framework and in our priorities. We should not shy away from this responsibility. Development policy, in the form of this new Consensus, will make a central contribution in this direction. The Commission will give the highest priority to this effort and we remain committed to working closely together with Parliament and our Member States as we move forward. Together we can achieve more and spur action that can change lives across the world for the better, helping to end poverty in our generation. Please believe me that, without this Consensus, eradicating poverty, reaching our official development assistance (ODA) commitments, effectively tackling the root causes of migration, and ensuring the leading global role of the European Union in the implementation of the sustainable development goals will be much, much more difficult to achieve, if they are possible at all. In conclusion, let me thank Parliament once again, and in particular the co—rapporteurs, for your contribution to this important joint endeavour.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, as Commissioner Mimica – and also Mr Goerens – highlighted very well, the challenges of reaching consensus among all the Member States are huge. I can assure you that all the amendments negotiated by the Maltese Presidency are factual and firmly in line with the Treaties. Ms Sánchez Caldentey and Ms Heubuch raised the issue of the security sector. Firstly, as Ms McAvan so eloquently underlined, poverty eradication remains the primary objective of the new Consensus. At the same time, the security sector, subject to democratic governance and accountability, is – as we all know – essential to achieving peaceful and inclusive societies. Therefore I find the wording in the relevant paragraph a good compromise that opens new ways to include and firmly embed security in the overall sustainable development framework.  The debate today shows how important the new Consensus is for the future of our development policy. It paves the way for common implementation with all development partners over the years to come. While the negotiation process that is now behind us proved to be demanding in terms of identifying the main political priorities and the most efficient tools, and setting clear responsibilities, implementation will not be easy either. It will require a shared agenda and a joint effort from all of us, just as all three EU institutions have been able to cooperate while negotiating on the Consensus. I can assure you that the Council will take its share of responsibility for the implementation of the Consensus and I look forward to cooperating with Parliament in this important endeavour.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 1 June 2017.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on: - an oral question to the Council by Linda McAvan, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on resilience as a strategic priority of the EU's external action ((O-000032/2017 - B8-0312 / 2017), -Oral reply to the Commission by Linda McAvan, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on resilience as a strategic priority of the EU's external action (O-000033/2017 - B8-0313 / 2017) and - Question for oral answer to the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union forForeign Affairs and Security Policy by Linda McAvan on behalf of the Development Committee on resilience as a strategic priority for the EU's external action (O-000034/2017 - B8-0314 / 2017).

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr representative of the Council, the European Union already has on its balance sheet a wide catalog of initiatives in favor of the provision of resilience in various parts of the world: at the beginning of this decade reacting to food crises and, shortly thereafter, approving an Action Plan for Resilience, aimed at those countries with recurring crises for the period 2013-2020. The Council, Parliament and the Commission have worked together in the preparation of meetings, resolutions and decisions and in the assumption of commitments in different world summits: starting with the Sendai Summit, on risk prevention in natural disasters; followed by the New York Summit, changing the dimension and ambition of the development goals; drawing attention at the Addis Ababa Summit to the lack of financing for development; supporting at the Istanbul Summit a greater commitment in the response to the humanitarian crises that plague the world, and, finally, in Paris, where a great responsible president took a leap for the prevention of risks to humanity - because, with the change We risk not only what our world will be like, but even if our world will exist. And, now, a small president has taken a leap back that puts the resilience of the world as a whole at risk. With this Resolution, we express our satisfaction with the recognition of the importance of resilience in the framework of the global strategy, as a priority element for the Union's external action. We reaffirm the need for the Member States of the Union to fulfill their commitments regarding development aid, especially by reaching 0.7% of this gross domestic product. We highlight the multisectoral nature of resilience, which affects, of course, the economic dimension, the environmental dimension, the social dimension, the political dimension and the dimension of security, but whose center and focus is the human being in the midst of all these highly multidimensional characters. We urge the Commission to incorporate resilience into its political dialogue with other global actors, and we underline the special position of humanitarian aid, which must be provided with the utmost respect for the principles of humanity, neutrality, impartiality, independence and the protection of human rights. Respect for these principles is an essential condition in order to subsequently demand access to populations in need and to guarantee the protection of humanitarian actors. We underline the importance of disaster risk reduction and call on the Union to ensure that the new Communication, which will appear in the coming days, is in line with the commitments made in the Sendai Framework and with the Development Action Plan of this Frame. We also call for inclusive local and national disaster risk reduction strategies to be formulated. We call for special emphasis to be placed on protecting the most vulnerable groups, the poorest populations, minorities, families, women, children, migrants, people affected by AIDS, LGTB people, people with disabilities. . We call for programming with a gender perspective, and we also highlight the need to expand the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and the Kampala Convention to protect displaced persons. We underline that resilience is based on respect for human rights, the strength of democracy, the rule of law, good governance and trust in institutions. All of these constitute objectives that should be promoted in application of the Global Strategy of the European Union, and we ask that it cover not only the territorial framework closest to us, where crises develop, whose effects come closer to us, but also global geographic.We want to serve all parts of the world, with special attention to the most fragile countries.And, finally, we understand that providing education to children in humanitarian crisis is not just giving them a right that belongs to them, but also preventing further conflicts and restoring peace where it has been definitively broken.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, the global strategy for the European Union’s foreign and security policy identified state and societal resilience as one of the five priorities of the Union’s external action, with enhanced attention to the EU’s near and broader neighbourhood. The Foreign Affairs Council in October 2016 called for the five priorities to be swiftly translated into concrete policy initiatives and action. Therefore, the Council very much looks forward to receiving the upcoming joint communication by the Commission and the High Representative on the strategic approach to resilience in the EU’s external actions.  The Council stands ready to bring forward the discussions on this topic. The EU acknowledges the need to move away from crisis containment to a more structural, long-term and non-linear approach to vulnerabilities, with an emphasis on prevention and stabilisation. Indeed, we need an integrated approach to conflicts and crises, for thus we contribute to enhancing the EU’s own resilience and that of our citizens.  The nexus between security and development and between the internal and external dimensions will be at the core of the new approach, with full respect for the EU’s commitment to the observance of fundamental human rights and the rule of law. I look forward to hearing the debate today.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this opportunity to continue the conversation on our common work on our global strategy. The strategy does not belong only to the Commission or the Council. It is a strategy for the whole European Union, for all our institutions, for all Member States and, most importantly, for all our citizens. This joint communication on resilience is no exception.  As you know, a wide consolidation process and a fruitful dialogue with Parliament preceded the writing of the communication. It should be adopted at the beginning of June. In the second half of the month, High Representative Mogherini will present a report on the global strategy’s first year of implementation. The timing is no coincidence. When the work towards the strategy began, we decided that it should be not simply a security strategy but something much broader. The global strategy recognises that there is no security without resilience, human development, human rights and democracy for all, in Europe and beyond.  Since then, much of the media’s attention has focused on the defence part of the social strategy’s implementation. With this joint communication, we want to stress that our work on resilience is just as important and is also moving fast. We have, of course, not started from scratch. The joint communication builds on the experience gained since the 2012 Commission communication, the 2015 review of the European Neighbourhood Policy and the EU work on resilience on the ground. Today’s EU resilience policies are supported by evidence of good practice from the Sahel and the Horn of Africa. Lessons learned will be set out in more detail in an accompanying staff working document. The joint communication will also ensure continuity with the 2013-2020 Action Plan for Resilience in Crisis-Prone Countries, which will continue to be implemented. When we evaluate the implementation of the Action Plan, we can see that progress has been especially positive in some thematic areas such as food and nutrition security and sustainable agriculture, or in humanitarian programmes for a protracted crisis. We also see that significant changes are underway in other areas, such as urban resilience, predictable and flexible financing and social protection. At the same time, the old way of doing things is not enough. On the one hand, the challenges we face have evolved in nature and in scope. They require a stronger and more coordinated response from us. On the other hand, we finally understand that better coordination within the European Union and with our partners can create new opportunities for our citizens and our friends. Let me go through some of the new ideas that shape the joint communication. Firstly, this is part of a global effort to improve the impact of our policies on sustainable development and resilience. The EU Consensus on Development also captures this idea and is key in this regard. With the joint communication we want to put at the core of our policies the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the 2015 Paris Agreement, the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction and the commitments to action made at the World Humanitarian Summit last year. The question now is how we secure progress towards these commitments in the face of a more fluid landscape of global challenges and risks. Strengthening resilience is part of the strategic response to this challenge. It helps to promote a way of working that moves us away from crisis containment to a more structural, long—term approach to vulnerabilities with an emphasis on prevention. Secondly, the joint communication aims at improving cooperation among all players inside our Union. This includes all institutions, the Member States and all political, development and humanitarian actors. For instance the joint communication will stress the need to streamline the current multiplicity of overlapping risk-assessment processes. Such a streamlined assessment would integrate, in a more systematic and dynamic way, information from our diplomatic network and from humanitarian and development actors, as well as the specialised knowledge about the external environment held by the EU’s internal policies, DGs and agencies. With the global strategy, we have agreed on principles and objectives that we all share. We can now work to join forces towards pursuing these objectives as a true union. Thirdly, in a world where power is much more diffused, we need to engage well beyond state actors. Resilience has to be addressed at multiple levels – not only at government level but also inside societies and communities. Local government and civil society are often the basis on which resilience can take root and grow at community level. We all know that, in every society, women are key factors of resilience as an engine for development, as problem solvers and as peacemakers. Nowhere is this truer than in fragile or conflict—riven societies. The communication too will fully recognise this. When we talk about the resilience of states and societies, we know that the two must go hand in hand, so we will put more emphasis, not less, on engaging these non-state actors, including the private sector, as we are already doing with the European External Investment Plan.  Finally, our world is much more connected than it has ever been. Clearly our work begins in the European Union’s vicinity. This is not surprising, given the special political commitments of the accession process and the European Neighbourhood Policy, but we also know that instability in our neighbourhoods can easily spill out. The only way truly to strengthen our immediate region is to look further and think globally. We believe this joint communication will help us to be more effective in our action on resilience, to the benefit of our partners and also in the interest of investing taxpayers’ money more effectively. So we really look forward to Parliament’s engagement towards stronger EU action for a safer Europe in a more stable, prosperous and democratic world.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! I very much welcome the joint declaration announced for June by the European External Action Service and the Commission on resilience as a strategic priority for the European Union's external action. The declaration can provide the basis for diplomatic efforts, foreign policy and development cooperation to work together in future to implement development cooperation goals in order to make them sustainable. In addition, different policy areas such as For example, humanitarian aid, disaster risk reduction, climate protection and development measures are better linked, and domestic and foreign policy are better coordinated. The discussion with the partner countries - especially the Cotonou Agreement - about continuing cooperation beyond 2020, the end of the Cotonou Agreement, can receive new impulses and content, and development cooperation can thus be placed on a solid foundation. The European Parliament's proposals for this process have been formulated in the motion for a resolution and the European Parliament is ready to cooperate further on this.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if we really want resilience to become a strategic priority of the European Union's external action, then we must fully grasp its potential, to contribute, in the long term, to the promotion of sustainable development not only addressing the consequences of increasingly recurring crises, but also going back to their root causes. What we are asking of the Commission and the Council is to preserve the multidimensional nature of resilience and provide it with sufficient financial resources. It is essential that Union actions on resilience are planned in concert between humanitarian assistance and development assistance, also in order to ensure maximum complementarity between actions and to ensure that short-term interventions lay the foundations for medium-term ones. and long term. In the next communication, the Commission will have to ensure that resilience and stability lead to respect for human rights, the strengthening of democracy, the rule of law and good governance, as well as the promotion of essential public services such as education, health, drinking water and sanitation aimed at improving resilience. It is important that in this process there is the full involvement of the populations concerned and of civil society, also with a particular focus on food security, with particular attention to the role of women, to a greater recognition of their role and a better protection of their rights.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, millions of people live in appalling conditions, both in the European Union and in the rest of the world, where most of the dangers are man-made. Creating societies capable of dealing with internal and external threats is of paramount importance. Our effort must be to strengthen the resilience of societies, that is, to support and protect populations from conflict, violent displacement, poverty, discrimination, corruption, slavery, climate change. It is important that the European Union's foreign policy focuses on promoting resilience by developing early warning and rapid response systems, that is, by engaging in social and economic crisis prevention policies. This requires targeting and efficiency in the provision of development aid and control over the provision of humanitarian aid. Only in this way will sustainable development be achieved and the needs of the poor people be protected, which will protect them from uncontrolled and dangerous displacement and all the accompanying dangers.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me begin by saying that I share the concerns expressed by my colleagues. Resilience is indeed a concept that has progressively made its way into EU development policies: 2015 was a milestone year as regards development and the idea of resilience in the EU’s eyes. The Commission rightly introduced a resilience marker in its humanitarian implementation plans. This was certainly a good step in a good direction. Today’s world is characterised by increasingly complex challenges – climate change, displacement, pandemics, extremism, population movements etc. Such challenges test the resilience of communities and institutions as well as the ability of regional and international organisations to support affected societies. Therefore, development and humanitarian aid should no longer be about responding to crises after they have occurred. They should also be about helping people and communities to withstand crises and shocks, and helping them to anticipate those and to be better prepared when they happen. This is true not only for state institutions but also for the non-state actors, civil society, NGOs and individuals who have to learn how to cope with complex risks. Building resilience, particularly in a fragile state, is a long-term commitment. It has to be done not only when TV cameras are around but also when nobody can predict the next conflict, tragedy or poverty situation. Let me conclude by emphasising that the EU Member States need to show stronger willingness to work in that direction and ensure that their words are matched by the requisite financial contributions.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, we have heard ad nauseam how uncertainty reinforces the need to promote new models of governance that strengthen resilience. Numerous studies have shown that resilient democracies enjoy lower levels of social violence and higher rates of well-being. For this reason, we are deeply concerned about how the Union will promote the alignment of this new initiative with many of our international commitments such as the 2030 Agenda, the Paris Agreement or the World Humanitarian Summit. Building resilience must overcome narrow visions based, for example, on security. This is a question strongly linked to the totality of a political and social system. That is why, beyond the what, we care about the hows. The decentralization of the energy model, food production, the promotion of open knowledge or the advancement in processes of democratic participation are crucial issues for the fulfillment of our international commitments and, also, essential elements for the construction of truly resilient societies.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Mr President, resilience means the ability of a state to withstand pressure and shocks, to absorb them and to recover quickly. At the present time, on all continents, there are many countries facing vulnerabilities that the European Union wants to eliminate, in the context of the leading role it wants to play as a global economic and political power. Thus, the European Union is interested in strengthening the resilience of the countries of Central Asia, Central Africa, the Horn of Africa, the Sahel region, and even the resilience of the countries of the Western Balkans and Turkey. But there is a country whose resilience, despite belonging to it, the European Union is not interested in. This country is Greece. For the seventh consecutive year, Greece is suffering from the imposition of unacceptable terms of the memorandum and the presence of millions of illegal immigrants in it. The Greeks are suffering, they are in danger of extinction and the country's economy has been destroyed. The European Union does not have the capacity or the will to deal with this modern genocide because it cannot resist the demands of the German Government, as expressed by Mr Schieble. Not in debt relief, yes in reducing wages, and therefore in the impoverishment of Greeks. Not in the removal of illegal immigrants and, of course, no mention of the repayment of Germany's debt to Greece. As long as the unacceptable terms of the memoranda are applied in Greece, discussions like the present one will be held simply to impress the naive and the uninformed.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Mr Chairman! Resilience is a concept that appears frequently in the public debate about development policy and humanitarian aid. This is a positive sign that the Commission has decided to make resilience a strategic priority for the Union's external action and has committed to updating the 2012 document and continuing with the Action Plan until 2020. Negative effects of conflicts and disasters have long-term and significant economic, social and social impacts , health, culture and the environment. It is especially acute at local and community level. Societies and countries at risk of conflict and natural disasters struggle to cope with their consequences, and we therefore urge the Commission in its communication to include resilience as a major element in its political dialogue with developing countries. We also underline the importance of joint programming of Union resilience actions in order to ensure maximum complementarity and less fragmentation of humanitarian and development aid.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, building resilience means creating a more responsive Union, and is key to forging strong partnerships. We must reiterate our call to the Commission and the Council to incorporate existing EU policies in the new initiative and ensure their continuity. In addition, the new initiative should promote alignment with international commitments, comply with development effectiveness principles, promote a coherent EU approach to resilience and the complementarity of EU development, humanitarian, foreign and security policies, with a particular focus on the needs of the most vulnerable populations while highlighting the role of local actors and civil society. It is fundamentally important to strengthen the resilience of states and societies by supporting good governance and accountable institutions and working closely with civil society.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). - Mr President, I will add another dimension to the resilience that my colleagues have rightly pointed out. There can be no resilience and stability for the European Union's external action unless the European Union proves that it can protect and safeguard its external borders, can protect and preserve peace in the Member States of the European Union. Today's violations by Turkey and the insults to the sovereignty of Member States, such as Cyprus and Greece, are a direct challenge and insult to the European Union itself. And if the European Union does not respond to safeguarding and protecting its credibility through a specific strategy for protecting its external borders, then all its policies are being tested and we cannot talk about resilience and stability. The European Union must guarantee to Member States such as Cyprus and Greece that Turkey, a candidate country for accession to the European Union, cannot, on a daily basis, infringe on the dignity and credibility of the European Union itself. I call on the High Representative of the European Union, Mrs Mogherini, to finally understand that she must send a clear message to Turkey, stressing that it cannot provoke and offend the very credibility of the European Union, and that we must finally understand that. In closing, I want to emphasize that peace is needed to ensure stability. The President of the Republic of Cyprus, Madam President, made a peace proposal to Turkey and to Mr. Akıncı, for a solution to the Cyprus problem. Not only was it not accepted, but offensively Turkey wants to continue to be in Cyprus, a quick guarantor, and to keep the troops. This is also unacceptable… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Madam President, we have built resilience in external action. We need a European Union with tools and strategic autonomy to ensure internal and external security for citizens. We therefore need a European foreign policy and a common security and defense policy, empowered with cooperation and sharing between Member States, to respond effectively to transnational and global threats. We need strategic and coherent external action in different areas, including a consensus for development, which gives priority to the elimination of poverty, the empowerment of civil societies, the empowerment of women, democracy, the rule of law, respect for human rights and humanitarian principles. Without that, there will be no good governance, nor will we achieve the millennium development goals and sustainable development. Rulers work against resilience, following the xenophobic rhetoric that associates migrants and refugees with terrorists, when, after attack, it turns out that the so-called foreign fighters are, in fact, European citizens. Making our cities resilient, in particular against terrorism, implies changing the self-defeating anti-Islamic narrative; combat social exclusion, inequalities and job destruction. It also implies promoting multicultural coexistence and global regulation.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: - Madam President, at the beginning I would like to thank the authors for a quality text and colleagues for a quality discussion on a very important topic. For us, the global strategy of the European Union for foreign and security policy and strengthening the resilience and capacity of partner countries focuses on the priorities of external action of the European Union so that they themselves are able to solve internal and external crises they face and ensure normal civilian action and strengthening development. efficiency. What I consider important is that existing aid instruments must be used more effectively. It is important to emphasize that better coordination of the European Union's external action instruments with the financial instruments of other international development institutions should be ensured. Better coordination will ensure synergies, help implement key reforms and implement important projects that could help strengthen resilience in these countries. But before that, it is necessary to conduct an analysis and possible overlaps in funding before better coordination is achieved. I hereby ask the Commission what it intends to do on this issue.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Now we come to the catch-the-eye procedure.I have seven requests to speak.I would like to let everyone have their say.However, the prerequisite is that you all please keep to the one minute.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, according to OECD data, one and a half billion people live in 56 countries identified as fragile. The situation of fragility, largely determined by human factors, has repercussions on the vulnerability of populations due to conflicts and insecurity, lack of access to health care, extreme poverty, economic crises and has direct and indirect consequences for the European Union, which must necessarily take this into account in the implementation of its foreign and security policy strategy. The new joint communication must recognize and support the promotion of resilience as an essential element of the sustainable development strategies of partner countries, in particular fragile countries. Systematic efforts and coherent policy actions are needed to alleviate the root causes of the crisis and enhance the ability to manage uncertainty and change. The development of resilience in partner countries is a long-term process that must be integrated into any external action of the Union, ensuring that European policies do not undermine the efforts of developing countries to achieve the sustainable development goals.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the resilience of societies to modern economic and social challenges is necessary especially at this historical juncture, characterized by poverty, unemployment, social inequalities and global hunger. But in order for societies to be resilient, the causes of this situation must be eliminated, not just the symptoms. This means a fair distribution of the wealth produced, abandonment of globalization, the casino economy and austerity. In addition, it's required to write off the debt of developing countries and the countries of the European South, especially Greece, which has been turned into a debt colony by armies of the poor and unemployed. Only in this way will the resilience of societies be strengthened, otherwise everything else will constitute a rhetoric characterized by the well-known bilingualism. The troika cannot dissolve Greece and we can talk about resilience.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, as we all know, the European Union global strategy refers to building state and societal resilience in the Union’s neighbourhood as one of the key strategic priorities for the EU. In the context of EU foreign policy, building resilience in the neighbourhood has been understood as the capacity of different layers of society to withstand, adapt to and recover quickly from stresses and shocks. The EU uses the concept of resilience as an answer to the growing complexity of the international security environment and the ongoing instability on its southern and eastern borders. Therefore, I call on the Commission to use the concept of resilience with nation states because they remain the key actors in societies capable of bringing about real changes and reform. In the long-term, placing more focus on nation states will increase the efficiency and credibility of EU foreign policy.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, although we live in a time that allows many to live in a luxury hitherto unseen, 1.6 billion people are in 56 countries described as unstable. We should ask: How did this actually happen? And we must always say quite flatly that the European colonial powers have tried to suck up these countries economically. When they left these countries, multinational corporations fell in love with them, and looting continued. It is only in recent decades that we are finally beginning to talk about how the basic public services, such as education, health, water and sanitation, needed to increase the resilience of these countries are being strengthened. We have seen them for many years as a means of building wealth, and now we must secure a future that they cannot do without, not least because we cannot afford the instability and crumbling states close to the European Union.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the phrase ‘resilience in external action’ might seem a little opaque to some, but what it means is crucial in today’s changing world. Resilience means the ability of states and societies to withstand and recover from external and internal crises. What we are seeing throughout the world, from the economic crisis to the Arab Spring and democratic uprisings, is how important civil society organisations and democratic institutions are in keeping a society from breaking down. When social tensions rise, the ability to organise and speak to one another becomes crucial. Arts and culture, artists, creators and journalists play a crucial role in societies in crisis by facilitating expression, communication and intercultural dialogue. They can often make the difference between peace and war. When conflict breaks out, artists, writers and thinkers can often lead the way to reconciliation, and this is why the EU must invest more in promoting cultural diplomacy and exchange.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Prime Minister, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the authors on this question from the outset. It was time to find out what new concept you have of resilience, given the global changes that are taking place and I strongly believe that all development, humanitarian, external, security policies must all lead to respect for human rights. We have many discriminated people in the world and in the European Union, and I do not only mean gender discrimination, I mean citizens, children, who do not have access to education, food, health, children from many countries in remote areas, more chosen from the rural environment, where they do not have the chance of a professional training, of a preparation for a future family life. In this sense, I believe that in the global context, the European institutions must think together with the other institutions how we go about the causes, what we do with the conflicts that create problems and lead children and families in many parts of the world.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Madam President, in addition to everything else that the European Union's foreign and security policy has to be unacceptable, there is a certain cynicism, a certain hypocrisy, in this global strategy that defines resilience as one of the priorities of the European Union's external action . The European Union, which promotes aggression, interference, and destabilization of sovereign countries, then elects the state and societal resilience of the victims as a strategic priority. Facing East and South, this strategy has in Ukraine and Syria a complete and exemplary demonstration of its objectives and its consequences. It would be better if the priority were to focus on scrupulous respect for international law, the United Nations Charter and the principles contained therein: from respect for national sovereignty to the peaceful resolution of conflicts. It would be better not to try to make a supposed development aid the screen for the affirmation of the imperial ambition and the geostrategic interests of the European powers and their economic groups.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have very much appreciated this debate and the pertinent questions. This all shows that the question of resilience is central to our work and that Parliament is very aware of this. In addition to what I said in my opening remarks, let me add some more information about our approach, which is in the joint communication. It deals not only with security, but also with economic and environmental resilience and, furthermore, the concept identifies state, societal and community resilience, which is closely linked to humanitarian and development aid. These means contribute to building democratic states and support societies.  We look forward to continuing the debate with you after the adoption of the joint communication on 7 June.

name: João FERREIRA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I do not have much to add to what Commissioner Jourová said in her introductory remarks and just now in the concluding discussion. Both of us have, of course, taken careful note of this very useful discussion today. The Council, for its part, in its conclusions from October 2016, has already highlighted its support for action at EU level on resilience. We very much look forward to the forthcoming joint communication by the Commission, and the High Representative and I look forward to continuing discussions in the European Parliament on that matter.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: To wind up the debate, a motion for a resolution has been tabled under Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure.That closes the debate.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 1 June 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I support this resolution because I welcome the fact that resilience is a priority in the EU's external action.We need a coherent political framework for resilience of our external action, in particular by promoting sustainable development, human rights, political dialogue and conflict resolution.

name: David McALLISTER
text: written. - The multitude of international crises and conflicts puts the resilience of the European Union to the test. In these times, the EU must not just react, it must actively shape it by acting together and resolutely in an increasingly complex world. With the migration crisis, the still tense situation in eastern Ukraine, the war in Syria and the unstable political situation in North Africa, it is no longer enough to limit yourself to yourself. Freedom, security, democracy and human rights are not an end in themselves and need to be anchored in our neighboring regions. Less developed countries and fragile states must be supported and promoted. Coordinated action by the EU is therefore more necessary than ever before in order to be able to meet these challenges. The European Union's resilience strategy shows the right way to enable our partner states to withstand future crises through efficient reforms. It enables democratic governments to react quickly and unitedly in order to preserve stability, freedom and security in order to also help in the migration crisis and to combat the causes of flight. That is why it is important to use it to strengthen the independent action of our partner countries and to accompany and support them on the path to long-term and sustainable development.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. - We live in times of increasing globalization, which affects more and more sectors. It is a process that cannot be stopped, but it should be understood and shaped so that EU Member States can find their place on a competitive global market. Among the problems of increasing importance and posing a serious threat and risk factor in the context of the proper functioning and development of enterprises, including those belonging to the agri-food sector, there are, for example, price volatility and various cases of unfair competition. Increasing resilience in individual sectors and, more generally, expressed in various EU policies deserves to be taken seriously also in the context of the numerous concluded and negotiated trade agreements conducted by the EU with various third countries or groups of these countries (CETA, TTIP, negotiations with Japan, Mercosur countries, etc.). The efforts of the EU services responsible for the EU's external action should therefore largely focus on analyzing the risks at national and regional level and improving the monitoring of the impact of external factors to allow for timely and appropriate action. In order to facilitate such activities and increase capacity for crisis prevention, a useful initiative would also be the development of international policies and arrangements in this area.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - In the context of the upcoming publication of the Communication from High Representative / Vice-President of the European Commission, Federica Mogherini, entitled "Resilience as a strategic priority for the EU's external action" it is worthwhile for the European Parliament to make a clear contribution to the preparation of this document. Especially since it is one of the five priorities listed in the EU global strategy. The resolution prepared for this occasion is a good document that explains how the concept of resilience is understood, with particular emphasis on its importance for development policy. In it, the EP points to the multidimensional nature of resilience, which is both a human, economic and political factor, as well as a security factor. We have already emphasized many times in this House that there is no development without a sense of security and political, institutional and social stability. The process of building partner countries' resilience is a long-term activity. Its effects are rarely seen right away. However, this should not make us doubt its effectiveness. Therefore, long-term financial guarantees for such projects should be provided. And that is what I would like to make today.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on combating anti-Semitism (2017/2692 (RSP)).

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank you for the opportunity to speak today on combating anti-Semitism. It is a topic of common concern to us all. Let me start by expressing my deep concern about the current situation in Europe. Evidence from different sources, including the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights and the Council of Europe, shows an alarming increase in intolerance and hatred. There exists specific data collected by the Fundamental Rights Agency confirming that every fourth Jew in Europe has experienced verbal or physical violence. It is difficult to believe and understand that so many in our society reject the fundamental values of tolerance, respect and liberty, and instead choose to hate.  What can be done to address anti-Semitism? This issue was discussed in more general terms during the conference on positive narratives against hate speech, which the Maltese Presidency organised in April this year. Experts from Member States, international organisations, academia and civil society agreed that there was no single perfect remedy for hatred. As is often the case, we need a complex response that starts with education, data collection and analysis, and ends with condemnation and criminal sanctions.  Let me start with the measures I mentioned last, condemnation and criminal sanctions. The EU has adopted specific legislation on combating intolerance and hatred, namely the 2008 Framework Decision on combating racism and xenophobia. This decision outlaws Holocaust denial and anti-Semitic hate speech inciting violence. In particular, it prohibits under criminal law condoning, denying or grossly trivialising the Holocaust.  In June 2016, the Council stressed the importance of this legal instrument and invited Member States to ensure its effective transposition and implementation, in addition to other relevant hate crime laws at national level. Furthermore, the Council asked Member States to develop effective methods to report and ensure proper recording of hate crimes.  In the context of hate speech, the Council supports the Commission High Level Group, which seeks to develop, together with the Member States, concrete practices and tools to improve responses to racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance. This group is actually meeting today and tomorrow, and one of the items on the agenda concerns specifically the Week of Action on Combating anti-Semitism and anti-Muslim hatred. There will also be an opportunity to discuss the rights of victims of hate crimes. On several occasions, the Council has called on Member States to ensure the full and correct implementation of the EU legislation, notably the EU Directive on the rights of victims of crime. I hope that the expertise from the High Level Group experts will bring us closer in our common endeavour. However, let me stress that all these countermeasures will be in vain if we forget the important role of education and youth work. More precisely, it is crucial to know the history of our continent to understand the value of tolerance and to be able to counter anti-Semitism when confronted with it. In the context of awareness-raising and policy advice, we are grateful to the European Fundamental Rights Agency for its continued monitoring of, and research into, discrimination and anti-Semitism and for offering evidence-based solutions and suggestions.  I would like to conclude by stressing once again how important it is to combat anti-Semitism. I would like to recognise the work of the first European Commission Coordinator on combating anti-Semitism, Katharina von Schnurbein. We have different tools: we have knowledge, we have education, we have counter-narratives, but we also have condemnation of any form of anti-Semitic violence, hate speech or discrimination. Accordingly, the responsibility rests with all of us – politicians, teachers, students, parents and, if need be, also judges and prosecutors. No one can close his or her eyes or ears and pretend not to see injustice, discrimination or hatred. An important part of the exhibition in the recently opened House of European History, which was founded at the European Parliament’s initiative, is devoted to the genocide of European Jews. It is the duty of our continent, and our shared responsibility, to remember and not to let it happen again.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, combating anti-Semitism is indeed a very important and alarming topic, considering the statistical evidence which the Minister has just mentioned. I very much welcome Parliament’s debate and the motion for a resolution. Increasing fear and high rates of verbal and physical violence against ethnic, religious and other minorities across Europe are a major concern, and it is our duty not only to discuss this but also to come forward with solutions. Data show a clear spike in anti—Semitic incidents. There was more than one incident a day in Austria and three incidents per day in the United Kingdom in 2016, in both cases the highest numbers ever recorded. We are particularly worried about discrimination and harassment against Jewish youngsters, who are more likely to experience anti-Semitism in schools and universities. A hostile environment in schools will put the next generation at risk of exclusion. All of us, collectively and individually, have the duty to fight against intolerance and hatred and reject all expressions of them.
