We welcomed yesterday’s Joint Day of Action, with Parliament, on combating anti-Semitism and anti-Muslim hatred, which brought together Jewish and Muslim youngsters. Today we are opening two funding calls for applications, making available EUR 5.5 million to support civil society and Member States’ authorities in better preventing and countering racism and xenophobia, including anti—Semitism and other forms of intolerance, hate crime and hate speech. Particular areas of attention include hate-crime training, empowering and supporting hate-crime victims, and improving recording, as well as data collection and methodologies. Also, at today’s meeting of the High—Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other intolerance I presented the results of the implementation of the Code of Conduct we concluded in May 2016 with major IT companies to combat illegal hate speech online. I can inform you today that significant progress has been made and all IT companies have been improving their reaction to notifications concerning manifestly illegal hate speech, including anti-Semitic hate speech. Let me also inform you that I have asked the EU Fundamental Rights Agency to conduct a large-scale survey on the experience of Jews with anti-Semitism. We expect the results by early next year. It will be the first time that we have comparable data on trends around anti—Semitism across the EU, following an initial survey in 2013. On the occasion of this year’s Holocaust Remembrance Day we made the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance definition of anti-Semitism available through our website. The Commission welcomes any useful tool that helps to prevent anti-Semitism. Several Member States, including the UK and Austria, which I have already mentioned, use this definition in their policymaking and training and in data collection on anti-Semitic incidents and hate crimes. As you know, following our first Annual Colloquium on Fundamental Rights, the Commission appointed a Coordinator on Combating anti—Semitism, tasked with liaising with Jewish communities and with advancing and mainstreaming Commission action against anti—Semitism. She is here today. We must learn from the past, in order to ensure that nobody is persecuted for what he or she is, stands for or believes in.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, and representative of the Council. With this resolution, the European Parliament is showing a clear sign of responsibility and political decision-making power. In the future, we can fight anti-Semitism across Europe more effectively. I would therefore also like to thank the co-authors of the resolution - first and foremost Mr Aguilar and Mr Wikström - with whom an extraordinarily professional collaboration has produced a serious and excellent result. There is an urgent need for action given the increasing number of anti-Semitic incidents in Europe. It must be our common goal that the Jewish population in Europe can live without acts of violence and physical attacks, without hate speech and terror in social media, children go to school, drive people to work, visit the synagogue and spend their free time without fear and Spend threat. I am confident that more and more member states can be persuaded to follow the example of Great Britain and - to my delight - also my home country Austria and to form a starting point with the EU-wide uniform definition of anti-Semitism according to the IHRA definition which we can fulfill the prosecution of anti-Semitic perpetrators through new police work and clear justice. I appeal to all Members of the European Parliament to strongly support this resolution, and I thank you in advance for that.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, as a constitutionalist, professor of Constitutional and Academic Law, as a socialist and as a representative of citizens, I have always worked for fundamental rights and against all forms of discrimination against people or minorities due to their belonging to an orientation sexual - LGBT -, because of their belonging to an ethnic community - gypsies, the Roma population - and because they also belong to a cultural and religious identity, such as the Jewish population in Europe, in the Member States of the European Union. That is why I promote this Resolution and have signed it with the full conviction that it sends a signal of solidarity with the victims of the wave of attacks and of the growing aggressiveness and offensiveness against Jews in Europe, to which the events in Toulouse bear witness , Brussels, Paris, Copenhagen, resulting in death in a good number of cases and, above all, the spectacular increase reported by the Agency for Fundamental Rights of the European Union in its annual reports - 40% and 48% in the last years in France, Belgium, Hungary, United Kingdom, Austria—. This deserves a message of solidarity, and it is the one carried out by this Resolution, betting on a working definition, for a definition of work, which is not legally binding, but which is endorsed by the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance - the Holocaust Memory Alliance , which is an intergovernmental organization that has diplomatic representatives from the vast majority of the member states of the European Union - about what anti-Semitism is as an instigation of hatred of Jews for being Jews and of violence, and therefore to attack Jews for being Jews in Europe. It is also committed to strengthening the security of the Jewish communities in Europe and the establishment of mechanisms for parliamentary action, special envoys and specific commitments of parliamentary groups against anti-Semitism. This working definition does not come from any Jewish lobby: it comes from cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and has been endorsed by the Commission, by the Commissioner for Fundamental Rights and Justice, Commissioner Jourová; for the action of the coordinator against anti-Semitic actions in Europe, Mrs Schnurbein, from the Commission. And my last message is that this has nothing to do, logically, with the sensitivity that legitimate criticism and the right to criticize the settlements and the violations of the fundamental rights of the Palestinian population arouse. Because it is not fair to link the resolution of the conflict in the Middle East, which lasts seventy years, and the occupation of the occupied territories, which lasts fifty years, with the condemnation that each attack against the Jews in Europe deserves and the message of solidarity and commitment to your fundamental rights that you deserve from this Parliament. That is why I am running a favorable vote for this Resolution.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, as we speak today, we are facing an unprecedented increase in anti-Semitism in Europe. For years, hate speech and hate crimes against Jews were the domain of marginal groups and political movements. Unfortunately, anti-Semitism is becoming a strong political stream in Europe. It is accepted and followed by many, often in ignorance of its real impact on people in our communities. Populist, anti-establishment movements use any kind of motivation to gain attention. This includes so-called ‘discussion’ of the Holocaust, and verbal and physical violence against Jews in European cities and the presence of Jews in the Middle East. This dangerous political rhetoric, however, leads us back to dubious discussion and debate about the legitimacy of the State of Israel. Democracy cannot be an excuse for allowing undemocratic forces to act. Jews in Europe have the right to live freely without fear. The State of Israel has the right to exist and protect itself. Any kind of questioning of this legitimacy cannot be part of a debate in this House or anywhere else. I call on my colleagues, in the first place, to unite and give a strong political message to the world: any kind of anti-Semitism, subtle or explicit, has to be rejected. I also call on Member States clearly to target grey areas in their educational systems. New generations of European citizens must be raised with awareness of this issue and be able to refuse from the very beginning the malign seed of anti-Semitism.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I will start with a quote by Simone Veil: ‘Human beings are so made that the ones who do the crushing feel nothing; it is the person crushed who feels what is happening. Unless one has placed oneself on the side of the oppressed, to feel with them, one cannot understand.’ I just need to say ‘Paris 2015’: four persons dead in a terrorist attack against a Jewish kosher grocery store. In this city, Brussels, four people were killed in a terrorist attack against Belgium’s Jewish Museum. This resolution we are discussing today shows that we, the elected Members of European countries and citizens in this institution, do not tolerate anti-Semitism in our continent. The memories of the Holocaust should never be forgotten. We should do anything we can to combat anti-Semitism in all its ugly forms. To do this is to accept the resolution. I am proud of it and I would like to reach out to my colleagues Mr Becker and Mr López Aguilar for having done such a great job on this. It is very important that we use the new tool, that we spread it, and that we encourage governments to use the tool and the new definition, because I am convinced that this resolution can actually send a very clear message to governments to do everything they can to prevent and combat anti—Semitic actions and to bring to court anybody, any perpetrator, performing them. I encourage you to take this resolution to your hearts, digest it and vote in favour tomorrow.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the majority resolution points the finger at an undeniable fact: the increase in anti-Semitic acts in Europe. My group is aware of this, but it is deeply against the definition of anti-Semitism borrowed from the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance, because it tends to include what is not included: criticism of Israel. This inclusion is a trap because it cuts off freedom of expression and the opposition of a large part of the diaspora to Israeli conduct. Insidiously it is suggested that the source of anti-Semitism may not be in the gaze of the anti-Semite, but in the person being viewed, including the Jew, if in disagreement with Israel or Zionism. To define anti-Semitism it is enough to say that it is hostility towards the Jew as a Jew, period. It is a hostility that precedes the birth of Israel. All Europeans who have memory of themselves know this, in Germany, France, Italy, Austria, Poland. Please look at the amendments we have tabled with the Greens. Our intention is to give voice to the many critical Jewish associations of Israel, it is also the attempt to fight all xenophobias, Islamophobia, anti-Gypsyism because anti-Semitism is always a precursor of other phobias and stigmatizations.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! Today, the theme of our debate is anti-Semitism. I therefore keep talking about the hate crimes and harassment against the Jewish population in Europe that have never stopped completely but rather been constant, flared up from time to time or lain dormant, but which have increased in recent years. In particular, the situation has worsened during the various Gaza wars, as many in our countries do not differentiate between the state of Israel and the Jewish population. As a result, it is no longer just those with Nazi sympathies who are harassing, but the group of perpetrators has become so many more. It also makes the problem so much harder to deal with. It is also very important that we make a clear distinction between justified criticism of what the state of Israel does - just as we criticize other countries and even our own when necessary - and hatred and harassment of Jews. It must be allowed to criticize the actions of the Israeli state, the settlement policy, etc., without being considered anti-Semitic for that reason. Today we take a stand on a definition of anti-Semitism that several have already addressed here. There is no consensus among Jewish organizations on the definition. The Jewish peace organizations, for example, are clearly opposed, as they believe that it risks restricting the free debate on Israeli politics. On the day that the various Jewish organizations can agree on a common definition of anti-Semitism, I will be happy to support it. On the other hand, I will not support the definition referred to in today's resolution. This does not mean that I am not behind the necessary work against anti-Semitism and most of the rest of the resolution. There must be zero tolerance for all forms of racism, against other ethnic groups, religious expressions, ethnic groups. This must be and is the goal for all of us.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, anti-Semitism is on the rise in Europe and this resolution does not attempt to understand the reasons behind it. Studies show that European Muslims are 10 times more likely to hold very unfavourable views about Jews than non-Muslims. There are two main reasons for the growth of the current strains of European anti-Semitism. The first is the anti-Semitic content of the Islamic tracts, the Qur’an, the Hadith and the Sunnah. The second is the dramatic growth in the number of Muslims in Europe over the last 50 years, a growth that is now spiralling upward. The problem is that many Muslims take literally what is written in their works of fiction. These works are full of exhortations for discrimination, hatred and violence, and not just against Jews, but Christians too. These hateful passages are being propagated by imams in mosques paid for by Saudi Arabia and other Islamic countries. These are not extremist forms of Islam: these are literalist forms of Islam. The passage that always sticks in my mind is the one from the Hadith which says: ‘Judgement day will not come until the Muslims fight the Jews. The Muslims will kill the Jews and the Jews will hide behind rocks and trees. The rocks and trees will cry out Oh Muslim, oh faithful servant of Allah, there is a Jew behind me. Come and kill him.’  If European governments were serious about combating this problem, they would do two things immediately. First, stop all overseas funding of mosques and imams. Second, end the mass immigration of Muslims into European countries. Any future migration from Islamic countries should be on a highly selective basis only, and only those migrants prepared to make a solemn and binding pledge that they reject the passages of hatred and violence should be admitted.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: There are people who only speak for themselves and not for a parliament, I would say.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it was necessary to wait for Mr Batten's intervention to hear about Islam. These documents and all this discussion are deeply affected and are a serious example of "Islamic" correct language. There is an inadmissible self-censorship on the part of the Council, the Commission and even this Parliament. I must acknowledge the President's initiative which is very timely, the talks and reflections that have been made in which some of us participated with keen interest. But beyond this it seems to me that we are trying to escape the heart of the problem. Perhaps not all mosques preach anti-Semitism, perhaps not all Islamic and Islamist sites preach anti-Semitism, perhaps not all acts of violence that are carried out are of Islamic origin, but many of them are. It is absolutely absurd and even insane to hide behind the finger of a reality that is under our eyes. It is enough to leave this Parliament and take, for example, the direction of the rue de la Paix and see that no rabbi, no religious person, professing the Jewish religion would show the signs of their religion. I believe it is necessary to defend the law in a much more serious way than these extremely superficial and generic documents, because it is part of our cultural identity.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, as someone who has Jewish heritage in my family I am fully aware of the detrimental effect that racism can have on people. As someone of black heritage, too, I have felt that in the past. I have spoken many times, in this Chamber and beyond, about the ways that Israel, a beacon of freedom across the globe, has been attacked from all quarters. But I am afraid that the definitions in this motion have caused me grave concern: my concern is that they will enhance those who wish to do the Jews and Israel harm. In particular, I am concerned about the adoption of the definition from the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance. The definition is extremely broad and wide. Let me, for example, cite this quote to you: ‘Palestine belongs to the Arabs. It is wrong and inhuman to impose the Jews on the Arabs.’ The author of this quote would have to be imprisoned if we adopt this definition. The author of the quote was Mahatma Gandhi. There have been hundreds of politicians, writers and philosophers who have opposed violence but who would be caught by this definition. So I would say to those behind this motion: your definition may be well-meaning, but what you will be doing is preventing freedom of speech and creating a fear of speaking. That is why I would ask you to reflect. Go back to the drawing board, please.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you have spoken of incidents involving Jews. Looking at the definition of an accident we see that this is defined as an unexpected occurrence. There is nothing unexpected, there is nothing unexpected every time a Jew is attacked, every time an act of anti-Semitism is carried out, because if we take a map and mark with a pencil where the episodes of anti-Semitism and then we take another map and draw with the same pencil where there are the episodes of terrorism and then we take the two maps and we overlap them with each other, we will see that these points coincide. Dear Commissioner, dear colleagues, we must understand that where there is anti-Semitism there is terrorism. And then we cannot be lukewarm, we cannot be too weak in condemning acts of anti-Semitism. The violence against Jews that is carried out every day in all parts of Europe cannot be defined as accidents, they are not unexpected events. Episodes of anti-Semitism develop due to the weakness of governments that are unable to protect Jews and therefore freedom of expression. Today it happens to Jews, elsewhere it happens to Christians.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Madam President, it is a shame for Europe that, more than 70 years after the incomprehensible tragedy of the Holocaust, anti-Semitism is still alive - it is not only alive but growing in several Member States. That is why we have a duty not only politically but also morally to do everything against anti-Semitism and for the safety of our fellow Jewish citizens. It is completely unacceptable for anyone in Europe today to face any kind of threat because of their Jewish identity or religion. It is heartbreaking that politicians who declare themselves moderate also use covert or sometimes not so covert anti-Semitic clichés, sometimes even here in the European Parliament. I support proposing the widespread use of the IHRA definition of anti-Semitism. After all, it is hardly possible to monitor, follow and document the spread and manifestations of anti-Semitism in Europe. This definition does not restrict freedom of expression in any way. And perhaps most importantly, it makes it clear that blasphemy against the state of Israel is also a form of anti-Semitism, as it attacks Israel for being a Jewish state. However, any criticism of the policies of the Israeli government in power is not anti-Semitism. We do not have to stand up for an Israeli government, but for the state of Israel and Judaism. This is what the European tradition commits us to, and it commits us to the memory of the millions of Holocaust victims.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Madam President, historically anti-Semitism in Europe has been connected to extreme nationalism. However, this historical background should not make us blind to what is going on today. The new rise in anti-Jewish hatred and violence is linked to immigration from Muslim countries. Research shows that anti-Jewish attitudes are mainstream in Muslim communities. Unfortunately these communities, together with the so-called liberals, have been very successful in portraying Muslims as victims and victims only, thereby placing them beyond justified criticism. The Left, with their pathological anti-Israel agenda, is not very helpful. It is not enough to condemn anti—Semitism in general terms. The problem must be properly identified and recognised if we want to do something about it.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: - Madam President!I thank the initiators of the resolution.I would like to speak out in favor of the proposed definition of anti-Semitism.I distanced myself from claiming that this definition would make it impossible to criticize the policies of the State of Israel - that is not the case.I say this as someone who grew up in a city where the first synagogue was built in 1104.For several hundred years, my hometown Speyer, as a member of the ShUM Federation, was a stronghold of Jewish learning.In 1349 the community was wiped out.In 1435 banished from the city again for ever.Only after the French Revolution did a Jewish community emerge again in my homeland.In 1933 it still had 269 members, of whom exactly one Jew survived the Nazi era.Today we have the fourth synagogue in town.Anti-Semitism has a long historical history and deep roots.We have to keep fighting him.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! It's about anti-Semitism and we have two types that we need to fight. We find the first among many Muslim migrants and also among the Muslim minorities - among us, in our countries. Last week I was in Hungary. I could visit a synagogue and a Jewish house - no police anywhere. That is completely unthinkable in Berlin, where there is protection in front of every synagogue by the police, seven days a week, twenty-four hours a day. Roads are closed for Jewish services. I would like Hungarian conditions for Germany and Europe. And it has to do with Islam. The second type of anti-Semitism we find here in this Parliament. You have decided that products from Israeli settlers should be labeled. This branding contradicts the free trade idea and is also forgotten about history. Let’s fight anti-Semitism and it’s best to start right here in the house - not through empty speeches, but through deeds. Jewish life is part of Europe and it is our job to protect it.

name: Georg MAYER
text: - Madam President! Anti-Semitism must have no place in Europe. I think we can all put that out of the way. And unfortunately we have to find more and more often that Jewish institutions and Jewish people are exposed to attacks and the drama gets out of hand with the fact that synagogues in Europe today have to be guarded. This also has - and I know that many of you do not want to hear that - to do with the migration crisis of last year. As a result of uncontrolled and completely undifferentiated influx from Islamic countries, radical Islam naturally also immigrated to Europe, and of course they live out their ideology here too. Turkey must also find a further consideration. AKP MPs who openly make anti-Jewish statements - that cannot exist. And our colleague Storch said: There is also something on the part of the European Union that does not exactly help to improve the climate, including in Europe, namely the labeling of Jewish products. Here, too, we should think very hard about whether that still makes sense today. Thank-you.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Madam President, violence with anti-Semitic motives is on the rise. Terrorist attacks like those in Toulouse, Brussels, Paris and Copenhagen are aimed at individuals only because they are Jewish. Threats and harassment are also increasing. The situation in my home country, Sweden, illustrates what we are talking about today. Earlier this spring, the synagogue in the city of Umeå closed down due to systematic threats. In the city of Malmö, Jewish individuals risk being attacked if they wear a necklace with the Star of David around their neck. In order to confront today’s anti-Semitism in Europe, we have to acknowledge the problem and its roots. Tomorrow this House will vote on a resolution on this matter. The aim is to find a common European definition of anti-Semitism and to use the EU institutions for exchange of information in the fight against this kind of racism. The issue of definition is important because the lack of agreement on how to define anti—Semitism makes it impossible to monitor and prevent anti-Semitic hate crime, which is a precondition for an effective fight against these evil acts. Finally, I would like to thank my colleague, Mr Becker, for drafting this very important resolution. Let us hope for a broad majority tomorrow and a vote across party lines.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, inciting hatred and violence in all its forms and manifestations is incompatible with the values ​​of the European Union and, therefore, sanctioned. We must avoid falling into the trap of the race to victimize the various forms of discrimination. There is not one that must be protected more than the other. Racism and hatred must be addressed with the same attention and energy. Today this Assembly strongly condemns all forms of hatred and violence against Jewish citizens who are victims of anti-Semitic attacks, which are on the rise throughout Europe. Even in light of the atrocious persecution of millions of Jewish European citizens, how is it possible that in some Member States the invocation of reasons based on race, national or ethnic origin, religion or belief is not yet an aggravating circumstance? of crime? The repressive tools against the perpetrators of hate crimes and the not only physical protection of the victims are certainly effective and, indeed, must be strengthened. However, if isolated they will not be able to restore the climate of legality by themselves. To prevent and combat anti-Semitism, as well as all forms of discrimination, it is also necessary to invest at an educational and cultural level in promoting tolerance and respect for human rights, as well as promoting dialogue and cooperation between the various components of society. at local and national level, including dialogue and cooperation between various cultural, ethnic and religious communities.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: -  Sir.Chairman!The rise in anti-Semitism beyond Europe, which we are experiencing in recent years, is a very serious matter that we should reflect on, also in my own country Denmark, where we have recently seen the terrorist attack, which affected both freedom of expression activists but also the Jewish synagogueand the bar mitzvah that took place there, which is a terrible example that anti-Semitism in Europe is not something that belongs only to the past.Contrary to the past, we see today that the majority of the increase in anti-Semitic assaults comes from minorities in some Muslim communities, where one clearly does not want to accept the Jewish presence, neither in the countries one comes from, the culture one brings, orin the countries to which one has fled or traveled to Europe.Therefore, we should also address the problems where they are most, and therefore we should take this confrontation with the cultures that do not recognize the place of the Jewish religion in Europe.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: –  Fru formand! Jeg vil ikke tale på egne vegne, men på vegne af elleve jødiske organisationer i Europa, der har skrevet til os i dag. I har alle sammen modtaget brevet fra dem, og jeg vil gerne citere. De kommer fra bredt over Europa, det er først og fremmest fra Jødisk Stemme for Fred fra de forskellige lande, og lad mig her citere:  As Jewish organisations, we strongly believe that a commitment to tackling anti-Semitism and all forms of racism is essential. Racism and anti-Semitism are generally covered by specific legislation in each European country and should be dealt with resolutely under these statutes. Endorsing the highly contentious and flawed IHRA document will not aid our collective endeavour to combat anti-Semitism. In our view, endorsement would significantly undermine defences against anti-Semitism by expanding the concept in a politically motivated way. You should think twice about how these organisations look into this. It is important that they address us like this.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - “Fight against anti-Semitism” is what this debate is called.This raises a personal question: what am I doing and what are you doing against the manifestations of the great evil of hatred for the Jews?This question is all the more urgent today because anti-Semitism is "normal" within the borders of the European Union and has been for years.How do I know?By standing with open eyes and ears in our society.Through the media, through studies, but above all through personal contacts with the victims of anti-Semitism.For years I have noticed the normality of anti-Semitism in Strasbourg and here in Brussels.The stories of everyday anti-Semitism against members of the Jewish community in our midst all ask for a clear answer.Do we form a living wall around them or do we accept the normality of Jew hatred, especially that common form of Jew hatred against the state of Israel, also here?Don't ever let this debate testify against us.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, Holocaust denial has been penalised by the majority of EU Member States, yet recently voices have been raised questioning this legislation. Moreover, thousands of Jews, families of Holocaust survivors, have recently decided to leave the EU and move to Israel. They see no future here. I think that early warning is needed about the awful rise of anti-Semitism in Europe.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: - Madam President! An anti-Semitism report published by an expert commission in April of this year shows that Jews in Germany see themselves increasingly threatened by Muslims. Social media are a central element of the spread of hatred and agitation against Jews. A study by the EU itself from 2013 shows that most anti-Semitic attacks are currently perpetrated by Muslims; followed first by left-wing extremists and second by right-wing perpetrators. In view of the proportionately still small Muslim population in Europe, this population group is far over-represented among the perpetrators. This resolution today does not specify that. Instead, it tries to propagate the multicultural society and offers diversity as a solution. That is well-intentioned, but naive. Even today, in my city of Hamburg, the stumbling blocks in the sidewalks - small brass plates that were installed there - remind me of Jewish families who lost their belongings and mostly their lives during the Second World War. Let us not be led, out of a misunderstood tolerance, to simply silently accept attacks on Jewish fellow citizens. Only a clear analysis allows us to defend our values. Otherwise the commitment to European values ​​degenerates into a mere speech bubble. In fine words, as is the case in this report, it is simply not done.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - Europe is based on Judeo-Christian roots and Jews have been and will be part of Europe. But at the same time, it is a sad truth that they have been and still are persecuted and exposed to inappropriate, unnecessary and unjustified violence, not only verbal but also physical. Not because they would personally do anything like that, but just because they are Jews. That is why it is extremely important to protect these people very concretely physically. That is why I support the resolution, especially in the part that calls for an operational definition of anti-Semitism. This is necessary in order to be able to recognize anti-Semitic acts and fight against them. Anti-Semitists often hide and say that they are not anti-Semites, but only criticize the actions and actions of the Israeli state or government, just as we are critical of governments and countries in other countries. But the line here is thin, and the operational definition of anti-Semitism allows us to face this challenge, to be able to better expose the people who are spreading anti-Semitism and to prevent it. Freedom of speech is a very valuable right that must not be abused to spread hatred.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately anti-Semitism is not a phenomenon to be entrusted to the memory of the past. It, as well as other phenomena of racial discrimination persist and are even increasing in some parts of the Union. The atmosphere on our continent has long since changed and an increasing number of European Jews are asking questions about their future. Hate speech has become one of the most widespread forms of human rights abuses, with serious negative consequences, both in the real and virtual world. Europe is perhaps underestimating the seriousness of the problem that has arisen in the eastern part of its borders, where the situation has long since crossed the threshold of tolerance. Nothing can justify the incitement to racial hatred, much less if anti-Semitic sentiments are fueled. These are phenomena that must be severely pursued and punished with harsh and effective measures because intolerance is a direct violation of the principles of freedom, democracy and respect for human rights, principles on which the European Union is founded and it is good that some leaders of the European Union if they come to terms with it.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: – Mr President, I am obliged to you for giving me the floor. It amazes me how we can be the best of parliaments and sometimes the worst of parliaments all in the same session. I have sat through this debate and listened to some of the most corrosive, divisive and cancerous language that I sometimes hear from time to time.  Equality is a cornerstone of the European Union. If we allow discrimination and its cancerous effects to take root, we are nothing. It particularly interests me that those colleagues here today who decided to speak about another one of our great religions in the way that they did actually share one thing in common, and that is a hatred for the European Union. They wish to cloak their arguments in Islamophobic rhetoric in order to attack Europe. That does not take us any further at all. As Europeans, we are equal. You attack one of us, on any basis whatsoever, and you attack as all.  (Applause)

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Mr President, anti-Semitism is no longer the heritage of the right.In Spain, seventy municipalities governed by the left have joined the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions operation, and some have declared themselves "Israeli apartheid-free zones."Apartheid in Israel?Israelis and Palestinians even live in the same neighborhoods.Hamas and the PNA, instead, proclaim their intention to expel all Israelis.Anti-Semitism is camouflaged today as a vindication of the rights of the Palestinians.I also want rights for the Palestinians, that's why I demand that Hamas and the Palestinian National Authority hold democratic elections and guarantee the rights of women and all minorities.I would like to tell my colleagues at Podemos, if they were here, to explain to me if it is okay to accept money from the Iranian and Venezuelan tyrannies, but not to trade with the only democracy in the Middle East.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, I strongly condemn all forms of violence and hate speech. Violence and hate speech are completely at odds with European values ​​and the European Union must do everything to eradicate them. This resolution is only one step on that path. It unites us and puts before us the fight against anti-Semitism in the European Union as one of our priorities. But we need to think about what lies at the roots of modern anti-Semitism. Many of our Jewish friends see the rise of anti-Semitism in Europe as a direct attack on the state of Israel itself. We also need to recognize this clearly and we must strongly support the achievement of peace in the Middle East. It is necessary to establish effective legal mechanisms to identify and prosecute perpetrators of hate crimes and to ensure the protection of Jews who are citizens of the European Union as well as the right to freedom of religion. Religious hate crimes are on the rise in Europe. Freedom of religion is one of the fundamental values ​​we have in Europe and which we must preserve.

name: Maria ARENA
text: - Mr President, this draft text is indeed important because it reminds us that anti-Semitism is a serious and intolerable form of racism, which we cannot under any circumstances trivialize or accept and against which we absolutely must fight.It does, however, contain a reference to a contested definition which, through the examples it cites, is particularly ambiguous about the amalgamation it makes between the obvious facts of condemnable anti-Semitism and the criticisms leveled against it.'a policy pursued by an Israeli government.It would have been better to limit ourselves to a redacted definition of these examples, which add nothing and, on the contrary, create ambiguity and weaken the excellent work that has been done by our colleagues in this text.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, we are clearly opposed to any action that reinforces or even promotes feelings of hatred, against any rhetoric that reinforces anti-Semitism, that intensifies tension and produces violence. Education, dear colleagues, and prosperity are the key tools that can support peaceful coexistence. Any action that supports anti-Semitism or anti-Muslimism is condemnable, but we must be clear: anti-Semitism does not mean anti-Israelism and the two should not be confused. And finally, any attempt to resolve the Palestinian issue reduces many of the problems we face in this area.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: - Mister President!I have to honestly say: I am very shocked and angry about some of what I have heard here in this Chamber.It is unheard of when I hear that anti-Semitism is combated with Semitism against other religions.Playing one religion off against the other is the worst thing you can do.That is the opposite of what our core values mean in the European Union, namely creating common ground, creating peace among people and ensuring that we can live well together.My grandmother always said to me: Never point a finger at someone, because at least three fingers will then also point at you.And these people should also look at those three fingers that are pointing at them.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, as I said at the beginning this is a very important debate on a very alarming topic. Some of you mentioned that it must be a matter of solidarity to help and to protect people who are affected by anti-Semitism, but I must say that solidarity is not enough. We need to ensure security for all people, and speaking about security, we are in the field of criminal justice.  Some of you mentioned that we need a legal framework. I can only inform you about something you know yourself, that the Member States are very well equipped with the necessary legislation because we have the framework decision on combating racism and xenophobia and the Member States are obliged to implement it in full – to to my regret, not all the Member States. In some Member States, the situation is not satisfactory because we still have some Member States where denial of the Holocaust, for instance, is not considered criminal wrongdoing under their criminal codes. We have many other problems with definitions and so on, but the Commission is pushing very hard on the Member States to have the legislation in place.  Speaking about criminal justice, I want to respond also to those who mentioned aggressive jihadism. This must be fought by means of criminal justice as well. We now have very strict legislation on combating radicalisation and terrorism. We have very strict rules and laws that enable our Member States to punish not only those who are the perpetrators of violent crime, but also those who are helping, who are supporting with finance, or who are supporting with information, shelter and so on. We are equipped and we have to act.  Speaking about criminal justice, however, I must say that for me, criminal justice is the last resort. We must do much more, because here in Europe we face the situation where we have a high number of people who are able to commit criminal offences against people of another race or another religion. Unfortunately, I have to say this is a happening in Europe due to the passivity of society and the silent acceptance by society. This is something we have already witnessed several times in our history and we need to do much more than prohibit criminal wrongdoing. We need to act against this passivity and help society to be much more vocal, to say this is not only prohibited – this is totally unacceptable. I am speaking about all sorts of violence against groups of people and minorities. I would warn very strongly against some attempts to impose collective guilt in Europe because we must never do that again. Today we had a very good debate with the IT providers, NGOs and the representatives of the Member States on combating hatred and hate speech online. You also mentioned it many times here and we agreed on the fact that we need to work together. We need to invest a lot and to use all our collective energy and determination against these phenomena, and we need to work in the direction of having a hate-free Europe. It is highly ambitious, but we have no other way. We have to do it and we have to try.  So thank you very much for all your comments. This debate has convinced me that we have to invest a lot of energy in combating not only anti-Semitism, but also all other kinds of hatred in Europe. It is something we have to do, and we have to do it together.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me once again assure you that the Council is determined to address anti—Semitism in all its forms – xenophobia, racism. Hate speech will be on next week’s agenda of the Ministers of Justice for discussion. Moreover, we need to ensure effective implementation of existing legislation and protect victims. Much is at stake here: responsibility for the history of our continent and the essential democratic rights that shape our societies today. Crimes motivated by racism and xenophobia affect not only the victim, but also society as a whole.  In the name of the Council, I have followed this debate very closely and paid particular attention to the views expressed. I wish this House all strength and wisdom for tomorrow’s votes.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I have received two motions for resolutions submitted pursuant to Art.123 sec.2 of the Regulations.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 1 June 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The problem of anti-Semitism has intensified in recent years, as is also reported by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OECD) and the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA).The fight against anti-Semitism must involve the whole of society, especially we politicians, and we must commit ourselves to publicly and severely condemn any kind of anti-Semitic gesture, affirmation and externalization and to promote tolerance in the conscience of civil society.In this regard, the Member States must absolutely facilitate the adoption of a clear and common definition of anti-Semitism, in order to create a precise framework.The 5 Star Movement has always been committed to the fight against anti-Semitism and will continue to do so, encouraging and promoting respect and tolerance to counter hate speech.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: written. - The initiative to combat anti-Semitism is a good and necessary one. However, there is one big problem with that. The resolution calls for tougher measures against anti-Semitism and calls on member states to start condemning people in court for anti-Semitism more vigorously than before. This is a good thing. The problem is point 2, where anti-Semitism is defined. The definition is copied from an association called the IHRA, or International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance. The definition of IHRA is twofold. First comes a brief, more general description of what anti-Semitism is. It's good. The following is a list of examples of what anti-Semitism can be, for example. They have problems. According to them, Israel’s normal criticism of, for example, the country’s racist practices and many other issues related to fundamental freedom of speech and normal criticism would be anti-Semitism. For this reason, for example, the European Fundamental Rights Agency stopped using the IHRA definition of anti-Semitism. I hope that the definition of IHRA will be deleted. After that, the initiative is great.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: signed up. - Lately, anti-Semitic behavior has begun to become a kind of new normal in Europe. The terrorist attacks in Toulouse, Paris and Copenhagen targeted Jewish community institutions and are clear evidence of the recent proliferation of anti-Semitism. Anti-Semitism involves prejudices and attitudes that legitimize discrimination, violence and hatred. Today, more than ever, the European Union must make the fight against anti-Semitism and discrimination based on ethnicity, religion or nationality a priority. Unfortunately, the online environment facilitates communication and adherence to extremist and anti-Semitic groups and leads to the trivialization of deviant behaviors. The Jewish community has made an important contribution to the cultural, economic and social development of Europe, and we must ensure that their rights are respected and that their security is ensured. There is also a need for a universally accepted definition of anti-Semitism at Member State level, and the next EU Presidencies should take this into account.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - Data from the OSCE and the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, as well as others, are worrying that the number of anti-Jewish incidents has risen sharply in recent years. Hate speech and all forms of violence against European Jewish citizens run counter to the values ​​of the European Union, which is why society as a whole must be responsible for combating anti-Semitism. Civil societies, educational institutions, journalists, religious and religious organizations, as well as state authorities, have a very important role to play in the fight against anti-Semitism to record and address any manifestations of extremism, anti-Semitism and intolerance in accordance with applicable laws. With more than 70 years since the end of World War II, generations without knowledge of the atrocities committed during the war have grown, Member States need to promote Holocaust education in schools and ensure that teachers are adequately trained to do so, and able to respond adequately to the diversity of students in the classroom. The Commission must also work closely at international level with international actors such as ENESCO, the OSCE and the Council of Europe, as well as with other partners, to combat anti-Semitism.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - It sounds like a commonplace, but it is a very real, dramatic experience in Europe: mass violence and murder begins with words, and the promotion of hatred and discrimination that is toxic to social consciousness can lead to tragedies on a historical scale. The growing incidence of anti-Semitic, racist public discourse and atrocities in Europe calls for urgent action by the Union and all European democrats. This requires a clear definition of the concept of pure speech, anti-Semitism, interpreted in the same way in public discourse and uniformly applied in case law, so I am convinced that this decision will, over time, prove to be an important contribution to halting this dangerous process. The motion for a resolution points to the key responsibility of political leaders and governments in curbing anti-Semitism. If only because there are still European politicians today who do not use their open or coded anti-Semitic manifestations to address extremist, racist-minded voters. A month ago, in this very room, at our previous plenary session in Brussels, Viktor Orbán did the same when he condemned the American “billionaire speculator” György Soros for all the troubles of his government. In Central and Eastern Europe, this awakens severe reminiscences, we are well aware of the anti-Semitism hidden in such allusions. According to one of his interviews, this is exactly what Vice President Timmermans understood, only his situation at the time did not allow him to react to Orbán's disgraceful remark. However, as MEPs, we must not tolerate anti-Semitic speech here or anywhere in Europe from politicians in charge.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the report by Jarosław Wałęsa, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the introduction of temporary autonomous trade measures for Ukraine supplementing the trade concessions available under the Association Agreement (COM (2016) 0631- C8-0392 / 2016 - 2016/0308 (COD)).

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, in recent years Ukraine has faced unprecedented challenges, both political and economic. Despite the toll taken by the illegal annexation of Crimea and the Russian aggression in Donetsk and Lugansk, the Government has been conducting reforms on a scale that the country has never experienced before. The scope of the reforms is so ambitious that it is fair to say more has been done during the last two years than over previous decades. These processes happened while enormous economic strain existed due to the Russian embargo and transit ban.  The European institutions have always been supportive of the process of stabilisation and peace in the Ukraine. This has included not only support for the reforms but also micro—financial support, trade measures and, finally, the visa—free regime for Ukrainian citizens. Only yesterday, we heard that the Dutch Senate had voted on the ratification of the EU—Ukraine Association Agreement. These are all signs that our partnership is going strong.  In September last year, the Commission issued a proposal for granting temporary additional trade measures to Ukraine in order to increase its trade flows and support the country economically. These asymmetrical preferences in the Commission’s proposal include additional tariff rate quotas for agricultural goods and a reduction in duties for industrial goods. As the Commission did not provide for an impact assessment, due to the time constraints, this proved problematic for Members of the European Parliament. At this point it should be remembered that those preferences are on top of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement that entered into force at the beginning of 2016. As the first report on implementation is underway, we are not yet able to assess whether the preferences already granted are sufficient. In the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, concern was expressed about the timing and the choice of products. According to the opinion, the preferences target highly sensitive agricultural products that were hit by the series of crises and the Russian embargo. Furthermore, last year EU farmers experienced a record low harvest, while the opposite was true for the world’s other main exporters. I also received feedback from stakeholders regarding potentially sensitive products among industrial goods, which was reflected in their report. Taking all this into consideration, I think we have managed to achieve a balanced outcome in the Committee on International Trade. My report proposes the deletion of two agricultural tariffs, wheat and processed tomatoes, and one industrial tariff, urea, from the annexes. The report also tackles a number of challenges to Commission proposals, such as the need for checks and inspections in order to issue a movement certificate, especially when products stem from territory not under the control of the Government, and also Ukraine’s abstention from introducing discriminatory internal administrative measures, as well as the implementation of continued and sustained efforts with regard to the fight against corruption and illegal activities. I also emphasised the right for European industry to initiate a safeguard procedure. In the end, I believe that a detailed assessment of the implementation of these temporary alternative measures is needed. I am hoping for a strong majority tomorrow and a strong plenary mandate. Once this is obtained, my goal is to start the interinstitutional negotiations as soon as possible.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, these autonomous trade measures that the Commission has proposed aim to express economic and political support for Ukraine, an associated partner and our neighbour, which is at a very difficult juncture. The Commission made the proposal in September and it is a reasonable and balanced proposal, granting better access to the EU market for certain agricultural products and certain industrial goods from Ukraine. The Commission has considered some sensitivities related to agricultural markets, for instance, and we have not included the most sensitive products such as poultry, sugar or fruits.  We propose to increase annual duty-free tariff rate quotas for eight agricultural products on top of what is already provided for in the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA). In some cases these additional amounts are small and will have no impact whatsoever on the EU market. In the case of other products, for example honey, the additional preference to Ukrainian exports will most likely simply displace imports from other countries, such as China, without affecting prices or import flows to the EU. Moreover, honey and processed tomatoes are examples of export products that will benefit small and medium-sized Ukrainian companies immediately. And in this context Ukraine is a net importer of EU agricultural products. By the way, neither wheat nor processed tomatoes are subject to the Russian food ban, and when it comes to urea, that will actually benefit European farmers because it will replace imports of fertilisers from Russia and give us a cheaper alternative.  Furthermore, we have recent free trade agreements negotiated by the European Union with Peru, Colombia, Central America, Vietnam and Canada. Here we already provide unlimited duty-free access for some of the agricultural products covered by the proposal, so why should we not do that for Ukraine, our friend and economically integrated neighbour? We also have in the proposal a specific safeguard that would suspend preferences to any of the products in the event of market distortion, and we are ready to consider reinforcing that clause, should you so wish, when we go into trilogue. So in sum, this is very much a political gesture. It is about sending a positive signal of EU support to Ukraine, helping the economy of a country which is suffering from the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol and military conflict provoked by Russia in the eastern part of the country. That is why I am very concerned about the report that the committee has adopted because it significantly reduces the scope of our proposal.  On the impact assessment that you have requested, let me just recall that the trade preferences cover a very small fraction of the preferences already in force in the DCFTA, so it is impossible to separate the two impacts. Moreover, the last sustainable impact assessment that we did for the DCFTA in 2007 forecast a deep market opening by the EU, and that is still valid. The economic parameters have not changed much, especially not on the Ukrainian side, and the impact assessed at that time was negligible for the EU market. You suggest applying stricter rules of origin to the products from the territories which are not under effective control of the Government of Ukraine. That would unfortunately lead to two different types of rules of origin applying to exports of the same product. It would be cumbersome, it would create legal chaos both for exporters and for the customs authority, so we oppose these amendments. This proposal, as I said, is a political gesture. I hope that we can work together, Parliament and the Council, in the trilogue so as to send a more constructive proposal to Ukraine and help its people and its economy in these challenging times.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. -  Ladies and gentlemen! Trade preferences for Ukraine proposed by the European Commission are unfavorable for some of the very sensitive agricultural sectors of the EU. These are mainly cereals, but also some fruits and vegetables. The markets for these products have recently experienced severe crises and the negative impact of the Russian embargo. This applies in particular to the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, which are the gateway to the EU for products from the East. To avoid compounding the difficulties already faced by EU producers in the sectors most affected by current preferential imports from Ukraine, in its position on additional preferences, the Committee on Agriculture recommended the removal of the proposed tariff quotas for wheat (100,000 tonnes), maize (650,000 tonnes) and ) and processed tomatoes (5 thousand tons) and the reduction of the barley quota from 350 thousand to 50 thousand. tone. Despite the political and economic problems Ukraine is experiencing, in the face of the current difficult situation in European agriculture, in the committee we were unable to support such a significant increase in trade preferences for Ukraine in the agricultural area. The Union supports and should continue to support the reconstruction of the Ukrainian economy, including agriculture, but the proposed additional quotas are used very quickly and by few market participants. This aid does not go to a larger group of producers and traders, but only to a small group of oligarchs. Other forms of aid should be introduced, for example in the form of transfer of know-how or various pilot projects, which would implement modern technologies on the agricultural market and strengthen normal farmers.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: for the PPE Group.- Mr President, Ukraine has chosen the path of self-determination.She knew it would be a politically and economically dangerous path for her.She preferred freedom to the certainty of vassal times.Ukraine paid for its right to self-determination through the annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation and the fierce fighting in eastern Ukraine.She paid extra economically as well.In 2015, the share of trade with Russia fell to 16% compared to 27% in 2013. The aim of this proposal is to increase existing trade flows between the EU and Ukraine.However, I am afraid that our Parliament's proposal is curtailing the more favorable proposal of the European Commission.Ukraine is fragile, undergoing transformation and at war.We must do our best to help her economically.However, I would like Ukraine to have a real equivalent of the Marshall Plan.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: for the S&D group. - Mr President! Ukraine is still characterized by difficulties and a weak economy. Corruption is still widespread and reform work is ongoing but definitely needs to be intensified. The current trade benefits were negotiated in completely different circumstances. That was before Crimea, before Donbass. The new proposal for additional trade benefits may, even if it is a cautious proposal, be a signal that still indicates a future. At the same time, I and my political group have been clear that the additional trade benefits must be accompanied by continued efforts and reforms in the fight against corruption. This requires clear efforts from the EU, especially from the Commission - a follow-up that can also show that the efforts make a difference, a positive difference. I am pleased that we have included a stronger language in Parliament's text on the work against corruption in particular, and that we have received references to the need to pay attention to economic and social effects, as well as the clear requirement for follow-up. My hope is that these extra trade measures will accelerate the country's reform efforts and, in addition, send a message to Ukraine that we are here as friendly neighbors.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Speaking out in this debate, I would like to emphasize that Ukraine deserves support because, on the one hand, the war waged on its territory, supported by Russia and the occupation of Crimea, and, on the other hand, the deep economic and social reforms were carried out. Ukraine has already received such strong support as part of the association agreement it signed with the Union, as its commercial part includes generous preferential quotas, including for wheat, maize and barley. In this situation, the Commission's proposal to grant Ukraine additional duty-free quotas for as many as eight agricultural products is, according to the Polish delegation in the ECR, a proposal that goes too far. Therefore, we strongly support the decision of the European Parliament's Committee on Agriculture and International Trade to exclude wheat, processed tomatoes and artificial urea from duty-free quotas, and we hope that the Commission and the Council will respect this Parliament's decision.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the Association Agreement between the EU and Ukraine was signed in order to support the European aspirations of the people of Ukraine. In recent years, in the most difficult conditions of war, occupation and prolonged conflict, Ukrainians have succeeded in delivering the unprecedented reforms we demanded of them. Now it is time for the European Union to show its support.  Due to the war, occupation and trade sanctions imposed by Russia, Ukraine has been losing markets in the East and faces economic hardship. In 2014 and 2015, GDP fell by almost ten percent and the reorientation of the Ukrainian markets towards the EU has been difficult. But now the economy is growing again – by 2.3% in 2016 – and it is a crucial moment to support Ukraine’s economy and development. These additional preferences to Ukraine will support recovery and help combat the economic consequences of a war that is still going on in the eastern part of the country. Some measures are asymmetrical but my conviction is that it should be that way. The war and occupation is actually raging in Ukraine and not here. In this respect, I welcome the prolongation of restrictive measures against the Russian Federation as long as the terms of the Minsk Agreement are not fulfilled. I believe that the autonomous trade measures that the Commission has proposed are what we owe to the people of Ukraine and I sincerely hope that my colleagues are of the same opinion.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I find it hard to believe that such words have been spoken in this House towards the Ukrainian Government.The Commission, the European Commissioner, who also say they pay close attention to the relationship between human rights and trade agreements, perhaps they are forgetting to say who the Poroshenko government is composed of, by flag bearers who explicitly, for example, refer to the thirdReich.The Commission has not presented any impact assessments on the possible effects of these measures on Ukraine and has not presented a report on the use of the huge loans granted to Ukraine, perhaps aimed more than to finance the economy, to finance thewar.Now Parliament's proposal limits that of the Commission, but our group is firmly opposed to any form of financing for Poroshenko's parafascist regime.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the changes introduced by the committees of the European Parliament have turned this attempt to support Ukraine into a missed opportunity. This will be a great mistake. It is very hypocritical to see what Parliament is doing to the Commission’s proposal. We should not forget that trade policy is a powerful instrument and should be used to strongly support the EU’s foreign policy objectives, especially in the neighbourhood. In this neighbourhood, relations with our partners are unavoidably closer, and the values enshrined in our Treaties also play a significant role. The importance of our values is shown by the special emphasis that we have put on the fight against corruption in Ukraine. Progress has been made on this topic, but more needs to be made. In decisions concerning our closest partners, we should not let tariffs or quotas obscure our vision, which is to help Ukraine, a country whose sovereignty has been blatantly violated by Russia, and which now sees how Parliament turning its back on the further development of its economic and social situation.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, after Tunisia, now Ukraine. Europe continues to play the Good Samaritan and grant trade preferences like giving out points at school. This reduction in customs duties on agrifood products is conditional on Ukraine's respect for human rights, its fight against corruption and other major principles. However, the level of corruption has reached new heights in Ukraine. In reality, Ukraine is a threat to Europe. Moreover, who will pay the price for these ideological, false and unjust decisions? I think the farmers will be the stuffing turkeys and the market gardeners will once again be taken for apples. As for this European Parliament, which authorized Tunisia to export its olive oil to the European Union without customs duties, an impact study was due out in the year. A year later, no trace of this study. Perhaps the impact for Italian and French producers is too disastrous to be acknowledged ... I look forward to seeing you next year to make the same observation with regard to Ukrainian cereals.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I see autonomous additional measures as a useful tool that can support Ukraine in a difficult economic situation and, following the Association Agreement, support its gradual integration with the European Union's internal market.The measures discussed today send a strong signal that the European Union is ready to help Ukraine.However, the report is less favorable than the European Commission's proposal.From a foreign policy point of view, it is not possible for the European Parliament, on the one hand, to declare its support for Ukraine, but then to practically empty the report of its content, thus reducing the credibility of the European Union as a partner.It is also important for us to take action with the original wording from the Commission as soon as possible, in order to support Ukraine and the development of its economy as much as possible, notwithstanding the voices of the Kremlin, which are heard in this House from the far right and left.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! I appreciate the fact that the idea of ​​unilateral concessions is being treated with reservations by some of my colleagues who are afraid of the position of European farmers. At the same time, I would like to remind you that this measure has both theoretical, political and practical implications, and it is worth considering these in their interaction. As a Member, I myself am particularly sensitive to protecting the interests of European agriculture, but in this case, the list of Ukrainian exports covered by the facilitation has been preceded by a real impact analysis, and this can be further strengthened. The draft legislation already provides adequate guarantees to prevent possible market disruption, as the Commission can intervene at any time on its own initiative or on the initiative of a Member State. In this situation, the European Union must be ready and able to express our free solidarity with Europe in Ukraine in a tangible form, in this case with trade preferences.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, do not go too fast. A judgment of the European Court of Justice of May 16 has already informed you, in a very serious warning, that the European Union does not have exclusive competence in matters of trade. We must learn to share, and the Union here has a role shared with the States. On an issue as serious as Ukraine, I would like to tell you one thing, Madam: it is France that speaks to you, rural France, the France of farmers. We had a very difficult year 2016 in France, where most farms lost more than 30% of their turnover. The year 2017, Commissioner, will be just as difficult, because climate problems persist and prices continue to fall. However, while the French and European farmers suffer, you make your treaties, you continue your free trade agreements. After Canada, meat and grains, after Mexico, Mercosur, you have also started a dialogue with Australia. Today it is Ukraine, which is a real competitor to European agriculture. It is very bad news to see this treaty come at a time when European agriculture is in crisis and at a time when, on the contrary, we should help our own before helping others.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to emphasize that I expressly support additional trade concessions to Ukraine. However, I do not want to hide the fact that, in my opinion, it is urgently necessary for the Commission to present an interim report on European support. Because, and that is the important reason, the data on economic development and the social situation in Ukraine are by no means satisfactory. This is certainly partly due to the military conflict in eastern Ukraine. That is why it is politically very important that we continue to do everything we can to ensure that the Minsk Agreement is implemented. But I believe we must also examine what economic and social effects the implementation of the Association Agreement had and is having, namely under the question of whether the previous measures have been successful, and specifically successful, in terms of promoting development in Ukraine, or are they there there are other or other measures that should sensibly be taken? From my point of view, it is important that the support should not reach the oligarchs alone, but that it should improve the living conditions of broad sections of the population. That is why I believe we need an updated basis for answering the question of what further support is needed for Ukraine.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - I think we will all agree that Ukraine is an important partner of the European Union.We will not find much contradiction in the statement that Ukraine needs help.We will also find it easy to reach a consensus, also because the European Union's capacity to provide financial assistance is limited.As for how Europe can help its partners, I would like to remind you that even the Cohesion countries benefit most from the single market effect, not from European Union support.It is the possibility of free trade in the world's largest single market that encourages its participants to modernize and increase their competitiveness.By bringing more Ukraine into the European Union, we will work together to ensure that a larger part of the European economy and Ukrainian society becomes even more interested in adapting to Europe, but also in ensuring that the country's government does not deviate from European integration.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members, the rapporteurs and everybody who has been working on this very important issue. We are aware in the Commission that some products in European agriculture are sensitive and that this has been difficult for many European farmers. That is why we are working, together with my colleague Commissioner Hogan, to support those farmers, and we are also trying to open new markets for farmers. That is one reason why we have such an ambitious trade agenda, in order create such possibilities. European agriculture is of a very high quality, it is in demand and there are a lot of offensive interests, as well, for European agriculture in trade. When it comes to this specific proposal, it is – and I beg you really to read it – very modest. Fruit is not even in there and, when it comes to processed tomatoes and wheat, they are not subject to the Russian embargo. Please check your figures. I would also like to say that the urea will actually make it cheaper for European farmers to get access to fertilisers because we are lowering the tariffs there. So this is a limited, but for Ukraine a very important, proposal. We have looked very carefully into what we think is possible. We have specific safeguards that would suspend the preferences if there were any disruption in the market and we will supervise and monitor this very closely. We can reinforce that clause when we discuss it in the trilogue that I hope will start very soon. It is true that Ukraine has a lot of problems. Many of them are, of course, due to the conflict, but the country is also in the process of making painful reforms. They are working really hard to do that and a lot has been done in recent years. Yes, corruption is still high and, yes, there still a need to continue the reforms, but work is ongoing and we are supporting them and working with them.  Most of you say that we should support Ukraine. It is a neighbour, a friend and an ally, which has had a very difficult situation. One way of doing that would be to agree to this proposal. In July we will have an EU—Ukraine summit in Kiev, and having a political agreement on this proposal would be a great deliverable to bring with us to Kiev. It would show that we are on their side, that we do care and that we are here to support them. I believe that this proposal strikes the right balance between protecting sensitive agricultural areas and sectors here in the EU and providing some extra market opportunities to Ukraine. So I hope that when you vote, you can take the broader picture into account – the political and the economic one – and that we can soon enter into a trilogue in order to get a balanced proposal.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all, I say to the House: I would like to thank all of you for your valuable input in this debate. Your comments are very important to me, but I have to say that today’s debate illustrated exactly the conditions I was forced to work in while I was working on this report. As you could hear, we have very extreme views in this House, from left to right, from one extreme to the other, and my goal from the beginning was very simple. I always had in mind help for Ukraine, but also I always remembered that protecting the interests of European farmers and producers is also important. So finding the proper balance was not as easy as it seems.  Here in the European Parliament a majority of us strongly support the reforms in Ukraine, and I believe that by introducing these additional trade measures we are helping Ukraine to develop, not only in the economic sphere but also politically. Keeping that in mind, I understand that we are going to have a very difficult time in the Council. I understand that the Council will present additional deletions of additional tariff lines, so we may have a problem with that, Madam Commissioner, and I hope that we can find a middle ground.  Tomorrow I hope that I will receive a very strong mandate, because this is the proposal of this House, and this is the starting point of the debate. I hope that we will be able to start the trilogue negotiations very soon, and I hold that we can conclude them as soon as we can. I am going to strongly defend the position of the European Parliament and in the end I hope that the position of Parliament is going to prevail.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 1 June 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The Free Trade Association with the European Union has given Ukraine a new opportunity for development. Customs liberalization could expand the current trade relationship between the European Union and Ukraine. Thanks to this, new gates can be opened to attract capital to Ukraine and to foreign entrepreneurs, it is possible to cooperate with Ukraine with the European Union and its neighboring regions, and to implement joint cross-border projects. In this way, new jobs can be created, economic and infrastructural developments can begin, which would also improve the living standards of the population. The European example of revitalizing the economy should be taken, such as the Tisza EGTC, established in 2015, which was established between an EU county (Szabolcs – Szatmár – Bereg county) and a Ukrainian county (Transcarpathia) for regional development purposes. In order to start trade with the European Union, it is primarily necessary to improve border infrastructure and logistical and transport conditions. Unfortunately, the reforms implemented so far in the country are causing a number of social and economic tensions. Thus, it is extremely important that trade reforms and the country's economic development take place in parallel. Achieving the Ukrainian market economy and further integration into the EU internal market should be an important goal. Economic subsidies and reforms can only achieve their maximum impact by completely eliminating corruption.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
