text: in writing.- I believe that the choice of the European Union to grant additional support measures to Ukraine in the form of additional trade preferences is appropriate.Ukraine is carrying out unprecedented reforms, and reforms often also involve short-term socio-economic difficulties.The proposed measures will guarantee real economic and political support to Ukraine, in a particularly delicate phase, albeit with due attention and balanced incentives, while at the same time being weighted in the coverage of the selected products and in the respective volumes and additional quotas, as well as beingequipped with all the necessary safeguards to compensate for any market distortions.However, it is essential to ensure that any support measures, serving the objectives of the Association Agreement, to achieve a functioning market economy in Ukraine and to further integrate it into the internal market of the European Union.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - This text concerns a set of trade concessions in favor of Ukraine within the framework of the “deep free trade area” which has been applied provisionally since May 1, 2016 due to the association agreement between the European Union and this State. The report highlights the asymmetric nature of the concessions granted by the European Union, which reduces tariffs faster than Ukraine. This asymmetry is justified by the difficult situation of the Ukrainian economy, which contracted by 9.8% in 2015. These concessions consist of the granting of quotas exempt from customs duties for certain agricultural products: wheat, barley, oats. , natural honey, processed tomatoes, grape juice and corn. Certain industrial products are also subject to partial exemptions. These concessions threaten the economic equilibrium of certain sectors. With regard to maize in particular, this additional quota of 650,000 tonnes per year could cause prices to fall, since the European Union is already in deficit with Ukraine on its maize imports. Note that the European Union - Ukraine Association Agreement is the symbol of a denial of democracy. Rejected by the Dutch people by referendum in April 2016, the agreement was nevertheless adopted on May 30 by the lower house of the Netherlands.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – There is no doubt that the EU and Ukraine should cooperate more extensively in order to achieve a full implementation of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area between them. In light of this, the proposed additional preferences to Ukraine may further support the country’s economic recovery efforts and the reorientation of its markets towards the EU. This is really needed, particularly in view of the ongoing conflict in Eastern Ukraine, Russian trade sanctions on Ukraine, the unfavourable global economic environment and the economic hardships which Ukraine faces nowadays. Here, it is important to note that I fully support further trade liberalisation with Ukraine but I cannot hide my concerns that additional trade preferences to Ukraine in practice have the potential to destabilise EU agricultural markets. Recently, I asked the Commission about Ukrainian sunflower oil, which is a product of unfair competition and which significantly threatens sunflower oil producers in the EU, notably those in Bulgaria and Romania. In conclusion, I call on the Ukrainian authorities to initiate and implement deep political and economic reforms in order to decrease negative sentiment for the developing integration process with the country both within the EU and Member States.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Although some would like to see Ukraine as an example of a failing state, the government has conducted considerable reforms in the past two years, bringing concrete results and improvements for their citizens. Civil society has been instrumental in bringing those reforms forward. Two aspects have been of particular concern to both politicians and civil society in Ukraine – the visa free regime, which we already established, and the full implementation of the DCFTA. I welcome the very mature position of the Dutch Government and the vote in the Dutch Senate yesterday, confirming the ratification of the Association Agreement with Ukraine.  I hope that the outcome of the trialogue on the introduction of temporary autonomous trade measures for Ukraine will be constructive and balanced. Increasing the trade flows with our neighbour is a step towards a closer cooperation – an economic but also a political gesture. The EU should, however, maintain its conditionality to be able to foster reforms in the country. Measures to eradicate corruption should be part of this conditionality for further accessions in trade.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- Due to the ongoing conflict and trade sanctions with Russia, the Ukrainian economy remains in a difficult situation.The difficult state of the world economy has also exacerbated the country's situation.The EU can help Ukraine boost its economy by increasing trade flows between the EU and Ukraine through certain unilateral trade measures.This will allow Ukraine to reorganize its markets towards the EU (due to the collapse of Russian markets).On the positive side, the introduction of similar trade measures in the past has now increased trade flows between the EU and Ukraine.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – Regarding the situation in Ukraine, where the Russian Federation has occupied the Crimean Peninsula and is constantly engaging in active warfare in Eastern Ukraine, there is definitely a need for Europe to support Ukraine in one way or another. Regarding this report on the temporary autonomous trade measures for Ukraine, and the idea to increase the trade flows concerning the import of certain agricultural products and to grant concessions in the form of autonomous trade measures in selected industrial products, this seems to be positive for the acceleration of the elimination of customs duties on trade between the EU and Ukraine. One must also reiterate that Ukraine must continue strengthening the rule of law, human rights and the separation of power in their country and actively fighting corruption and organised crime.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on Sri Lanka GSP +.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate is about Sri Lanka. As you know, we are now granting the Generalised Scheme of Preferences Plus (GSP+) to Sri Lanka and thereby we recognise and support the historic political change in Sri Lanka which began with the election of a new President and Government two years ago. That resulted in a Government that launched an ambitious reform agenda, including reconciliation and justice, after the end of a very painful civil war. A major political priority was to re-engage with the international community and the EU, so Sri Lanka reapplied for GSP+ preferences. An unprecedented achievement was also that Sri Lanka decided to co—sponsor the United Nations Human Rights Council resolution on promoting reconciliation, accountability and human rights. I welcome the vote here in plenary on 27 April on GSP+, which, I believe, signals Parliament’s ambition actively to engage with Sri Lanka.  But of course this GSP+ is not a blank cheque. Just as with other GSP+ beneficiaries, the EU intends to hold Sri Lanka to its commitment to improve sustainable development, human rights and good governance. Sri Lanka will now be covered by one of the fundamental pillars of GSP+, the monitoring mechanism, which implies three things. Firstly, it implies written questions, the so-called scorecards, where we ask the GSP countries to detail how they are addressing shortcomings in the implementation of the relevant 27 international conventions. Secondly, we have regular dialogues with the authorities, as well as GSP missions and regular interaction with, for instance, the International Labour Organisation, the various monitoring bodies, business, trade unions and NGOs in order to have a broad and deep understanding of the situation in the country. Thirdly, we have a dialogue on human rights. With Sri Lanka we already have a well—functioning working group on democracy, good governance and human rights, and that is broader than the GSP+-related human rights conventions.  The information gathered during the GSP+ monitoring process is reflected in our biannual reports to Parliament and the Council. The next one will come by the end of this year. The European Parliament plays – you play – a very important role in this monitoring process because you submit relevant information to us and you use your political leverage to call for visible progress in GSP countries. So we will take the monitoring of Sri Lanka just as seriously as we take it for all the GSP+ beneficiaries. We are actually planning to do a first monitoring mission as early as next September to include Sri Lanka in the 2018 GSP+ implementation reports. The fact that we are now granting them GSP+ status does not mean that we are fully satisfied with the situation. We have been explicit that there are a number of shortcomings that need to be addressed. I have raised this with the relevant Ministers personally and we expect movement and progress from the Government on these issues. Some have doubts about the ability of Sri Lanka’s Government to implement tough reforms. However, it is undeniable that the human rights situation has improved with the new Government. We have also seen that the Government is resolved to act on controversial issues, for instance repealing and replacing the controversial Prevention of Terrorism Act, and ensuring that persons arrested are not denied access to legal counsel. So I am confident that this measure, GSP+ for Sri Lanka, can help the country to develop its economy on sound foundations that respect human rights and labour rights, and that are environmentally sustainable. This is, of course, needed in a country which is struggling to find a way forward in a process of reconciliation after a very troublesome and difficult past.

name: Thomas MANN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues! My speech starts with condolences for the victims of the devastating floods and landslides in Sri Lanka last week. Is the country ready for the GSP + program? The EPP thinks: yes. It's not just about tariff reductions and not just about easier access to European markets. With almost a third of exports, the EU is Sri Lanka's largest market. It is also about supporting reforms through a contemporary agreement, such as strengthening the rule of law and the further development of human rights. As a member of the South Asia delegation, I have visited Sri Lanka several times and have been able to convince myself of the measures taken to pacify the country. Mine clearing, building destroyed villages, resettling people in their former homeland. Sri Lanka is involved in the UN Human Rights Council and has committed itself to reconciliation. They have achieved most of their Millennium Development Goals - in education, gender equality and health. But there are still problems: anti-terrorism legislation must be in line with human rights conventions, women's and children's rights must be further strengthened, and many allegations against the security forces need to be investigated. There is an APS + control system - it has to be used. With the EU trading partners, human rights should not only be on paper, but must be tangible in everyday life - for all sections of the population.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Our group supports in principle the granting of GSP + to Sri Lanka, because the country has recovered very well after a terrible civil war lasting a decade. The steps taken to bring peace and harmonization deserve our support. The population deserves a chance for prosperity and happiness. But there are still loose ends and matters that have not yet been settled, such as the terrorism legislation or the power of the military. We also continue to hear from the UN rapporteur on human rights that the situation is still far from being right. That is why my position is: we give Sri Lanka the benefit of the doubt. But I am counting on the Commission, with regard to evaluation and enforcement, to do everything in its power to ensure that all those other loose points are sorted out. I am pleased that the Commissioner has said he will. Let's use the GSP + mechanism as a carrot and stick not only for Sri Lanka but also for other GSP + countries, such as the Philippines, to make sure they stick to their commitments. So yes, reward Sri Lanka after a long agony. But no, don't give the country's government a free pass to further delay much-needed reforms. After all, a Dutch saying goes: procrastination means cancellation. And cancellation will result in loss of market access and we do not wish that to the country. Thank you. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question under Rule 162 (8).)

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Ms Jongerius, for taking my blue card. You criticised the delay in the new counter-terrorism bill, but do you not appreciate that this is a very sensitive piece of legislation? It was approved by Cabinet in April 2017. It is just about to be put before the Sri Lankan parliament and of course this is so sensitive that it has to be dealt with by various civil society groups across the political parties, across society, and across international organisations as well. This is a serious matter and I do not think it is fair to criticise the Sri Lankan Government for the delay. They are actually trying to do the job properly and make sure it is a good piece of legislation.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: "blue card" answer.- It's clear to me.We have taken the decision to grant Sri Lanka GSP + status, although not all 27 criteria have yet been met.But if we take ourselves seriously, we also need to make sure that a country that gets these trade benefits takes all the other steps.We must therefore also point out that the legislation on this point still needs to be changed in practice.Through the granting of trade benefits, we are giving the country and the government proper encouragement to continue.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, may I start by agreeing with and underscoring every word of what was stated by Commissioner Malmström in her opening address. May I also on a personal basis as Chair of the South Asia Trade Monitoring Committee congratulate Sri Lanka on this achievement, and may I thank Christofer Fjellner, my colleague who chairs the GSP+ Monitoring Committee, for his attitude and the tremendous work he put into this file.  It is quite clear that Sri Lanka today deserves the support of the international community, and Europe must play its part in that. It is also clear that if every country had achieved all of the standards that we would like to see, there would be no need for the GSP+ scheme. This provides a genuine opportunity and an incentive. I have only two things to put to the Sri Lankan Government today. One, this is an opportunity for you to provide opportunity in those areas where it is most required in Sri Lanka and in those communities where it is most required, and secondly, please do not give this Parliament any opportunity to turn its back on the grant of the GSP+ to you in the future. The monitoring mechanism requires you to comply. Please ensure that you do.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - The human rights situation in Sri Lanka has improved a lot on paper. But not yet in practice. I was there at the beginning of April and I have heard many stories that testify to that. Employees work too long working days. They do not receive a living wage. They are intimidated if they want to join a union or go on strike. Trade unions cannot participate in collective bargaining and are not given access to workers and workplaces. That is blatantly contrary to the ILO conventions. Sri Lanka has previously had GSP + status, showing that the benefits do not automatically reach the entire population. The treaties that the country has signed must be respected and the European Commission can play a positive role in this. I would like Commissioner Malmström's commitment to work with Sri Lanka on a concrete roadmap for effective implementation of the GSP + conditions. There is already a roadmap by the Sri Lankan trade unions to implement union rights and during my visit the Minister of Development committed that 50% of the benefits of GSP + should go to workers. You have received my letter about that. The preliminary work has already been done. Will you take up the gauntlet, Mrs. Malmström? (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Madam Mineur, are you not missing the whole point of the GSP+ programme being put back in place? It is actually to allow the process to begin, to allow wealth to be created, and to allow success, prosperity and wealth to pass down to all levels of the working cycle. The working man and the working woman will inevitably benefit from this. I cannot see why you are criticising it.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: "blue card" answer.Thank you for your question.I am of course in favor of these people getting a job.The trade unions are also in favor of this.But Sri Lanka is a country where trade unions can hardly play a role and where there are many foreign investors.They are particularly interested in Sri Lanka because of the very low wages and the enormous workload.Foreign investors in particular benefit greatly from this and not the country itself.I know this is the system we work in, but GSP + is designed to help people in developing countries move forward.That is why I want there to be a level playing field where everyone meets lower limits and human and labor rights are respected.I insist on that.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I am also speaking in my capacity as Chair of Parliament’s South Asia delegation. GSP+, as we have been hearing, is a process of engagement and better market access to the European Union in return for implementation of the 27 international conventions. The implementation of these international norms – and I stress that these are not European Union wish lists, these are international norms – will be to the benefit of all Sri Lankans in many areas of everyday life and help towards much-needed reconciliation.  But the Commissioner is right. Effective and stringent monitoring is key, not least because many of us fear that the progress promised by the current Government of Sri Lanka is slow, whether that is on changes to the proposed counterterrorism act to bring it into line with international norms, operationalising the office of missing persons, moving on constitutional change; there are a number of areas.  I am pleased to hear that Commission monitoring will engage with a wide range of institutions such as the National Human Rights Commission, and civil society across the island, including war-affected areas and communities. It must build on the UN reports, such as that of the Committee against Torture. A timeframe for changes must be agreed with the government, and I would be interested to know what the Commission has identified as key objectives for the end of 2017. Sri Lanka knows from its own experience that GSP+ can be withdrawn but we hope that all will benefit after so much suffering in the country, but it is only going to happen if the government of Sri Lanka delivers on its promises to its people.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, "Trade or human rights? That is the problem!" I have mentioned Hamlet, but there is no Hamletic doubt here to dispel. Because you see, Sri Lanka is one of the countries that has violated human rights on a larger scale, yet it has been rewarded by the European Union with preferential trade duties. True, the country is slowly finding the right path of law and justice, but it has not yet made peace with the past, which is why it was important not to make concessions at this time, but to use them to leverage institutions and continue the reconciliation. However, the European multinationals crave privileged access to this country and its cheap labor, and here the Commission and Parliament give them the green light. Colleagues, I know that for many of you this is not the case, but for me the choice is not difficult between trade and human rights. Finally, let me express my closeness to Sri Lanka which was hit by a severe monsoon flood, we may have different opinions, but in the face of these catastrophes we are all one people.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! APS + is a check for the future, not a payment for a past deed. In this respect, it is correct that we are giving GSP + for Sri Lanka, but with clear monitoring. Cecilia Malmström said: There is already a monitoring delegation to Sri Lanka in September. I would simply say: You have to make sure that the signed and ratified ILO Conventions 87 and 98, which enable union involvement and joint negotiation, are respected. And there we have a lot of incidents in Sri Lanka where that doesn't happen. That is why I would advise the monitoring group to pay particular attention to four points. Firstly, there is the question of the establishment of trade unions in companies. The 40% membership threshold is too high and registration is too complicated. That has to be changed. Second, we need to ensure that the minimum age for union membership is the same as the minimum age for taking up employment. It cannot be that younger workers are not allowed to become union members. Third, we need to make it clear that responsibility for labor relations rests with the Department of Labor and not with the Board of Investment and others. Fourth, we must ensure that trade unions and workers have the right to bring their rights to court. Take that with you and try to get that through to the government of Sri Lanka.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, in Sri Lanka, as has been heard, there is a huge violation of human and fundamental rights, there is an uncontrollable role of the military. Sri Lanka is a paradise for multinationals who make huge profits as there are starvation wages, child labor, labor rights violations, lack of protection in health and safety and, of course, limited trade union rights. Thus, with the enhanced regime of generalized preferences, the winners are practically the European and other multinationals. And in practice what is being done is to have unfair competition, to have unfair practices, to dismantle the European textile, clothing and apparel industry. Therefore, what is needed is to strengthen the textile industry of the European Union itself. Do not wait for Sri Lanka to change and protect human rights. The exploitation of child labor will continue. Decisive measures are needed, especially the support of the European textile and clothing industry itself. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8))

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: blue-card question. – I apologise profusely for blue-carding a colleague from my own group but, based upon the comments that have just been made, Mr Marias, would you accept that we have heard all of these arguments of protectionism for European industries presented in previous cases before in this very House? But when all the time we have tested those arguments against fact and experience that is carried out in the marketplace, they have always failed to live up to the claims that were made at the outset, and in fact our industries have not been disadvantaged by granting such schemes to other countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), blue card answer. - I will disagree with Mr Karim, because what we have seen in both Sri Lanka and Bangladesh and in Asian countries is an overexploitation of the workers themselves. We have child labor, we do not respect labor rights. This creates unfair competition, we do not have fair and good practices in international trade. Of course, this is how they produce cheap goods that unfairly compete with the goods produced in the European Union themselves. There is therefore neither fair trade nor competition, but illegal practices to the detriment of Europe's own workers and businesses.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - When it comes to the application of the Generalized System of Preferences to Sri Lanka, we need to consider two aspects, I think.First of all, after three decades of civil war and terrorism, Sri Lanka is one of the fastest growing economies in the world.Its growth last year was more than 16 percent and is almost double the corresponding figures in the region.And this is largely due to the Generalized System of Preferences' access to the European Union's single market.Accordingly, the European Union, as a community based on values, has, I would say, a duty to ensure that a state that takes advantage of the opportunities offered by the European Union does not violate its values.At this point, I am convinced that the Commission has a great opportunity to set a policy precedent by constantly assessing the extent to which countries benefiting from facilitated access to the Single Market adhere to European values.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, it is a fact that the Sri Lankan government has made some progress in restoring peace to the country after a decade of civil war, as well as in its efforts to govern the country democratically. Whether it will certainly be able to meet its commitments on the implementation of international human rights treaties, as well as on work and reforms to be carried out such as, for example, the restriction of rights of the army, the anti-terrorism law and everything else, will be the subject of an examination that we must have as the European Union, because we have granted it the enhanced regime of generalized preferences and it is an opportunity to develop its economy. However, I would also like to point out at this point that we must take our measures so that we do not create conditions of unfair competition for the respective workers of the European Union and especially of the European South.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you all for this very important debate. The EU is already today Sri Lanka’s biggest trading partner, taking 30% of the country’s exports. Therefore, the potential to boost exports in clothing, fisheries, tea, spices, machinery and other products, as well as to attract investment, is of course considerable. This would bring clear benefits to the people and the local communities in Sri Lanka.  Granting GSP+ to the country gives a clear political signal to Sri Lanka that we, the European Union, want to engage, to invest in its sustainable development, to support a government which has as its prime priority to re-engage with the EU and the United Nations system, and to rebuild and reconcile the country after so many years of terrible civil war.  Nobody denies that there are still problems in Sri Lanka. It takes time to reform a country like this. We will engage with the government as we have done and we will deepen that engagement. We will be watching to ensure that they respect the 27 international conventions that they have signed up to. We will be watching the anti-torture legislation and the terrorist legislation. We will be watching the labour laws. We will be watching the situation for LGTBI persons. We are concerned about the criminalisation of homosexuality, for instance. Experience shows that a positive engagement with a GSP+ country contributes to economic development and creates platforms and possibilities for dialogue on all these issues with the government, of course, as well as with business, trade unions and civil society organisations. This in turn builds the building blocks for improvement. We will be dedicated to the monitoring and we will be looking forward to informing you on this process. As I said, we are already sending a mission in September this year, and I will be happy to report back when that mission has written its report. So thank you very much for your support on this. Thank you for this debate, and I am looking forward to working with you on Sri Lanka in the future as well.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the joint debate on: - the recommendation by Angelika Mlinar, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on recommendations for a draft Council decision establishing a multiannual framework for the work of the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights 2018-2022 (14423/ 2016 - C8-0528 / 2016 - 2016/0204 (APP)) and - the statements by the Council and the Commission on the multiannual framework for the EU Fundamental Rights Agency for 2018-2022 (2017/2702 (RSP)).

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to start by expressing my sincere gratitude to the Commission, the Council and all the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation and support during this process. As I have already said, I find the Council decision once again not to include police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the new Multiannual Framework for the Agency to be regrettable.  This is mainly for two reasons. First, I believe that from a legal point of view it is the wrong decision. Following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters have become part of European Union law and are therefore legally covered by the scope of the Agency’s tasks. The second reason is related to the evolving reality in the field of fundamental rights. Including police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the Multiannual Framework would better reflect the needs on the ground, by giving the Agency the right of initiative in these areas. Currently, the Agency for Fundamental Rights can act only upon request by the institutions to provide comprehensive analyses in these areas, which are of obvious relevance to fundamental rights. A change in this direction would send a very important signal, especially given the recent and ongoing legislative developments at EU level in this field. As already mentioned, this is not the first time that the Council has refused to include these areas of competence – as suggested by the Commission in its initial proposal – hiding its political will behind a legal argument. During the past month we have had a very constructive, open and transparent interinstitutional dialogue and, as rapporteur, I could not wish for a better working method. However, I would like to remind the Commission and the Council that the result achieved is not the end of the process, but actually the beginning. Tomorrow, hopefully – and I am pretty sure that this will happen – Parliament will give its consent to the Council decision and will vote on a joint motion for a resolution, which I proposed with the support of the majority of my colleagues in this House. The goal is to strengthen the opinions expressed by the Council and the Commission in their respective written statements, which were Parliament’s conditio sine qua non for giving our consent. I really appreciate the will demonstrated by both institutions to improve the working procedures for the governance and functioning of the Agency for Fundamental Rights and to clarify that the Agency’s competence also includes former third-pillar matters. However, fair interinstitutional cooperation will require additional action to be taken in the near future, starting with the Council and Commission agreement on the interpretation of the Agency’s founding regulation. Moreover, without prejudice to its right of initiative, I warmly invite the Commission, once the external evaluation of the Agency has been concluded, to present the proposal for amendments to the Agency’s regulation. This revision is necessary in order to improve the procedures for governance and for the functioning of the Agency, and to align the regulation with the Lisbon Treaty. Last but not least, I would like to thank the Agency for its good cooperation and to reiterate the importance of its work and its key role in the promotion of fundamental rights across the European Union.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I am very grateful for this opportunity to speak on behalf of the Council on the proposal for a Council Decision establishing a Multiannual Framework for the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights for the years 2018-2022. Every five years the Council has to adopt this multiannual framework. It determines the thematic areas of the agency’s work on the basis of the agency’s founding Regulation (EC) No 168/2007. This is essential to ensure the continued functioning of the agency, which makes such an important contribution to fundamental rights in the Union, a work that the Council highly values.  I would like to inform you about the statement of the Council concerning the review of the Multiannual Framework 2018-2022 made in December 2016 and entered into the Council Minutes. I quote: ‘Under Article 30, paragraphs 3 and 4, of Council Regulation No 168/2007, an independent external evaluation of the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights will be carried out in 2017. As stipulated in Article 31(2) of this Regulation, the Commission, after having assessed the evaluation report and recommendations made on that basis by the Agency’s management board, may consider submitting any proposals for amendments to the Regulation which it considers necessary. In this context, the Council agrees that it will consider carefully any proposals for amendments to the Regulation that the Commission may decide to submit, including those pertaining to the remit of the Agency to cover the areas of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The Council further agrees that it will consider carefully any proposals to improve procedures for the governance and functioning of the agency.’  The Council trusts that this statement will enable Parliament to give its consent to the proposed next multiannual framework for the Fundamental Rights Agency. This framework will allow the agency to continue to deliver high-quality work in the area of fundamental rights in the year 2018 and beyond.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first of all I would like to thank Ms Mlinar for her constructive dialogue with all parties concerned and for proposing that the European Parliament gives its consent to the Council’s draft compromise text on the Agency’s Multiannual Framework for 2018-2022.  Like the rapporteur, the Commission deeply regrets that the text agreed in the Council excludes the thematic areas of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and indeed this is not for the first time.  The Commission has always insisted on the inclusion of these thematic areas in the Agency's Multiannual Framework. There is no reason why the Agency should not collect data on all aspects relating to the area of freedom, security and justice, especially in the current context. Police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters are extremely important in the fight against trafficking of human beings, organised crime and combating terrorism. There are also sensitive areas from the point of view of fundamental rights. It is important that the Agency can provide support through reliable and comparable data and the collection of best practices and initiatives.  We cannot ignore the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and its consequences. The pillars have disappeared, there is only one law of the Union. The Commission will thus continue to ask the Agency to carry out tasks in these areas, even if they are kept outside the Multiannual Framework.  The Commission made all efforts to have these thematic areas in the Fundamental Rights Agency’s new framework, but the Council has unfortunately not achieved the unanimous agreement necessary. The Commission prepared a formal written declaration regretting the exclusion of the set thematic areas, which we will ask to have included in the European Parliament, as well as Coreper and Council, minutes. Let me also underline that the external evaluation of the Fundamental Rights Agency is ongoing and will deliver its findings at the end of this year, and on that basis, the Agency’s Management Board will make recommendations to the Commission. At the end of this process we will see whether any modification to the Fundamental Rights Agency founding Regulation will prove necessary. This being said, and as also expressed by Ms Mlinar, it is crucial that the new Multiannual Framework of the Agency enters into force as of 1 January 2018. The consent of the European Parliament is essential and I would like to express my full confidence that the plenary will vote to give such consent, allowing for the final adoption of the framework in the Council by the end of this year.

name: József NAGY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. –  Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, Minister, as the shadow rapporteur of the EPP, I would like at first to say thank you to our rapporteur Angelika Mlinar for her really great job and professional approach. Let me remind that the mandate of the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights for the next four years is to work in eight huge thematic areas, namely equality and discrimination based on sex, race, ethnic origin, or based on language, religion or political opinion. This Agency also produces research and surveys on discrimination based on disability, age or sexual orientation, or on membership of any national minority. The FRA will be responsible not only for the protection of personal data, but also for migration, asylum and integration of refugees and migrants. Other important issues are racism, xenophobia and related intolerance, as well as children’s rights.  Last, but not least, the Agency takes care of the victims of crime and access to justice. However, some of you complained about their exclusion of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Our legal services confirmed that the current legal basis does not allow such an addition. As Madam Mlinar pointed out, it would be a highly sensitive change, but there is a possibility to adjust the thematic areas by changing the establishing regulation of the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights.

name: Soraya POST
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Angelika Milnar and other colleagues for producing this report. As a shadow from the S&D Group, I wish you good luck, because you did this work very professionally and I liked cooperating with you. I would like to start by thanking to FRA for their excellent work, which has become essential in recent years. Just as in all the other thematic areas, we need FRA’s data and recommendations relating to the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters as well. That is why I would like to urge the Council and the Commission to make the necessary legislative changes to open the Agency’s mandate to the former third pillar matters.  I would also like, before the Commission and the Council, to express my special appreciation for FRA’s research into the situation of Roma in the EU, which is vital for monitoring the efficiency and shortcomings of the policies of the EU and those of its Member States. We especially welcome the Agency’s research—based recommendations concerning successful ways of fighting anti-Gypsyism and securing the Roma people’s access to, and enjoyment of, their human rights. It is essential that FRA continues its work in this much—neglected field. To this end, I would like the Commission and the Council to encourage FRA to focus on anti—Gypsyism during their work on Roma issues, to prepare a study on anti—Gypsyism in the EU and in the candidate countries, and to monitor it in all the relevant fields.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, we can be proud of a Union which commits to preserving the God-given gifts of life and human dignity for all of us. We should deeply value fundamental rights for all, both in our nation-states and in our cooperation. The Fundamental Rights Agency (FRA) has a duty to gather data on how well we are doing and to offer solutions to the institutions and Member States seeking to safeguard them. They are servants of our Union. As such, we must carefully cost and evaluate the added value to be gained if new areas of competence are to be given to them or not. In the past doubts have been raised over the methodology ensuring certain minorities, as we can read in the report on homophobia, transphobia and discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity. Costly research was weakened by respondents being able to enter the data multiple times and without further checks. I cannot, therefore, support any expansion of FRA topics and I would question whether this would be given real value for taxpayers’ money.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, I would like to address my first words to the teams and to the Director of the Agency to thank them for their work and for their research, which undoubtedly feeds our parliamentary work, and also for the expertise they have developed. I would like to reiterate - as colleagues have done - the importance of their role in the promotion of fundamental rights and freedoms throughout the European Union. Two points quickly. Firstly, on the Agency's multiannual working framework - as has been stressed by colleagues and as mentioned by the Commissioner - I also deeply regret the absence of the two themes of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters within the multiannual framework of the Agency, while these themes are obviously relevant for fundamental rights and that there is obviously, even today, a lot to do in terms of respect for rights in this area . I deplore this all the more since the program demonstrates the Agency's ability to adapt, in general, to the new realities of our European society. And our agreement today, Commissioner, Mr Council representative, is basically given to you only on one condition: that the regulation establishing the Agency be rapidly amended so that it is finally competent in all areas relating to fundamental rights, that is to say to these police and judicial cooperation. Finally, secondly, our Union is founded on values. The latter are the subject of systemic threats to the rule of law and I would like us to be able to grant greater independence to the Agency, and for it to have the power of self-referral and investigation, to be truly , not only independent but also impartial and strong, and thus live up to our ambitions and our European values.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the European institutions are not the closest to citizens, really, and that is why there is quite a lack of knowledge of how they work. On the one hand, we have the legislative reports, which later become directives, regulations, which are mandatory, let's say, and, on the other hand, we have the non-legislative reports, the declarations, the recommendations, which is not that there serve for nothing, but rather for little. In fact, on many occasions, what they do is to whitewash the European Union or to make it appear that certain political groups in this House are progressive. Today, for example, we have here the Recommendation on the multiannual framework for the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights. Of course, this is one of the second type - second class - and that is why it talks about promoting equality, non-discrimination, integration for migrants, the fight against xenophobia and the fight against gypsyphobia. And the same people who a few weeks ago voted in favor of a report - yes, legislative - will agree on these questions to deport migrants. The multi-year framework for the Fundamental Rights Agency will be great. And I'm glad. But what use is it? What good is it if they continue to build fences at the borders, if they continue forcing trans people to sterilize or if they continue to segregate Roma boys and girls in schools? The truth is that it will not serve any good for anything. In any event, it will serve to make it appear that some people in this House are concerned about human rights.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank colleague rapporteur Angelika Mlinar and all the shadows for the very good cooperation and very proactive attitude in trying to get through what the majority here wants. I would also like to say a big thank you to the Fundamental Rights Agency for all the great work it has been doing, all the staff there, for supporting us in our work for fundamental rights inside the European Union. What the Fundamental Rights Agency has been doing over these last years is something we definitely need. It is unique in providing reliable and comparative data, EU-wide data and studies, on all kinds of discrimination that human beings on this continent still face, be it because of being Roma, as has been mentioned already by my colleague Soraya Post, but also LGBTI people, asylum seekers and migrants. On data protection, the rights of children and disability too, we get such important material and studies for our work in all those fields from the Fundamental Rights Agency.  The case that we have here now – and it has been said by all of us who have been shadowing – is one of the examples where the Commission and Parliament have done a lot together to move ahead. It is the Council and the Member States that simply do not follow what has been on the table since the Lisbon Treaty. As both Commissioner Jourová and Angelika Mlinar have been saying, there is no reason why – in times of terrorism and the fight against terror and organised crime – police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters should not be included. There is no reason for that, so reluctantly my political group, the Verts/ALE, will give consent but I really want to see progress on that in the very near future, and I am addressing that to the Council.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group.- Madam President!So here it goes and the multi-year program for the Fundamental Rights Agency.We have to ask ourselves: What does this agency actually do?She does polls and she makes statistics.Eurostat does that too.The question is: what does this agency deliver for the general public?My statement: It delivers nothing and also no social added value.First and foremost, this agency is the operator and the pioneer for the gender ideology and it is the stirrup holder for the LGBTTIQ lobby.That is what we are working on.With this fundamental rights agency, the EU wants to control values and norms and form values and norms at the expense of the general public.This value-planned economy is then called the protection of fundamental rights.That is why I am of the opinion that this fundamental rights agency can simply be dissolved without major loss.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - The European Union puts endless emphasis on the apparent right of the whole world to settle here. But at the same time, the immigrant does not have to commit himself culturally or in behavior to his new country and can then collect his entire family. Madam President, we are no longer allowed to protect our borders and we can no longer even protect our own children against the daily violence of Islam, which we even now import. In the meantime, more money must go to an EU Fundamental Rights Agency, which has been more concerned about perpetrator profiling and Islamophobia since its inception than about the victims of Islam. The jihadist who struck Manchester had the right to reside and to practice his Islamic religion, which he did. But the children, his dismembered victims, had no right to safety. The cowardice and looking away of our political elite is incomprehensible. Chairman, how have we earned this?

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Madam President! I consider this Council decision to be window dressing. How do you intend to prevent discrimination, among other things because of worldview, political or other beliefs, when at the same time in EU countries such as Greece and Slovakia prohibition proceedings are organized under your eyes and people are persecuted and imprisoned for their political convictions and their professional existence is destroyed ? One of the largest political processes in the history of my country, the Federal Republic of Germany, ended yesterday. The proceedings against the Mittelrhein Action Office were initially directed against 26 defendants and lasted five years. Many of the accused have been in custody innocently for almost two years. A similar political procedure was directed in the FRG against the lawyer Horst Mahler, formerly the Red Army parliamentary group, then a defender in the NPD ban proceedings. In 2009, he was sentenced to a total of twelve years' imprisonment for expressing opinions. Today the 81-year-old, whose left lower leg was amputated in prison, is supposed to be abducted across half of Europe to spend the remaining three and a half years behind bars. Such political procedures are evidence that you, ladies and gentlemen of the Christian and Social Democrats, who are preying on the peoples of Europe, seem to be primarily concerned with silencing the opposition, despite resolutions and decisions. Get serious about the agency for fundamental rights. Finally, treat everyone equally in Europe.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, with regard to the thematic areas of the 2018-2022 multiannual framework for the Fundamental Rights Agency, the draft Council decision, contrary to the Commission's proposal, itemizes the various types of equality and non-discrimination, as set out in Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Thus, discrimination on the grounds of belonging to a national minority and language. This is a welcome fact, and I therefore welcome the draft Council decision, but it is important to emphasize that, although discrimination on the grounds of national minority is one of the thematic areas of the current multiannual framework, the FRA 2017 report on fundamental rights does not address national minorities at all. . For years, the agency has been pretending that this category does not exist at all in the Union, even though we are talking about 60 million EU citizens, including minority languages. While other minority groups are dealt with in separate subsections of the report, the problems of national minorities do not appear at all. It is time to realize that equal treatment does not mean equal opportunities, indigenous national minorities need positive discrimination for real equal opportunities.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the selection of the themes for 2018-2022 of the Agency for Fundamental Rights, continuity was chosen, continuity with the previous subjects that reflect the priorities of the European Union in the field of fundamental rights and will allow for asmooth continuation of the Agency's work.However, I hope that the Agency, within these established themes, will include the specific theme of aphrophobia, discrimination on an ethnic-racial basis of Afro-descendants, a phenomenon in strong growth in the European Union, but still little known.In-depth data and research are needed to document all the forms that aphrophobia can take in the different Member States such as marginalization, ethnic profiling, speeches and hate crimes, documentation necessary to be able to develop effective strategies for the fight against aphrophobiaand to advance on anti-discrimination legislation with a holistic approach.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Madam President, respect for human rights is essential. France knows this since it proclaimed them in 1789, but was there a need to create a specific agency to give states advice on human rights? I do not think so. The Union's Fundamental Rights Agency is a bureaucratic monster that costs us 22 million euros a year to almost zero results. Instead of questioning itself, it tried to capture two new areas: police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Fortunately, the Council opposed it. The worst thing is that the Agency has developed a communalist conception of human rights which is at odds with the French republican conception. In its 2017 report, the Agency admits this in paragraph 2.4, recommending that states - and I quote - promote inclusion, in particular by organizing the expression of religious communitarianism in the public space. It is against the French tradition of assimilation and that is why I strongly oppose this Agency.

name: Milan ZVER
text: - First of all, I would like to thank Angelika Mlinar for preparing the draft legislative resolution, this recommendation.I also congratulate the FRA, the agency, on its tenth anniversary.Like the rapporteur, I myself miss in this new multiannual framework the thematic area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.I know the work of the agency, years ago I also visited the president, the director of the agency and presented him with a blatant violation of human rights in the Patria case in my country, but without a real, appropriate response.So I think it would be good for the agency to expand its activities and also its responsibilities.I wish it would work a little more differently as well.It might be a good idea to try to conduct original research, not only on the basis of official data and information they receive from Member States, but to carry out their own original research on the state of democracy and respect for human rights and freedoms in the Member States.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, the European Agency for Fundamental Rights would offer special services if it had to deal with human rights violations in my country. In Greece, the troika has imposed memorandum policies that have led millions of my fellow citizens to unemployment. The troika has slashed salaries and pensions, imposed tax evasion on the incomes and properties of Greeks, properties which are now being auctioned off. The troika has now plunged the Greek people into poverty. Therefore, the Eurogroup and the troika, in which the Commission and the European Central Bank participate, are violating the fundamental rights of Greek citizens, as protected by the European Charter of Fundamental Rights. They are violating the right to a decent living, they are violating the right to protection of private property, they are violating the right to work since thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises are closing down. What will happen to this issue? Will there be more protection of fundamental rights in Greece?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you, honourable Members, for all your contributions and once again I share your concerns and I very much regret the Council's position on the exclusion of cooperation in criminal matters and judicial cooperation.  I heard here the question: why do we have a Fundamental Rights Agency? I find it quite important in simple words to reiterate what the Agency does and why we have it. The Agency is doing targeted research, mapping the situation, explaining the trends, collecting data and providing all those findings to us, to politicians, so that we can take responsible political decisions. Too much is at stake now and we politicians must make proper and right decisions, especially now at a time of brainwashing of our society through fake news. I would even say that, maybe with some pathos, we said we have an existential need of truth-based evidence which will enable us to take the proper responsible decisions. An hour ago here in this plenary session there was a very important debate about how to combat anti-semitism and we also spoke about the rise of hatred in the EU in relation to other groups of people, too. We spoke about anti-Gypsyism and about the hatred against the LGBT community and against other vulnerable groups of people, and so I would like to stress here that the Fundamental Rights Agency should deal also with the matters connected to this, especially criminal justice, because we need to make sure that all these groups of people are secure and safe in the EU, and we need to have the proper data to guide us in what we should do on this in the field of judiciary and police cooperation. So this is why the Commission is now disappointed by the position of the Agency. Anyway, I would like to repeat my hopes that the European Parliament will vote positively on the Multiannual Framework of the Agency and we will look into the possibilities on how to improve the situation in the future for the FRA so that it can do the proper work which we all need so seriously.  COMMISSION'S WRITTEN STATEMENT The Commission regrets the lack of agreement on the inclusion of the proposed new thematic areas of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights' Multiannual Framework for 2018-2022. The Commission recalls that following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters have become part of Union law and are therefore covered by the scope of the tasks of the Agency, as all areas falling within the competences of the Union, under Article 3(1) of Council Regulation (EC) n°168/2007. If these thematic areas are not included in the Council Decision establishing a Multiannual Framework for the Agency for 2018-2022, the Agency will continue to carry out its tasks in these areas upon request from the European Parliament, the Council or the Commission, under Article 5(3) of Council Regulation (EC) n°168/2007. Following the external evaluation of the Agency in 2017, the Commission shall transmit the evaluation reports and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council, the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions and make them public. After having assessed the evaluation report and recommendations, the Commission may submit any proposals for amendments to Regulation (EC) n°168/2007 which it considers necessary, as provided in Article 31(2) thereof.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me first say again that the Council attaches great importance to the work done by the Fundamental Rights Agency (FRA) in the area of fundamental rights. At the same time the Council is not convinced that the scope of FRA’s task should be extended before the evaluation exercise related to this agency. The exercise that is under way already has been concluded and evaluated, as highlighted by Commissioner Jourová.  For the future, the Council will consider carefully any proposals for amendments to the FRA Regulation that the Commission might decide to submit. This includes the possible amendments to extend the remit of the Agency also in the areas of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. I am not in a position to say more at this stage. I speak on behalf of the Council and therefore on behalf of all its members, but I can assure you that the Council will follow the debate closely, and I have paid particular attention to all the valuable opinions expressed here today.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would just to like to wrap up what you have all heard here. It is very clear that the work of the Agency for Fundamental Rights is highly appreciated in this House and that we really rely on all the information it provides. The quality of the Agency is beyond question, and this is something that we have to be aware of. We have a rare jewel here. I say this sincerely, also from my point of view as a human rights lawyer in a former life or when I had a different career.  You can see that you have a huge majority here in this House for the enlargement of its scope. I understand your position, but you can also be sure that we will not give up. I am quite well known for being persistent, so – with the support of the Commission, which we fully support in its approach – we will come back to you after the evaluation exercise, which will soon be over. I really hope that the Member States will then also appreciate the situation of the Parliament and the position here in the House, namely that we do not see this as an enlargement, but just an adjustment in the alignment of the scope according to the Treaty of the European Union.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure.I close the joint debate.The vote will take place on Thursday, 1 June 2017.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing.- I consider it a duty to support the report on the Multiannual Framework for the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, for which the Foreign Affairs Committee has also expressed its favorable opinion.However, I believe that the lack of agreement in the Council regarding the inclusion of the thematic areas of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters is a serious gap for the powers of this agency.It will therefore not be possible in the next few years for this institution to carry out analyzes on its own initiative in the sectors that have a clear relevance to fundamental rights.We hope that the Council and the Commission will soon review this decision, which would make it possible to send an important signal to citizens in terms of human rights.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - I am pleased with the broad parliamentary consensus to support the work of the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA). Like the rapporteur, I regret that the EU Council has left out of the new multiannual framework issues such as police and judicial cooperation, which had been recommended by the FRA Management Board, but I have no doubt that the Agency will know how to guide its activity within the more general framework of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU. I take as an example the work carried out by the FRA in its 2015 study on severe labor exploitation. Focused on the situation of migrant workers --who suffer disproportionately the most serious forms of exploitation (slavery, prostitution ...) - the work broadened the focus to realities such as those of the domestic, agricultural, hotel or construction sectors, in which many forms of severe labor exploitation generally go unnoticed. The conclusions, such as the recourse to Article 83 (2) of the TFEU to establish minimum European standards that allow criminal offenses in social policies, represent a concrete example of an innovative proposal that recognizes that labor rights are an integral part of the fundamental rights that the EU must protect.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, I invite you to support the text of this resolution, in particular because it provides for the inclusion of the fields of judicial cooperation in criminal matters and police cooperation in the multiannual framework.This would not only reflect the concrete needs on the ground in these troubled times, but would also allow the European Fundamental Rights Agency to undertake on its own initiative an in-depth analysis of areas which are clearly relevant to human rights.man, particularly in view of the recent legislative development that the European Union has experienced.I would like to remind you here of the ever-growing importance of the Agency's mission and the essential role it plays on a daily basis in the defense of fundamental rights within the EU.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. - The agency's statutory objective is to provide the Union institutions and the Member States with assistance and expertise on fundamental rights when implementing Union law. The thematic areas of the agency's activities are determined by a multiannual work framework covering a five-year period. In the draft decision, the Council proposed that in 2018-2022 the agency should focus, inter alia, on on the situation of crime victims and access to justice, equality and non-discrimination issues, information society issues, respect for private life and protection of personal data, judicial cooperation, except in criminal matters, migration and integration of refugees, as well as the rights of the child and the social inclusion of Roma. I share the rapporteur's opinion that Parliament should - in the course of the negotiations that have already closed - place greater emphasis on the need to include police and cooperation in criminal matters in the multiannual framework. This would not only reflect existing local needs, but would also enable the agency to provide, on its own initiative, a comprehensive analysis in areas of clear fundamental rights relevance. In addition, I believe that the agency should in the near term take over from the Venice Commission, which is a body of the Council of Europe, the task of providing the European Commission with professional expertise in the field of respect for the rule of law in the Member States, as well as analyzing the situation of their citizens (who are also citizens of the European Union), whose fundamental rights they are also violated as a result of actions of national authorities contrary to the principles of the rule of law.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Linnéa Engström, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, at the 14th UN High Level Conference on Promoting Sustainable Development (UN Ocean Conference) (O-000031/2017 - B8-0311/2017).(2017/2653 (RSP))

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Author. - Madam President! Thank you, Commissioner Vella. Next week, many of the world's leaders will gather in New York to discuss how we can coordinate to manage our seas responsibly within the framework of the UN's agenda for sustainable development goals. It is just the start of a collaboration that can become a gathering of forces for the oceans, like the work that is going on to slow down climate change. In October, the EU will host the Our Ocean conference, which will further strengthen cooperation to save our seas. The climate on earth and our oceans are intimately connected. Two thirds of our globe consists of oceans and one third of land. Our planet would not have been habitable if the relationship had been the other way around. The oceans are needed to regulate the climate, to provide us with vital food, water and not least oxygen. Every second breath we take is oxygen that has been produced by the sea. In order for the oceans to be able to deliver all eco-services, we must keep them healthy and viable. We get alarm report after alarm report that tells of distant paradise islands in the Pacific Ocean that are soaked in plastic, of plastic particles that increase mortality and reduce the reproduction of small fish and crustaceans - those that form the very basis of the ocean food chain - and of overfishing and illegal fishing. As much as 15%, or 26 million tonnes of the world's total fishery, is illegal, according to estimates by the UN Food and Agriculture Organization. In total, the fish is worth $ 23 billion. The "black" fish creates chaos in our markets and competes with fish from fishing companies that do the right thing. In addition, illegal fishing pulls away from the carpet for all efforts to preserve and manage our common fishing resources in a sustainable way. Inspiring more countries to take the step of actively combating illegal fishing will be one of the most important issues during next week's UN conference. More than three million people have fish as their main source of protein, and in many developing countries fishing is the most important employment and source of income for millions of citizens. As the struggle for resources intensifies, we must ensure that we manage them in the best possible way and that they are distributed fairly. Then there is no place for illegal fishing. Developing countries are particularly affected, as they lack the resources to control their waters and stop illegal behavior. In recent years, the EU has developed a framework of rules to better control fishing outside the Union's borders. It includes the Control Regulation, the Regulation on illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and the Regulation on the authorization of EU vessels to fish outside Union waters. As for the last regulation, I am the rapporteur, and we are currently in final negotiations with the Council on a new legal text that is more comprehensive than the current regulation. We are taking a holistic approach to all EU boats fishing outside the Union's waters, including those fishing through direct agreements with third countries and those fishing in the high seas - something that has previously been completely unregulated. This is a big step forward. However, the regulations must not stay on paper - they must be followed up. The Commission's own evaluation of the Control Regulation and the European Court of Auditors' report, which came out this week, clearly show that much remains to be done before we can say that we have full control over EU fishing activities. It is completely unacceptable that some member states do their homework while others get away with completely ignoring the regulations. I expect the Commission to take its role as guardian of the Treaty seriously and put pressure on those who do not yet live up to our standards. At the same time, with the regulation on illegal fishing, we can put pressure on those fishing nations that do not live up to their responsibility as flag states, and that do not control the activities of their boats. Ultimately, the EU can stop the import of fish. When the EU, which is the world's largest importer of fish, closes its market - then it hurts. Unfortunately, there is however, still too many other markets are less meticulous, and the "black" fish finds other sales. That is why I want to encourage and encourage other states to follow the EU's example: to take responsibility as a market state. It is time to completely close the market for illegally caught fish. A first step is for more countries to adopt and implement the FAO's agreement on port state measures, which entered into force exactly one year ago. It is a regulatory framework that allows states to keep boats fishing illegally away from their ports. So far, however, only 46 countries have joined, and many of the major fish markets, such as China and Japan, are missing. It is now very good and gratifying that the world's oceans and fisheries are on the international agenda, where these issues belong. The EU is continuing its efforts to tackle illegal fishing. Hopefully the rest of the world will sit with us in the boat. We must continue to work hard to combat those who see our oceans as a haven for illegal activity.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking Linnéa Engström for the question on the UN Ocean Conference which will be starting in five days in New York. The UN Conference, together with the Our Ocean Conference which will be hosted by the EU this coming October in Malta, will be the most important global ocean events this year. These two conferences are mutually reinforcing each other and will help us all to keep the momentum for action in the interest of our oceans. The UN conference will allow the European Union to showcase its leadership in making oceans safer, more secure, healthier, and above all, more sustainably managed. These are priorities for the European Union and its Member States, as set out in the joint communication on international ocean governance.  Sustainable Development Goal 14 can be a very strong driver for reinforcing ocean governance. This and other goals under Agenda 2030 are being actively pursued through many of the EU's policies, as we established in our communication in November on the next steps for a sustainable European future. For example, the Marine Strategy Framework Directive provides a comprehensive and integrated approach to the protection of the marine environment and natural resources. This is based on an ecosystem approach aiming to achieve good environmental status of European marine waters. Our birds and habitats legislation provides for protection of the EU sea area through a network of marine protected areas - MPAs - as a part of Natura 2000. The European Union is tackling marine litter and pollution at source through its rules on waste management and prevention and port reception facilities for ship-generated waste and cargo residues, as well as through the circular economy. We have also set up a system for ecosystem-based maritime spatial planning in Europe. We have revised our common fisheries policy, and many stocks are now recovering as a result.  Our rules against illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing ensure that our Member States implement their international obligations, keep illegally caught fish out of the European market and help us improve fisheries governance in third countries. Just last week we again showed our commitment to fight illegal fishing globally. We listed St Vincent & the Grenadines and the Comoros as uncooperative third countries. This is tantamount to issuing a red card which, amongst other consequences, effectively bans trade in fisheries products from these countries to the European Union. And we have also issued a warning, a so-called yellow card, to Liberia to encourage necessary reforms there.  I will also emphasise the importance of fighting IUU at the UN Ocean Conference on 9 June. The day after World Ocean Day I will host an event on the contribution of this fight to ensuring the long-term sustainability of fisheries resources. I will be joined by Ministers from Fiji and Guinea, two countries that benefited from cooperation with the European Union in the past.  Sustainable management and conservation of natural resources, such as biodiversity and fisheries, is also gaining importance in our trade and investment policy. For example we are including dedicated sustainability provisions in the relevant trade and investment agreements and we are also committed to eliminating harmful fisheries subsidies in line with target 6 of SDG 14. And that is why the European Union tabled a specific proposal at the WTO last October. We are now actively involved in WTO negotiations and hope to achieve a multilateral agreement on fisheries subsidies at the WTO eleventh ministerial conference in December in Buenos Aires. Finally, I am pleased to announce that the Member States and Council two days ago endorsed a list of clear and concrete voluntary commitments that the EU will present at the UN Ocean Conference next week. These demonstrate the European Union's strong and common endeavours to make SDG 14 happen in practice.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, coastal and marine resources contribute an estimated EUR 30 trillion to global [inaudible] ecosystem services, but those resources are extremely vulnerable to environmental degradation, overfishing, climate change and pollution. In this context, policymakers all over the world need to find a way to agree to ensure sustainable long-term use of the oceans. Only yesterday, Members of Committee on Fisheries voted on my opinion concerning an agenda for the future of our oceans in the context of the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals. In this opinion, we recognised that the current framework for oceans governance is not effective enough. We therefore encourage more concrete actions in order to accomplish the Sustainable Development Goals. International oceans governance should apply the principles of decentralisation and regionalisation; it should involve all the stakeholders at all stages, from conception to implementation of the measures, and it should be based on environmental and strategic impact assessment.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, the world has committed itself to the goals for sustainable development. Among these, the fourteenth concerns the oceans. Sustainable development encompasses three non-hierarchical pillars. As provided for in the full text of the United Nations, it is necessary to provide opportunities for appreciation to remote communities and island states. Next week, at the important meeting to be held in New York, several states and organizations will commit to the sustainable use of the oceans. Moving from political commitments to concrete actions is essential. The way the European Union and its Member States are getting involved, on a voluntary basis, strengthens my pride in being European. We know that the United States of America is blocking understandings and decisions committed to sustainable development. All the more reason for the European Union to ensure leadership and commitment to this dossier. This is not just my appeal, it is a cry from future generations.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to join with all of my colleagues in wishing the Commissioner, and indeed our team, every success at the Ocean Conference next week. When I started to look at this, it made me realise how far we have come on this issue of sustainable oceans, and yet also how far we still have to go. We have had a change of mindset. Certainly the common fisheries policy, which has not always been universally admired, is beginning to change, but we need to be very vigilant. Indeed, just in these few weeks when we have been talking about external fishing fleets – as I have been, and the rapporteur, the author of this report, has also been involved – you are reminded, with every article you go through, about how you have to be vigilant and to make sure that you do not slip backwards. We have to go forwards when it comes to sustainable development.  So I would like to welcome this resolution. I welcome the opportunity for a delegation from this Parliament to go to the meeting and I wish them every success.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development Goals presented by the Commission is an ambitious agenda. The 14 actions proposed by the Commission are sustainable, responsible and reasonable, but we must keep in mind that more than 30% of our marine resources are overexploited. I believe that two actions on this agenda are vital to the future of our oceans: firstly, improving the framework for international governance of the oceans, closing the gaps in the existing framework and, secondly, illegal fishing.
