The two actions, in my view, are interconnected, but I believe, Commissioner, that it will be a very difficult battle, the battle with illegal fishing, in the context of non-EU countries that have not yet ratified and implemented the UN Convention, and I am also referring to the United States. In the context of the negotiations on the future international agreement on marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdictions, which can only exist in the context of the UN Convention on the Law of the Seas, I would like to know how the European Commission aims to reach an effective agreement. when we know very well that there are states that are determined to deny the existence of climate change and the need for responsible management of fish stocks. With regard to the sustainable management of resources, we are once again talking about the need for a system of regional fisheries management organizations based on international agreements that have the necessary strength, support and respect from states for their decisions to be implemented. In this context, I would like to ask the European Commission to what extent it has a plan, other than the agenda proposed last year, for negotiating and setting up organizations in the Arctic.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, UN objective 14 on the oceans establishes the prevention and reduction of marine pollution of which fisherwomen and fishermen are the main victims and to whom the entire responsibility for the conservation of fishery resources should not be attributed. In this context, we want to put an end to it, once again, in the need for the elements of regeneration of the rivers and in the stoppage of the works that cause changes in the currents and impacts in the environment. In the field of prevention, we want to draw attention to the impacts of blue growth and to encourage this Parliament and the Commission to assume the need to prevent any activity that endangers fishing. We expressly call for a ban on mining on the seabed, as well as the cancellation of the mining concession on the seabed in Papua New Guinea and also an end to oil prospecting. I would like, Commissioner, that the EU also defend this issue.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, the question put focuses on helping third countries to fight illegal fishing, by highlighting the role played by the regulation on illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. But above all, it calls for better coordination of the fight against illegal fishing and trade policies. We are indeed the world's largest importer of seafood products and it is imperative to close our market to products from illegal fishing. This is far from the case today. The Commission is not sufficiently banning imports from countries which are not combating illegal fishing. It issues red cards against these countries, yellow cards, sparingly, while it is much harsher towards European fishermen who do not respect the rules. Finally, NGOs published a report last March to highlight the weakness of border controls and checks on catch certificates. For my part, I am delighted that we are rediscovering the value of border controls and I also expect these controls to be improved.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Madam President, I am pleased that the High-Level Conference of Nations on Goal 14 for Sustainable Development is taking place soon. The oceans are key to tackling challenges like climate change and hunger. I now stop at the fishing activity to highlight that the European fleet is one of the most regulated and most respectful of the oceans and their resources. Other countries should also ensure better control of their fleets in order to increase the number of sustainably exploited stocks. Also, logically, it is necessary that decisions about access to resources are based on rigorous scientific studies. Ladies and gentlemen, one of the objectives is to end unreported and unregulated illegal fishing by 2020. The fight against IUU fishing is a priority to which flag states, coastal states, port states, through the FAO agreement, and marketing states must contribute. I also welcome that another objective is to guarantee artisanal fishermen access to resources and markets. I remember that there are areas and fishing regions highly dependent on this type of fishing. According to United Nations data, for more than 3 billion people, the oceans are their main source of protein. The sustainability of resources is therefore essential. But I also want to regret that in Europe every year quotas of species that are at safe levels of exploitation are wasted. For this reason, I insist once again on the need to seek mechanisms that redistribute unused quotas within the Union among the other Member States.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately in this debate we cannot but start from the fact of the day: Trump's announcement to withdraw from the Paris agreement, a line that undermines the foundations not only of the fight against climate change but, more in general, the achievement of the entire agenda for sustainable development for 2030, the theme at the center of the United Nations conference to be held in New York next week and in which I will participate with the Parliament delegation. It was supposed to be the first important appointment to move from political commitments to concrete actions towards the global goals for sustainable development and now, in the light of what has happened, it will be even more so. We must aim to achieve the goals we have set ourselves, convinced that a more sustainable system is not only good for the environment but also good for the economy, which today is subjected to the challenge of efficient use of resources. If this argument is valid in general, it is even more so for the management of our seas. Responsible management of the seas is the only one capable of fully promoting biodiversity and at the same time the potential of the blue economy: tourism and fishing.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, in the current political climate and situation, the EU must take the lead on international ocean governance. These two upcoming conferences give us a good chance to take that role and gather broader political support. It could be that maritime ecosystems are actually under much greater stress than land ecosystems and that we are at the limits of the endurance of maritime ecosystems. Both demersal and pelagic systems are on the brink of extinction without the ability to recover and reproduce good and healthy fish stocks for the future. We would actually need a moratorium, at least in half of those systems used. Then there is the issue of micro—plastics, chemicalisation, dumping of waste, use of resources – like deep—sea mining, which was mentioned – and oil drilling. If we do not act now, it might be too late in five or ten years. There are of course the special challenges concerning the Arctic seas, which we discussed earlier here in the Parliament. So I hope that the Commission takes up this task and role.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, dear Commissioner, in 2016 the European Union set out the joint agenda for the future of our oceans. In 2015, the leaders of G7 agreed on a declaration that highlights the importance of oceans governance science? The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development proposes 17 sustainable development goals, amongst them SDG 14 – the oceans goal – which aims to conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development. However, only 2.18% of the world’s oceans have been fully protected as of today.  Our oceans cover more than two thirds of the earth’s surface and contain 97% of our planet’s water. Over three billion people depend on marine and coastal resources for their livelihoods, the majority of world trade is conducted by sea and the importance of the blue economy cannot be ignored. Nevertheless, we take our oceans for granted. Eighty per cent of marine pollution and litter in oceans comes from land-based sources, and maritime CO2 emissions are projected to increase by 50% to 250% in the period up to 2050. Put simply, oceans, seas and coastal areas form an integrated and essential component of the earth’s ecosystem. The ocean is a primary regulator of climate and weather. Next month in New York the United Nations’ first global conference on the oceans will take place with the aim of developing a robust implementation framework for our oceans. I believe that today, with the United States drifting away, the European Union should play an important role, on the basis of its experience, and not only through its environmental policy, in developing a sustainable approach to ocean management.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the upcoming UN high-level conference to support the implementation of SDG 14 is a unique opportunity to initiate an international process to improve global ocean governance. Despite global efforts to reduce overfishing by 2015, 31.4 per cent of the world's fish stocks were still overfished in 2002 in Johannesburg. Illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing causes much of this impoverishment and puts honest fishermen at a disadvantage, weakening coastal communities, especially in developing countries. The European Union has a duty to promote with greater determination, in the context of the United Nations Ocean Conference, a comprehensive approach to eliminate the loopholes that allow illegal operators to take advantage of their activities. Only a precautionary approach, based on the protection of ecosystems, as established by the treaties and the common fisheries policy, can help restore and maintain fish stocks above the levels necessary to ensure maximum sustainable yield.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, sustainable development is the key to the survival of the planet itself. The UN High Level Conference on the Oceans is an important opportunity for the international community to demonstrate that international law will finally be respected. Japan must realize that illegal whaling, which exterminates thousands of whales, cannot be tolerated. China must also stop illegal fishing and stop the systematic disappearance of marine stocks. The European Union must take practical steps to completely and completely ban the import of illegally caught fish. The red card, Mr Vella, has to go to various countries, including China. Only in this way can there be protection of the oceans and enhancement of fair trade. Only in this way, Mr Vella, can European Union fishermen be protected from the unfair practices of third countries. So support, Mr Vella, European fishermen, because there is unfair competition from third countries that violate the law of the protection of the oceans.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank honourable Members for their valuable contributions. Starting with Mr Wałęsa, I agree that it is time to take more concrete action. That was the idea behind Vice—President Mogherini and myself launching the Ocean Governance communication last November. This is a very important way of moving forward, focusing our ocean governance strategy on three areas: first, to strengthen the legal framework; second, to reduce human pressures on the oceans; and, third, to continue investing in more research and more knowledge. I agree with Mr Serrão Santos that it is important, again, to move from commitment to implementation and for the European Union not to take the lead but to continue to lead, especially in the absence of the USA. I also agree with Ms Girling that we have come a long way but still have a long way to go. This applies not just to the European Union, because this is a global issue and what we are doing is not only within the European Union: we are tackling this at a high global level. I also agree with Mr Nicolai that Agenda 2030 is an ambitious agenda. I can assure you that, in the same way that we took the lead during the negotiation process, we will continue with that lead, even more importantly during the implementation phase as well. As I mentioned, eliminating gaps in the legal framework is one of our focus areas in the ocean communication. Fighting illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing (IUU) is another important aspect of our second area of priority, reducing human pressures on the ocean. I also agree that we have to walk the walk when we say that all countries and all continents have to do the same. We cannot possibly move on more, better and stronger legal frameworks if some of us have still not ratified the existing legal framework, such as the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) – and we are doing our best to push the countries in question to start committing to and implementing the existing legal frameworks. With regard to an instrument on biodiversity beyond national jurisdiction (BBNJ), a lot of progress has been made, and in the coming weeks one of the final preparatory meetings will take place. Again, we are pushing other countries for support.  With regard to international agreements, we all know what is happening in the USA. I have already mentioned elsewhere that international agreements are there to be honoured. We cannot discuss, commit to and then not honour our commitments. With regard to marine litter, this is a scourge and we are also addressing this, among other things through the new Plastics Strategy, which will be coming out before the end of this year. We are trying not just to address what has already happened in the ocean but to address this issue at source. We call it ‘marine litter’ but it is actually all land litter that ends up in the sea. Regarding encouraging blue growth, we recognise the ‘blue opportunities’ from the oceans, but we also recognise the environmental responsibilities that go along with this, and these environmental responsibilities come into play when we talk about deep-sea mining, drilling and so on.  Ms Goddyn, with regard to illegal fishing, using the red card is, I think, the most effective tool that we have – and we have used it. It has been effective because, when it comes to trade, we have seen countries which were traumatised when we used the red card but some of which, today, are our best partners when it comes to fighting IUU. Mr Millán Mon, it is true that our industry in Europe is one of the best regulated and, I should add, not just within European Union waters but in our external waters as well. One word of caution: we do, more than anything, want to support small—scale fisheries, but unfortunately – and I say this with a little sadness – small-scale does not always mean sustainable. I think we have to focus on what is sustainable and what is not rather than looking at what is big or small. With regard to quotas and where stocks are, we are doing our best. At the moment, the only pending issue, where everyone is saying that the stocks are doing well and we can utilise a higher quota, is probably tuna. We are waiting for the new quotas to come out. New scientific advice will be coming out in the next few weeks as well. Ms Bonafè again mentioned the fact that, unfortunately, President Trump is not complying. It was a very sad statement that we all followed today. My feeling is that this does not reflect what the whole of the USA is thinking because I know that NGOs there are totally supportive, as is a section of the private sector. I know that even some of states within the USA have already come up with their own plans for ocean governance and blue growth. Here again, the European Union is ready to take a stronger lead and I think this is the sentiment when we talk to other continents and other countries. They are not saying that if the USA is not taking on its commitment they will not take on theirs. No, it is the complete opposite of that: the sentiment is that, if a vacuum is created by the USA, we have to work harder and to do better to fill that vacuum.  Ms Pietikäinen, you said the same thing about taking a stronger lead, especially in terms of what we are seeing. I totally agree with you about the ecosystems. Very often, when we talk about ecosystems and biodiversity, we are referring to our biodiversity and ecosystems on land, yet we know that the oceans are home to more than 70% of the planet’s global ecosystem. With regard to the Arctic, we are pushing through our Arctic policy – which we also launched last year – to have a fishing moratorium and to agree that no fishing will take place before there is scientific advice on this. Mr Faria also mentioned the areas protected in the oceans. When it comes to protected areas, it is true that we have made more progress on land than we have in the ocean. On land we have managed to reach 18% to 20% of the surface area of the EU, whereas in the oceans we have barely reached 60%. So we have to do more work, not just to identify the areas but also to see how we are going to manage those areas because simply identifying the areas without having any management plans at all is not going to get us anywhere. I agree with Mr Caputo that the coming conference in New York is a unique opportunity for everyone to start showing their commitment. I would add that the conference in Malta in October is also a very important one. As I said in my speech, the two events are complementary and mutually reinforce one another. We are looking forward to the sequence of the other ocean conferences, the fourth one being in October.  Mr Marius, yes, regarding our fight against IUU, you mentioned China. China is a special case because we can see that it wants to be committed and is making positive signs, with a lot of willingness to cooperate. Just to let you know, we have set up the EU-China Blue Year this year, and tomorrow we are going to have a Chinese delegation – another Chinese delegation within a period of three months – to continue working on our EU—China Blue Year and, as I said, we will continue pushing to turn their willingness into action. I would like to thank everyone involved once again and I would like, in particular, to thank Ms Engström.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday, 1 June 2017.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! This year, in June 2017, the United Nations will host a high-level conference to improve global ocean governance, which will contribute to the implementation of the 14th Sustainable Development Goal. Oceans and seas play a central role in our lives and are key to our well-being and our future. We know that at the Johannesburg Summit, the world committed itself to curbing overfishing by 2015. 31.4% of the world’s fish stock is still overfished. This not only poses a serious threat to certain marine ecosystems, but also poses a serious threat to food security and the economic and social sustainability of coastal communities. In particular, illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing poses a serious threat to fish stocks. The EU, led by the European Commission, should take a comprehensive approach and persuade partner countries to accept it so that we can take up the fight against illegal fishing effectively. Please support the draft EP report on the table, which could point the right direction for the participants in the UN Ocean Conference.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Sustainable Development Goal 14, defined by the UN, concerns “conservation and sustainable use of the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development”. This is one of those areas where the need for coordinated and shared efforts at the international level becomes evident. The oceans and seas are, in fact, fundamental to our life, to our well-being and to the future of humanity and the planet, as we know it. The issues under discussion - such as warming and acidifying the oceans, bleaching corals, increasing pressure on fish populations and the increasing amount of marine waste - are pertinent and require discussion and action in order to protect of the oceans. Without accepting that the EU and its policies stand as a paradigm of sustainability, quite the contrary, we follow the concern that is at the root of this debate, which we consider necessary. A wide view is required on the set of interactions between man and the seas and oceans, as well as on the activities associated with them. Fishing is just one of the activities to take into account. Others exist, such as the exploitation of mineral resources, among other examples, which have been gaining greater centrality.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: written. - When we talk about the planet we forget that its three quarters are seas and that global warming extremely affects the oceans. Ocean currents are the planet's thermal regulator and can dramatically change the climate. The rise in temperature, acidification, the rise in levels, and the accumulation of waste and pollutants on the seabed and sea surfaces irreversibly affects our way of life, risking the subsistence of millions of people. The lack of jurisdiction aggravates the problem of overexploitation of resources, illegal fishing and the dumping of all kinds of waste and pollutants, and international authorities do not have sufficient legal instruments to punish these actions. Technological breakthroughs, which provide insight into the state of the seas, are key to the governance of the oceans and will have to be deployed as a means of supervision and control. The urgent convening of the UN High-Level Conference, focused on the need to act on a planetary scale to mitigate the impact of human activities on the oceans, should be a clear signal for legislators to become aware of the serious state of the marine environment.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the joint debate on the following reports on Digital Europe: - the report by Reinhard Bütikofer, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the digitalisation of European industry (2016/2271 (INI)) - (A8-0183 / 2017),and - the report by Michał Boni, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on an Internet connection for growth, competitiveness and cohesion: a European society based on gigabytes and 5G (2016/2305 (INI)) - (A8-0184 / 2017)

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The New York Times journalist Thomas Friedman once said: “The country that gets the greenest, the fastest, with the smartest technologies, that is the country that will lead the 21st century.” In view of the disruptive effects that digitization is already having today in many areas of industry, we must add that the development of these areas must be taken at least as importantly. We are actually dealing with a fundamental industrial revolution here. The countries of Europe with their historically grown industrial base, know-how and research landscape, qualified employees and a large domestic market have absolutely good prerequisites. But whether we will be able to use these prerequisites effectively together, to keep up with the competition between the various major economic regions for technological leadership in this digitization area, that remains to be seen. I think we need a common European vision. I think we need European coordination. We need the right framework conditions for infrastructure, investments and innovations. We need a focus on cybersecurity as a special profile of European development, and we have to pay attention to the social dimension. An integrated strategy for the digitization of industry must consider competitiveness through profit - for example in terms of material intensity or more efficient use of resources - just as sustainability can contribute to digitization, for example in the area of ​​energy transformation or circular economy - and good work. Because digitization can help to improve working conditions. For example, it can be used to create new, employee-friendly working time models, and it can even help to improve jobs in other countries had migrated, return. We must expressly take care - this was shared by all the groups in this House - that the economic dynamism that is developing is not at the expense of social and regional cohesion in the Union. Five points are important in the EU's common industrial policy on the digitization of industry. Firstly, that it is indeed part of a European industrial policy and that it does not stand alone; that when we invest and innovate in infrastructure, we pay particular attention to the fact that it benefits SMEs; that when it comes to cybersecurity and the secure flow of data, we emphasize that this should be the profile that we particularly want in Europe; that we are not left behind when it comes to standardization policy and that we also have to reformat certain elements of our competition policy. We must not ignore the social challenges, the upheavals that can go hand in hand with them. That is why the report names these prerequisites, of which education - further education, further learning and training - is certainly of the greatest strategic importance.

name: Michał BONI
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank all those colleagues who worked together on the report. I believe that we in the European Parliament are united and have a common aim to make a coordinated 5G Action Plan for Europe. We are sending a clear message to the Member States, regions and all stakeholders, that Parliament supports all efforts to reach a comprehensive approach for timely deployment of 5G. 5G is more than a mobile revolution; it will be an innovation engine, bringing disruptive change across industries, creating new quality networks and very high-capacity networks. 5G will enable new high-quality services, which will ultimately improve the customer experience for increasingly sophisticated and demanding digital users.  What do we need to make the vision of 5G real? We need the rules to be future-oriented, pro-investment, pro-innovation and in accordance with the principle of infrastructure-based competition. Investments are the key for achieving 5G goals. The simplification of the legal framework, flexible models for co-investments, and long-term certainty and predictability are required. We need a clear understanding of what 5G means for all of us. The next generation of ultra-high broadband infrastructure will support the transformation of processors in all economic sectors – healthcare, energy, utilities, transport, automotive industry, virtual reality – and provide flexible and highly personalised services that improve every citizen’s life. We need 5G systems that are able to operate over a very wide frequency range, from below 1 GHz up to 100 GHz. The frequencies of 3.6 GHz and above 10 GHz should deliver extreme data rates and capacity in dense areas.  We need the cooperation of all stakeholders in order to fulfil all the conditions within the required timeframe. The key is to harmonise the spectrum allocation processes. The Member States should understand that we have to avoid the fragmentation of decisions and solutions if we want to achieve the 5G objectives. The effective collaboration of all – the European Commission, BEREC, the Member States, business, regions and regional authorities and consumers – is necessary. We need to develop financing for the 5G Action Plan in the next Multiannual Financial Framework. It should be at the proper level and use financial instruments, as well as subsidies, if we want to solve the problem of high -quality Internet accessibility in rural areas. Of course, we need to incentivise private investments, but we also need to have public support. We need to ensure coherent and timely actions at regional and city level. It should encourage cross-sectoral innovation and foster an industry-wide economic cooperation framework.  The first step is key. The timely implementation of the changes in all national broadband plans with country-specific recommendations. We need to make sure that 5G will be developed as an integrated set of solutions, and there must be tests and large-scale pilots in all sectors and countries at the same time. The standardisation roadmap for each sector, relying on industry-led processes, is needed. All hands on deck. We need to facilitate SMEs’ access to the 5G participatory broadband platform, which is key for using all of the resources for the best investment models. It is our obligation for the future.

name: Michał BONI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, very high-capacity Internet connectivity, fixed and mobile, is essential to unleash the next wave of the European Union competitiveness opportunities and innovation potential and to allow Europe’s businesses and citizens to harvest the full benefits of the Digital Single Market. The communications on a European Gigabit Society and the 5G Action Plan for Europe identify the tools needed to bring this about. The Commission has recently reported on the status of the initiatives presented in these communications as part of its mid-term review of the progress of the Digital Single Market.  The effectiveness of the proposed actions depends largely on the engagement of Member States and of the European institutions, in close cooperation with all relevant stakeholders, to provide the policy, regulatory and financial support that is required.  I also want to underline that, for achieving our vision of connectivity, we need to change the regulatory framework. The Commission proposed ambitious reform of electronic communication rules, which is essential for deployment of 5G and broadband, Without better coordination of spectrum, we would not be able to achieve connectivity that is needed for tomorrow. Your report also stresses the importance of mobilising the necessary financial resources, as well as the use of EU financial support to leverage public and private investments. We have to combine structural funds, national, regional and private funding. This report and the endorsement by the European Parliament of the new 2025 strategic objectives for internet connectivity in the Digital Single Market will be an important step. We look forward to working with the European Parliament and the Council on the key elements of the proposed strategy, in line with your resolution, as well as on the related legislative proposals, including the necessary investment-stimulating reforms in the European Electronic Communications Code. All these steps are essential to make the European Gigabit Society a reality. When it comes to digitising industry, the report by Mr Bütikofer very much highlights how to make the digital transformation a successful revolution, from developing digital infrastructure supporting businesses to helping workers acquire the right skills.  We presented our strategy to digitise European industry one year ago. Since then we have made substantial progress. As Vice-President Ansip has already informed you, €3.5 billion over the next 3 years will be allocated under the Horizon 2020 programme for investment in key technologies and their integration along the value chain, as well as for digital innovation hubs. At the Digital Day held in the Rome in March, we launched an EU-wide forum to coordinate national plans to digitise industry - the European platform of national initiatives on digitising industry. In Rome we also reached a very important agreement on high-performance computing. Today, scientists, researchers and engineers need access to world-class HPC to process vast amounts of data. It could be to simulate a complete airplane, for climate modelling, for genome sequencing or for understanding the human brain. Several EU governments committed to supporting the next generation of computers and we expect more Member States to join the initiative.  Your report rightly identifies that the big challenge ahead is the mobilisation of the necessary financial resources and the use of EU financial support to leverage public and private investments. We have to mobilise and pool structural funds, national, regional and private funding to achieve our objectives. I welcome your suggestion to study future sources of investments for industrial digitisation.  The report also highlights two important issues which are at the heart of the Digital Single Market review - data and cyber security. At present, data flows and access to data are often held up in the EU by localisation rules or other technical and legal barriers. Restrictions on localisation prevent the scaling-up up of SMEs providing cloud computing or data hosting services. As announced in the DSM midterm review, the Commission will present a proposal on the free flow of data in autumn. Regarding cyber security, as we saw less than three weeks ago, cyber attacks are a constantly evolving global threat. Later this year we will review the EU's 2013 cyber security strategy, present certification and labelling measures to make IOT devices more cyber-ready and review the role of the EU's Agency for Network and Information Security to make certain it can help EU countries respond adequately.  The European Commission is working on making sure European businesses and citizens can fully benefit from the digital transformation. We need to develop an inclusive digital society whilst boosting European competitiveness.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. –  Mr President, colleagues, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs was discussing this report with great interest and also concern, really, because for us the report is not only about digital industry, it is about the digital transformation of the whole of European society. We can have very nice figures about data, speed and machines, but the bottleneck, obviously, is in the lack of human resources for this big transformation. Already now we can say that the number of unfilled high-level digital jobs is approaching 800 000. If you look at the gap between the skills needed and the available skills, the gap in the level of education in different countries, it is really worrying. When we look at the labour market, one third of jobs will be deeply influenced by this transformation; this will require retraining of hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of workers in Europe. That means that this EUR 3.5 billion that Mr Ansip is talking about should not be spent only on machines, but also at the same level on the development of human resources for Europe. That is a huge task and I am very glad that we in our committee and between committees, we all agree that this is crucial and in all opinions of committees I found that the Commission is really expected to put.. (The President cut off the Speaker)

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 23 March the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection approved its opinion on a report from the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, with a large majority, and I am pleased to see that my dear colleague Michał Boni and the ITRE Commission have incorporated many of our suggestions. I would like to highlight that we are asking for the following: an explicit 5G rollout schedule that includes a technology neutral approach that neutralizes the digital divide; a forward-looking, pro-investment, pro-innovation regulatory environment to encourage competition; predictable long-term solutions that can build investor confidence; a coherent European spectrum strategy with better coordination in spectrum allocation and acceleration of 5G technology standardization efforts; and, with a view to creating more jobs - which is what really matters to us as well - the development and improvement of digital skills, providing the market with quality labor. Finally, I want to say that the internet has made the distances shorter, faster and cheaper. But that we must learn from our previous experiences, adapt to the new era and wholeheartedly embrace the new 5G technologies.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the future of Europe will also depend on the ability we will have to make the most of the opportunities of the digital revolution, while respecting our social model. I will focus only on two issues highlighted in the opinion of the IMCO committee on this important report. The first: the need to ensure that the digitalization process of the industry offers new opportunities to consumers in terms of greater choice and quality of goods and services. In addition, we stressed the importance of advancing on interoperability and standardization, supporting access to essential patents for technical standards on fair and non-discriminatory terms and involving stakeholders and social partners in the definition of new standards. It is therefore essential that the European Union equip itself as soon as possible with an ambitious and effective strategy for the digitalisation of industry, which strengthens the competitiveness of the European productive fabric, starting with small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, Commissioner, there is one sector that has been a frontrunner in terms of utilising digital technologies, and that is transport. Before automated driving, all connectivity between vehicles has become a sort of trend issue. We already have solid experience in terms of utilising ERTMS in the rail transport and SESAR in aviation, and that has been a wholly positive experience. We know that the automation of transport and the use of digital processes are also beneficial for safety and the environment. The sector is moving in this direction, and that of course requires further support and incentives for the development of appropriate infrastructure and equipment. We need, as a matter of urgency, to deliver on network connectivity for innovation and training.  What we really need is a digitalisation in industry strategy, but that strategy is needed so that we can grasp all the opportunities. There are, I would say, three important criteria: firstly, it must be long-term and across perspectives; secondly, we need to concentrate the financial resources in EFSI; and thirdly, we need to monitor the implementation on behalf of the individual Member States. There are two issues that I would like to mention briefly: the first is integrated ticketing, and the second is cyber security. I would appreciate it if the Commissioner would focus on that.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! In its opinion to the ITRE Committee, the Transport and Tourism Committee emphasizes the particular importance of the development of the 5G network for building a safe, integrated and modern system of transport and tourism services in the Union. Without ensuring universal access to fast and stable Internet connections in this standard, we will not be able to talk about development in areas such as autonomous mobility, integrated European ticketing system or automatic notification systems for road incidents. Unfortunately, we notice large differences in the process of building the appropriate network infrastructure between Member States and between individual regions. Inaccessible mountain regions and peripheral regions are particularly affected. Undoubtedly, investment in network infrastructure must be greater, and the next Multiannual Financial Framework and Cohesion Policy must take greater account of the needs of all industries, whose development today depends on access to broadband internet.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, [inaudible] my contribution because at one minute and fifteen seconds, I had two red lights. Just for the record, I had two minutes of speaking time. I had to shorten it, and I am afraid that I could not deliver it entirely, but no harm done. This is just for clarification.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Excuse me, but I have just one minute written down here.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - Mr President, I also congratulate Mr Telichka, who is leaving and will not listen to this conversation, but I still respect his opinion. We are on the threshold of a new and exciting era. These two files represent two more important steps towards a truly digital Europe that we are all striving for. Digitization is not only a political but also an economic issue. It is part of our daily lives for each of us. When we draft new legislation or call for a profoundly different course of action, we will be able to further improve the lives of citizens and provide the industry with modern legal frameworks. One of the key issues we must continue to focus on is bridging the generation gap and retraining the workforce, because they are the pillars of the European Union. Having said that, I would like to end by welcoming the dossiers on the digital industry and the 5G program, and I hope to see soon the necessary changes and measures to be implemented in the Member States of the European Union.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in our opinion as a culture committee we have highlighted certain aspects. Meanwhile, the development of 5G technologies represents a unique opportunity for businesses and cultural and creative innovators to compete on the global scene and also enhance their talent, but also to expand a sector that today represents over 7 percent of GDP. European. The audiovisual sector that is involved in this digital transition will also benefit, provided that its needs and peculiarities are taken into account. Secondly, it will be very important that the envisaged plan actually provides that by 2025 all primary and secondary schools, universities, libraries and research centers in Europe can effectively have access to fast Internet even with a strong investment with the fund of course. EFSI and also, however, as long as safety conditions are guaranteed and with a strong action to give digital skills, this must be highlighted, otherwise we risk that there is an infrastructural investment, but not in the infrastructures that are human resources. Finally, I think we must aim for a real inclusive digital citizenship, we still have a very strong digital divide and therefore I would like the aspects related to training and also to the inclusion of rural and peripheral areas to be very present in the 5G strategy. .

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the challenge of digitizing European industry is incredible in terms of numbers and historical and cultural significance. We calculate approximately 110 billion euros of annual turnover linked to this evolution of the European industrial process, alongside which we have, and more importantly, around 50 billion euros a year of planned investments. So it is a real numerical and, I repeat, cultural revolution. The report, and I thank Mr Bütikofer for this, is built by touching all the pillars, the theme of infrastructures, moreover with an appropriate emphasis on the need for greater attention to be paid within the EFSI, hence the Junker plan. investments linked to the development of industrial digitalization in Europe, the theme of a shared digital industrial policy at European level and the central theme of a right synergy, built in a precise and rigorous way, between public and private in the investment policy we were talking about. But the core of this challenge is all linked, as colleagues have said, to the great game of human capital. Once their skills lasted thirty years in the job market, today in three or five years they are obsolete. Therefore, the first challenge is to build the conditions so that the labor market is not rigid and protective, but adequate and flexible so that the best are always rewarded.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Mr President, today we are talking about the digitalisation of European industry and connectivity. Specifically, we are talking about a digital Europe, a society, practically, digital, in which all citizens should have access to the opportunities offered by new technological developments. The intentions are good, we want the European Union to become a world leader in the implementation of 5G by 2025. This would bring enormous benefits, of almost 141 billion euros, across Europe. For this, however, we must legislate properly and where necessary. For example, we need a definition of very high-capacity networks in the European Electronic Communications Code. To take advantage of the digital revolution, we need to involve all actors. For example, governments should coordinate better and integrate high-security systems, cities should have coherent development programs, SMEs and universities should have access to innovation, and the digital divide must be actively combated through strong action. and clear funding. We must act quickly because innovation and international competition are not waiting for us and it is our role here to make the right decisions.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! I would like to emphasize that digitization - as we all know - is a great opportunity to reindustrialise Europe. And we talk so much about this reindustrialization because the digital revolution is changing the balance of power. It gives an advantage to economies with large resources of engineering and IT staff, while the importance of low labor costs will decrease, so Europe has a chance to regain a large part of production from cheap Asian markets. However, we should not forget about the differences within Europe. And the digital revolution is also an opportunity to reduce the differences between different parts of Europe. You only need to be able to take advantage of this chance, otherwise the existing inequalities will rather worsen. Actions must be taken now to prevent this. Mr. Bütikofer spoke about the new industrial revolution; I would like to remind you that this first industrial revolution permanently divided Europe with all its political and economic consequences. We should act in such a way that this kind of division does not occur in this digital revolution.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - (NL) Mr President, the world around us is changing faster and faster. It is almost impossible to keep up. The use of the Internet alone surpasses everything predicted about it so far. There are already 5 billion cell phones for 7 billion people. The rise of machine-to-machine communication is shooting up to 50 billion interconnected devices. We are moving from a mega-bit society to a gigabit society. Shang Bing, the chairman of China Mobile, said it very nicely: connectivity is like oxygen, we can't live without it. Only 25 years ago, the 2G technology was introduced, which allowed us to send text messages on our mobile phones in addition to calling. With 3G, photos were added, with 4G videos and now we are growing to 5G with virtual reality. Actually, up to 4G it was mainly about connecting people, while 5G will also connect things, the internet of things. We will have an industry with smart devices and advanced self-healing networks that provide all the information and products we want 24 hours a day. Extremely high numbers of transactions are settled and data flows analyzed. This digital revolution is turning all kinds of business models upside down worldwide. Many opportunities arise to do things better, faster and cheaper. If we want to continue to play our part in the global economy in Europe, we must ensure that we are ready for the 5G society and create the right conditions for entrepreneurs to do business. We must ensure good digital infrastructure and innovation-friendly regulations, while offering the right guarantees for individual freedom and privacy. We must seize the opportunities that 5G offers. For all those extra gigabits I will keep fighting like a gigabitch. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Madam Representative!You have outlined an amazing amount of technical progress, which is probably the case.At the same time, what do you see as the reason why, in the meantime, the digital divide between Europe's countryside, especially between European villages and cities, has widened to an unprecedented level?And how do you see a remedy for this?

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: "blue card" answer.- Just for rural areas, satellite technology can be of tremendous help.In a large country like India, they will only provide the entire connectivity with satellites.So we must also be able to serve the countryside in this way.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, the digitization of the industry forces us to reflect on the transformation of the world of work. We have gone from large compact industrial centers, in which all the workers belonged to the same company under the same agreement, to a situation in which the industry uses new technologies to outsource and subcontract increasingly decentralized and also more precarious tasks, even through fake freelance platforms, while high value-added technology hubs are increasingly concentrated in a few countries, or even regions, of the global economy. For this reason, the public sector cannot remain impassive and must regulate the technological changes that are taking place, ensuring that labor legislation continues to apply to dependent workers and subcontractor chains under equal conditions, because otherwise we will generate a new focus of inequality. Faced with the fragmentation of the world of work and new figures that will emerge, a legal framework must exist and be strengthened that protects collective bargaining and the right to strike; in short, that rights are guaranteed. For this, it is necessary to have the unions in an ambitious industrial development strategy, which ensures that technological transformations go hand in hand with the creation of quality employment and the improvement of our production model. Only in this way can we face the technological challenges that lie ahead.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mrs. López Bermejo, forgive me for giving you a certain wake-up call, since you had — it is true — a minute and a half.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! According to a new study by the consulting firm Boston Consulting, industrial companies can save up to 40% of their manufacturing costs in the next ten years if they use the full potential of digitization. Smart logistics, 3D production simulation, big data, cloud computing, robotics and advanced analytics are the building blocks of the factories of the future. The implementation of these and other key technologies such as 5G, artificial intelligence and quantum technologies will be crucial for companies to become more competitive and thus able to create growth and jobs. The successful entry into the gigabit society is, however, associated with high costs. Costs for expanding the digital infrastructure, for research, development and innovation and costs for training. There are currently around 180,000 IT professionals lacking in Europe. The teaching of digital skills must therefore also increasingly flow into the curricula of schools and universities. Digitization is currently the greatest challenge facing Europe as a business location. We therefore need a clear industrial policy strategy so that Europe can take on a leading role worldwide, and only then will it be possible to achieve the reindustrialization target of 20%.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: - Mr President, thank you to all colleagues for the work and effort put into this report to digitize the industry. I would also like to thank the committee responsible for adopting the position of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, where I was rapporteur for the Group of the European People's Party. It is important to talk about digitalization, and boldly. The sector in Europe employs 6 million people and accounts for 4% of the European Union's gross domestic product. It is important to note that about one third of the growth of industrial production is already happening thanks to the introduction of digital technologies. In other words, the industry is benefiting from digitalization. Nearly 100 billion euros a year are expected revenues. But this result will not be achieved with a single effort. We need coordination of national and regional initiatives and exchanges of good practice, we need joint solutions and common standards to promote the development of the Internet of Things and cross-border data movement. But in addition to concrete investments and added value for digital infrastructure, the digitalization of industry also needs prepared human resources. Forty percent of workers in the European Union do not have enough digital skills. And that is exactly what we advocated in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. I am glad that these positions of ours are reflected in the final report. Now is really the time for the new Member States to show that we know how to do this best - to change, to embrace it, to change our industries and to skip the stage of the development cycle, as we did with the internet infrastructure. I hope that Europe can be an example of how to make our industry more efficient and competitive.

name: Martina WERNER
text: -  Mister President! The development of 5G and the path to a gigabit society have top priority for us social democrats, because comprehensive, future-proof networks are a prerequisite for economic and social participation. Above all, we need to invest more in fiber optics. Incidentally, this is particularly true for Germany, because according to an OECD ranking we are far behind. On the way to a gigabit society, we therefore need an ambitious definition of VHC networks and healthy competition. When it comes to the digitization of industry, three points are particularly important to me. First: We have to take SMEs with us in the digital transformation, e. B. through better cluster funding or advisory services. Second: For social acceptance, the involvement of the employees is essential - also more commitment from the companies. Third: It was not just the WannaCry attack that made the importance of cybersecurity clear. In summary: First, ensure connectivity for everyone. Second: take SMEs and employees with you. Third, ensure trust through cyber security. It is on these cornerstones that we should focus our attention now.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group welcomes the positive, but still too timid, approach of our colleague Bütikofer on the issue of controlling foreign investments in the digital domain. We must assert our right to digital sovereignty and protect key European companies in this industry's value chain, so strategic. Brussels had to wait until Germany was hit with the takeover of robotics flagship Kuka to wake up. So let’s take the plunge and protect ourselves against the appetites of the competing American and Asian powers that have profited for so many years from Brussels’s blindness to free trade. But habits die hard. The report by our colleague Boni unreservedly supports PPP 5G. However, in the private part of this partnership, we find companies that have nothing European in them. This is why we will refuse to have this text published because we believe that it is important today to protect ourselves against foreign competition.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, digitalisation is a megatrend that is changing the world very fast now, and it is important that Europe is strongly involved in this development. We know that digitalisation has meant new innovations and business - a lot of new opportunities - and it also offers companies the opportunity to operate more energy-efficiently. In particular, there are two themes that Europe now needs to focus on as we accelerate digitalisation. The second is precisely infrastructure, the related innovations that Mr Boni spoke strongly about here, in the form of 5G networks. The need for mobile data is increasing by 60 to 100 percent every year. And it is clear that we now need a great deal of investment in high-speed networks across Europe, and we need to ensure that Europe has a regulatory environment that encourages companies to invest in Europe and high-speed connections in Europe. Another big issue is improving people’s skills. Today, 90% of European companies already report a lack of adequate digital skills, and it is vital that people's ICT skills are raised at all levels: children, young people and adults already in employment. We cannot be competitive in the global economy if we do not have a sufficiently skilled workforce. This must now be addressed in all Member States.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, today we are discussing two structuring themes of the digital revolution that we are witnessing in the European Union and in the world. For a world in accelerated transformation and full of uncertainty, the Digital Revolution is an opportunity to refound the European project. I welcome the report on the digitization of European industry and its rapporteur for the proposed global strategy, addressing the dimensions of infrastructure, investment, innovation and skills. I also welcome the report on 5G and its rapporteur for the new technological vision that it shares, associating the necessary instruments to achieve it. This week, Parliament and the Council closed a provisional agreement on the WIFI4EU initiative. As your rapporteur, I made it clear that in the development of the European Society, Gigabits, we must guarantee high technological standards, promote inclusion, boost the economy and the capacity to generate value and jobs. We have the opportunity to reposition the European Union in the world as a technologically leading and inclusive project and we must not waste it.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, the EU needs faster and higher quality connectivity for all Europeans. This is essential if we are to establish a digital single market. Ensuring access to broadband across all the Member States and implementing new-generation networks are two of the most important issues for the success of the digital agenda. The creation of a European society where all citizens have access to fast and high quality internet connection is essential in opening up the digital single market, not just for urban areas but everywhere. In my own country, the digitalisation of rural Ireland is akin to the electrification of Ireland over half a century ago. The influence of the digital economy will be the driving force in balancing the rural economic environment. Leading the way, as a demonstration of what is possible if rural communities are given access to high-speed broadband, is the Ludgate Hub in my own constituency in Skibbereen in County Cork – a little town, by the way, that produced five European rowing champions last weekend. The objective of the Ludgate Hub is to facilitate 75 digitally working entrepreneurs, thus creating a wealth of new jobs in the West Cork area. Already the effects of the initiative are producing clear results, with a number of start-ups and young entrepreneurs relocating to the area – an area that has seen a huge decline in population in recent times, as young professionals were forced to move away to larger towns and cities in search of employment opportunities. We need many more Skibbereens. We need the digital single market. We need these proposals.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: - (FI) Mr President, we need to make fast and comprehensive networks accessible to all in Europe, and Europe must be able to lead the way in adopting 5G technology. 5G is an enabling factor as we digitize industry and the transport sector, modernize and digitize the European building stock, increase the effectiveness of health services through new means and enable the deployment of digital services and sensors. A skilled and trained workforce is essential. It is an increasingly important pillar of high value added and the competitiveness of industry and services. Innovations born in Europe generate economic growth and also provide a platform for European industrial solutions. I support the Commission's openings on digital innovation clusters and world-class platforms and partnerships. Resources need to be better coordinated, and it is also our job to see that legislation is compatible with the digital world.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: - Mr President, the digital revolution is fundamentally changing the way economic, social and human activities are carried out in all areas. That is why I support the European Commission's initiatives, the recommendations in these reports, which really aim to form a European digital single market. The literature shows us very clearly that whoever lags behind in the application of opportunities, the use of opportunities generated by the digital revolution lags behind for a long time. That is why we have a responsibility at European level to make it a priority to adopt the regulations needed for the digital revolution, and in particular we must work for digital education so that every European citizen, every company, has the full capacity to do so. use the opportunities created by the digital revolution. I am glad that the future European Commissioner for the Digital Market will be a colleague of ours, Mrs Mariya Gabriel, who has energy and I wish her much success.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the whole debate because I consider this point to be one of the most important. It is a pity that we are discussing this item so late in the evening at an additional meeting. It has been clear here, and I am glad that, in principle, all the speakers support the digital revolution, or rather the involvement of European structures in this revolution. I am convinced that without the coordination of the European Commission, if each country addresses the digitization of industry independently, we will not be very effective. We really need to address the issue of resources at European level, a huge increase in money. I was surprised that we in Europe spend only a third of our resources on digitization, for example against the United States. It is necessary to increase resources, to have a common strategy, but also to get workers. We lack IT staff, as some colleagues have talked about. So, Commissioner, this is a key issue and we need to work on it.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, industry plays a fundamental role in the European economy, new technologies such as Big Data and artificial intelligence are emerging, with new challenges and an eternally changing reality, but the new technologies pose above all ethical questions ; when the data are incommensurable and concern not natural reality but social, historical, linguistic reality, the classification criteria are affected by the object to be classified and tend to be confused with the social facts themselves. The management of this data ends up influencing social life itself by raising the questions expressed in the report, and I congratulate Mr Bütikofer. It is true, in fact, that the industry remains competitive only by combining innovation with sustainability, but it must be clear that the ubiquity and non-rivalry of data subtly expose the consumer to a vulnerability of privacy and to the possible and progressive violation of antitrust rules. . We should not be surprised in the coming years if consumers will have so-called personalized prices for the same goods. With the characterization of consumers, there is the danger that they live in increasingly narrow areas, where free choice is only apparent.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the current challenges for the European economy require a comprehensive strategy for the digitization of industry because only in this way will the competitiveness of the European economy itself, and in particular the economies of the countries of the European South, be strengthened. Thus, contrary to those who believe that European competitiveness should be based on the Chineseization of wages, it should be understood that only if education and training are strengthened and the digital economy is also strengthened, only then will Europe itself be competitive. This, of course, requires funds for the education and training of the workforce itself and can not be done decisively as with the austerity and violent fiscal adjustment imposed on the Member States, the necessary resources are not available. This is all the more true in Greece, where spending on education has been reduced following the violent intervention of the troika itself.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Mr President, technological change is an important driver of development. However, its concrete results depend on the mode of production that characterizes the society in which this change takes place. It can be used to improve the living conditions of workers and peoples, and it can be used to increase the exploitation of workers, inequalities, social injustices. Under the conditions of capitalist globalization, it is the second hypothesis that prevails. The digitization of industry, within the scope of what some call "the fourth industrial revolution", combines innovation and the growing automation of production processes with global technological platforms based on digital communication infrastructure networks. Workers cannot be left out of these processes. They must benefit from changes in wages and entitlements. These transformations should not be used as a pretext to impose social retrogression. It is important not to ignore that, in the context of maintaining the current neoliberal policies, these processes tend to dig deeper into social and national inequalities.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to point out that there are huge differences between the different regions of Europe in terms of the current state and future prospects of industrial digitalisation. It is important to emphasize that, in the context of digitalisation, we must avoid widening the gap between Member States and regions, putting even more backward regions in an even more difficult position. At the same time, digital technologies and their industrial application are a key factor in the European Union's global competitiveness, and the Union and the Member States must support SMEs and major industrial players, simply because they are doing the same in other economic centers around the world. with their entrepreneurs and industry. Reform of education systems can also be interpreted in this context: if we do not provide our young people with relevant knowledge and skills, we may fall behind in global competition very quickly and catching up will be slow and difficult.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the MEPs for their contribution. The European Parliament’s report on the gigabyte society and 5G Action Plan communications is an important step to make a reality of the strategy and of the concrete actions proposed. With regard to the 5G Action Plan, we are sure that it will encourage engagement by all stakeholders, including the Member States, in this ambitious work, which is more of a voluntary nature than of a regulatory nature. We also look forward to your support in the important ongoing regulatory procedures – in particular, concerning the better coordination of spectrum – that are essential to support the gigabyte society strategy, as well as in forthcoming financial discussions.  The European Parliament report on digitising European industry is also very encouraging. It shows that we share a common vision on creating the right infrastructures, as well as the right regulatory and innovation-friendly conditions, for the successful appropriation of digital innovations by any industry in any sector of the economy across the EU. Of equal importance is that we share similar views on the skills, social and work dimensions of digital transformation.  A critical mass of investments is required to achieve greater competitiveness for European industry through its digitalisation, in particular for smarter products, services, processes and business models, and this at all levels – EU, national, regional and from industry itself. This includes investments in, and coordination of, efforts on the development of the broad skills-set which is needed to master the digitalisation. To that end, we count on your continued support for significant investments in this financial framework and the next one.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! I want to focus my concluding remarks on four brief points. First of all, I would like to answer Mr Krasnodębski, who rightly pointed out that we must be careful not to divide Europe again through these technological changes. If we do not want that, Mr Krasnodębski, then we must not call for wagons in the individual countries, but we must develop a European strategy together. Second: I am expressly grateful to Mr Sógor for bringing up the subject of small and medium-sized enterprises again. I think that's crucial. Thirdly, Mr Ferrand raised the issue of protecting European industry. I am for such protection. But I am in favor of protection without protectionism. Mr Ferrand spoke of protection against competition. I would prefer to speak of protection against competition against unfair practices. Fourth, the area that I found most underexposed in this discussion was the area of ​​social implications. I am expressly grateful to my colleagues from the Left, Ms. López Bermejo and Mr. Ferreira, for at least putting this into focus. I am also grateful to Mr Salini and Mrs Werner for pointing out problems in the labor market. But the Commission, Commissioner Vella, disappointed me. You have managed to manage two sentences about the social, societal implications of this topic in two contributions. That's not a good thing. You'll have to sit in detention and think again.

name: Michał BONI
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all, thank you very much for all the comments, I think that it is very important. I have a number of short points to make. Firstly we need to have some kind of holistic understanding of what 5G means. This was raised during the discussion because while 5G is related to industries, to technologies and to infrastructures, it is related, first of all, to people. Through 5G, I think we can change our way of life and live in Europe with new services, a new healthcare area, new education reforms, and so on. Secondly, we need to take comprehensive action, so we need to work at the same time with many sectors of industry, we need to cooperate with regions and cities and, first of all, we need closer cooperation among Member States because certain decisions will depend on Member States. Thirdly and importantly, this is a way to create new competitive advantages for the European economy and European industry. The last and most important point is that we need to avoid fragmentation, because I think recent years have shown us that, in areas related to digital issues, we are fragmented. So, in thinking about the digitalisation of industries and about the 5G action plan, if we can avoid fragmentation, and make it work together, I think we will achieve our goals.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The joint debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The competitiveness of European industry is central and it is therefore essential that the Union manages to lead the new industrial revolution, through innovation, and on the basis of sustainability. Indeed right here, some strong points of the old continent lie: it has know-how, R&D, skilled workers, a large single market, a strong industrial base and a long collaboration between production and services. In this context, Europe needs an ambitious industrial modernization strategy that digitizes its manufacturing base. This must be accomplished with a global approach, which places both environmental and social sustainability at the forefront. The digitalization of the company must therefore be conceived as a holistic strategy, without forgetting the need for cybersecurity standards. The direction taken seems to be the right one, we will ensure that the path proceeds in the correct way.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. - 5G marks a revolution, a new era in the digital world by creating new high performance networks, including high quality and very high capacity networks. We share and support the European Commission's goal of rapidly activating 5G, which will be a pole for growth and innovation. In addition, faster and better Internet access across Europe will help reduce the digital divide and enable the development and delivery of new innovative digital services, such as connected cars or e-health, not only in urban but also in urban areas. and in rural and remote areas.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - President! As a member of the Committee on Regional Development and the shadow rapporteur for the opinion drafted by REGI on this subject, I would also like to draw attention to the regional aspects of the subject. Territorial and social cohesion must not be forgotten when drafting new legislation and during implementation processes. The digital lag of less developed regions is very large compared to urban areas. According to statistics, broadband coverage in some regions is 28%, which is almost 50% less than the average coverage. Taking advantage of broadband internet and 5G technology, this digital divide could be bridged. The rural population could also have access to the same digital content and services (e-government, e-education, etc.) as in cities. Achieving this goal requires the creation of targeted financial funds that encourage investment in less developed regions as well. In addition to territoriality, we must also pay attention to digital cohesion in order to ensure a level playing field for European citizens, wherever they live in the Union.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - The European Union must be a leader in the digital economy. Individual industries are key employers in most Member States. They provide economic dynamism, are important for the development of social policy and the effective management of the major societal challenges we are forced to face. We are part of a digital industrial revolution that is bringing fundamental technological change. These affect business models, production and consumption of goods and services. There is currently a global competition for who can best adapt to and benefit from the new conditions. The European Union has built a certain edge and has a great chance of being a leader in the digital economy. Years have been at the forefront of reducing energy intensity, promoting the use of renewable energy sources, innovation, or reducing CO2 emissions. The ability of Member States to further cooperate on economic issues, the development of a common market and an industrial base will thus be important for success. At the same time, the promotion of new technologies must not mean an increase in social insecurity. This is what populist and extremist parties and movements are abusing. They promise their constituents that they will keep everything as it is, or will go back decades. However, this is certainly not the right way to go. On the contrary, the responsible governments must support employers in preparing workers for employment in the new conditions.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - President! The events of recent times have shown us that Europe can no longer afford to follow the events of the world tired and is waiting for a solution to its own problems from the outside. We need to take our destiny into our own hands and do nothing but take the lead in tackling global challenges so that the world adapts to our solutions. The fourth industrial revolution is taking place before our eyes. New technologies, digitalisation, have an impact on each level of the hitherto familiar economic model and are able to fundamentally rearrange existing wealth relations. Our role in this transformation will determine Europe's competitiveness and economic strength for decades to come. With a well-founded strategy, we will be able to put the Union's economy on a new and stronger footing and be back at the forefront of the world. However, such a major transformation is both an opportunity and a threat. As the structure of the economy changes, jobs can not only be created but also lost. With the right strategy, we can be able to deal with the situation and even broaden the range of workers, but to do that we need to correctly identify the key forces that are driving the transformation. In Hungary, we believe that the development and expansion of technical and IT training is key in this situation, as Europe would currently need about 180,000 more IT professionals. I think the Hungarian example can be exemplary.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- The digitalisation of European industry has led to changes in the way of production and consumption, business models and thus increased global competition as a result of new technologies such as the fifth generation network (5G).It is indisputable that the European Union must ensure that its industry is competitive and sustainable through knowledge, research and development, but also through the single European market, which is an exceptional advantage for progress.In order for the EU to catch up with global industrial modernization, a common approach by Member States based on guaranteeing efficient infrastructure, promoting research and development and additional investment is necessary.It is clear that the digitalisation of the world industry brings with it great challenges, and I therefore believe that it is crucial that the European institutions and the Member States take the security aspect of the development of the digital economy very seriously.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - The report on the digitization of European industry rightly notes that the current industrial revolution is Europe's opportunity to build a competitive and strong economy.
