It is important to create a coherent policy that will facilitate innovation, stimulating investment in the economy and attracting global specialists. Attention should be focused on supporting small and medium-sized enterprises. The strategy to be adopted by the Union must be uniformly implemented and constantly monitored in order to avoid a digital divide. Therefore, we should ensure appropriate digital education and provide students with the best possible access to both computers and the Internet, and constantly improve teachers' qualifications. At the same time, we should note that the changes caused by the digitization of industry force the adjustment of legislation to new forms of work related to remote work or work via internet platforms. One more important issue is cybersecurity, the framework of which should be regulated and given priority as soon as possible.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - In today's time of global competition in the application of new technological advances such as 5G network, cloud computing, artificial intelligence and robotics, the question we ask is how to integrate them into business models, value chains, production and consumption in the most sustainable and socially acceptable way? The answer to this must be sought by the EU in sustainable innovation and the adaptation of the education system in order to maintain competitiveness and become a leader in the new industrial revolution. In this area, the strengths of the EU are specific knowledge, related and targeted investment in research and development, a large single market, a strong industrial base and experience in linking production and services. The key to progress is the education of workers and the acquisition of IT skills, because without people with the necessary knowledge there are no significant changes in the digitalization of the industry. Likewise, digitization means the need for different jobs and new knowledge. Only with a well-adapted system of education and science can we prepare our citizens for the digital age that is no longer the future. Combining digital skills with vocational education and engineering skills, smart specialization, connecting small and medium-sized enterprises, industrial entities, start-ups, scientists and researchers is the right way to adapt to change. It is therefore an important message for Member States that only by investing in workers' skills and developing digital infrastructure can existing disparities in digital development be bridged.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- The fifth generation of wireless network will significantly improve data rate-dependent technologies.Accelerating the flow of information will significantly affect the quality of services in all sectors, trade and business opportunities and the overall competitiveness of the economy.The deployment of the 5G network can lead to the creation of up to 2.3 million direct and indirect jobs in the Union and can thus help solve the problems of remote regions.I support the consistent implementation and implementation of the 5G Network Action Plan by the Member States and the Commission so that the Union becomes a world leader in the implementation of standardized 5G networks between 2020 and 2025.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up.- I express my reservations about the exaggerated tendency to involve institutions, governments and other stakeholders in a future 5G project, as long as the implementation of the current 4G standard, which is currently underway, is not satisfactory.I think we have a duty to complete a project first and then to get involved in a new, bigger and more expensive one.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: in writing.- Promoting digitalisation, especially in lagging regions, is essential for the EU to remain a world industry leader.I would therefore like to point out the importance of ensuring an EU digital governance system for industry that facilitates the coordination of national initiatives and platforms for the digitalisation of industry.That is why I have tabled amendments to the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the digitalisation of European industry, in order to emphasize that well-developed language technologies can help industry to overcome language barriers and thus open up opportunities for the digital market.As the impact of language barriers on industry has not yet been sufficiently reflected and assessed in digital market documents, I would like to call for the development of language technologies that, together with industrial digitalisation, reduce European market fragmentation and increase access to European services for citizens.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I would like to express here my concern about the impacts of digitization on the relocation of production, on employment and its quality; in the rights of the workers and in the isolation and depopulation of the rural environment. I believe that it is necessary to guarantee equal access to rural areas and to establish measures to protect employment. I would like to know what studies the report's rapporteur relies on to say that up to 2.3 million jobs are likely to be created when 5G technology is fully deployed. I would also like to know if these jobs are net; if this calculation discounts the jobs that will be destroyed and how is the distribution in the EU; or whether the use of "false self-employed workers", a method currently used by some companies to make employment precarious, will be controlled. Employment in rural areas and that generated by local commerce must be protected. Otherwise, we will be using technological advances to, through greater speed, further deepen the aspect of mere consumers, promoting the exclusive profits of large corporations over and above our social and labor rights.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- Digitization is a phenomenon that will completely change the structure of industry, industrial relations and business in the near future.We need to prepare for this change, because we are growing competition in the form of fast-growing economies such as India or China.These countries have even overtaken us in many ways.At European Parliament level, we have succeeded in pushing for the abolition of roaming charges, the geoblocking of content on the Internet and also the unification of bands for high-speed connections.These are key steps in building a full digital market within the European Union.The task of the nation states remains to reform education systems, labor codes and pave the way for new forms of business.I regret to say that Slovakia is lagging significantly behind in these areas.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - I believe that digitalisation is a sine qua non for the development of a competitive European industry, as the socio-economic benefits of this phenomenon are obvious. Technological progress creates new employment opportunities and formats, including for vulnerable social groups, and facilitates a good work-life balance. All this contributes to increasing labor market participation, resulting in improved production capacity and economic growth at European level. However, I regret that this report does not sufficiently highlight the challenges of digitalisation on social issues. Lack of digital skills and the time it takes for industry to adapt can lead to imbalances in the labor market, with the risk that regulated rights and working conditions will be affected. In my opinion, digitalisation can cause gaps between companies and Member States that already have the necessary infrastructure and those that do not have the same opportunities to invest in modernization. Therefore, cohesion funds, investment in underdeveloped regions and stimulating vulnerable sectors must complement measures to accelerate the digitalisation of industry.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- While 4G and 3G were created to meet a need for speed on the mobile internet, 5G is part of a larger project.In the future, we will all be ultra-connected: smartphones, tablets, PCs, connected objects, home automation, connected cars, VR headsets, augmented reality, artificial intelligence.Twenty years from now we will be living in a world we cannot even imagine today.The industrialists of this world must have a vision of this future, and prepare ourselves for it.5G is this network that will allow all of our connected devices to communicate with each other.A large flow is necessary, but not only.5G will also provide better battery life for years to come.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The concrete results of technological changes depend on the mode of production that characterizes the society in which this change takes place. It can be used to improve the living conditions of workers and peoples, as well as used to increase the exploitation of workers, inequalities and social injustices. Under the conditions of capitalist globalization, it is the second hypothesis that prevails. The digitization of industry, within the scope of what some call the fourth industrial revolution, combines innovation and the growing automation of production processes with global technological platforms, based on digital communication networks and infrastructures. Workers cannot be left out of these processes. They must benefit from changes in terms of wages and rights. These transformations should not be used as a pretext to impose social retrogression. It is important not to ignore that, in the context of maintaining the current neoliberal policies, these processes tend to dig deeper inequalities, social and national.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the same rules must apply in the same common market. Recently, however, we have witnessed many practices when a different quality appears on the European market under the same brand. I am convinced that we must take action against such practices and that they violate the rules of our common market. In addition, in the younger EU Member States, such practices are very sensitively perceived and people are considered second-class citizens. Even some populists abuse these practices in anti-European sentiment. That is why I am in favor of always providing the consumer with the information he can make. I am in favor of ensuring the same quality under the same brand. I am in favor of addressing this issue on European soil. It is important to involve producers and traders who want to compete fairly in this debate, and it is important to divide competences between the European and national levels. I believe that we will be able to make progress on this topic, because our people perceive European integration despite such topics.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, villages that currently offer very limited opportunities compared to urban life across Europe are at risk of depopulation. This process is already a source of serious cultural, social and economic problems, which will only intensify over time. Especially if there are governments in some Member States such as In Hungary, which does not seem to be reluctant to steal even the millions of food packages received from the EU. That is why one of the biggest challenges for the coming period is to revitalize Europe's villages. I would like to refer to the 'smart villages' initiative of the European Parliament and the European Commission, which aims to revitalize European villages by significantly improving the living conditions of the rural population and focusing primarily on young people. Internet access, quality education, advanced health services, good transport and, of course, access to meaningful jobs. Currently, these services are the prerogatives of the urban population. With the smart, so-called “smart” approach, we can make our villages not only more livable places, but even innovation centers.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr. President, Parla is a city of 125,000 inhabitants with one of the lowest incomes in the Community of Madrid: 15,000 people in severe poverty, 17% unemployment, 240 homes at risk of eviction.A municipality punished by the crisis and by the years of neglect of the different administrations.Faced with this, neighbors, union organizations and social movements grouped in the Urge Parla platform have drawn up a plan of guarantees and rights that includes employment plans, housing and soup kitchens, investments, public services, etc.A plan to which the European Union can and must contribute through its policies and resources against poverty and social exclusion.From here, all our support for Parla's fight for employment and for decent public services for this municipality.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, I would like to express my indignation at the behavior of four European countries. These are Germany, Italy, Belgium and France, which are trying to impose protectionism in transport. This is unacceptable. Transport protectionism prevents Eastern European entrepreneurs from being able to do their jobs. The restriction of transport affects hundreds of thousands of people working in Eastern Europe, and they enjoy the four basic freedoms, namely freedom of movement, freedom of ideas, freedom of people and the freedom to be able to do the things you do. tried to do. That is why I object to this protectionist transport policy. The fundamental rights of people who work and people who are entrepreneurs and try to contribute to the common good must be respected.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Mister President!So today the European Commission presented its reflection paper on reforming the euro area.The Commission wants a common budget, Eurobonds and of course a Euro Treasury by 2025.The paper begins with the words: "The euro is more than a currency." Yes, that is exactly the problem.The Commission wants the euro more as a tool than a currency.The euro should bring peace, and it should bring the EU on a par with the USA and China and, of course, also create the EU central state.What is lost from sight is what a currency is actually for.People need a currency in which they can pay in the present and in which they can save for the future.The one about saving has not been possible for a long time.We have zero rates and now we have negative rates.A currency in which you cannot save has to fail and will fail.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). - Mr President, at a time when the European Union is stepping up its militarization and taking repressive measures in the name of security, the dangerous decisions of the NATO summit in Brussels are promoting, among other things, the transfer of large NATO military forces to the border with Russia. The transformation of Greece into a hub for the transfer of NATO troops puts our people in great danger. The NATO exercise Noble Jump is at the forefront of war plans in an area where energy and market control interests are at stake. The Souda base is a strategically important base for imperialist intervention. The SYRIZA-ANEL government has great responsibilities. On behalf of the capital and in the name of geostrategic upgrade, it involves Greece in Euro-Atlantic planning. Neither land nor water to the murderers of the peoples! Close all bases! No facilitation of the passage of foreign troops, no change of borders, immediate disengagement from imperialist interventions and wars! Release from NATO and other imperialist organizations!

name: Daniel BUDA
text: - Mr President, Romanian farmers are currently facing an acute labor crisis in all sectors. Although they offer decent wages, they fail to find workers, especially in the livestock sector, but not only, which will unfortunately lead in the not too distant future to close these businesses in this field. The phenomenon mainly affects small and medium-sized farms, which we also want to support at European level. I appreciate that it is not enough to offer only financial support for the establishment of these farms, but it is necessary to ensure their proper functioning in the long run. Social assistance is the main cause of this phenomenon that affects the agricultural sector in Romania. A large part of the people who could work in this field benefit from social benefits, so they prefer not to work, which I consider inadmissible, considering at the same time that immediate intervention in this field is required, so that through policies that be made at European level to stimulate employment in this agricultural sector.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: –  Mr President, many in Western Europe were surprised to see the political events in Hungary and Poland when nationalist political forces came to power and started to attack the European project. This contradicts memories of huge demonstrations of people in Eastern Europe in the 1980s, who were protesting against the old undemocratic power and demanding freedom and democracy. Dear Western European colleagues, amongst those people who took part in those demonstrations there were not only democrats, but also many nationalists who were dissatisfied with the old power. The aim was not to establish a democratic society, but to clear the way to power. They killed the dragon because they wanted themselves to become a dragon, but not because they wanted democratic challenges.  In two days’ time in my country, Latvia, there will be local elections to which 14% of the population with the status of Latvian aliens will not be admitted. For a quarter of a century, these people were not entitled to participate in any elections. It is happening in an EU country, and many of you do not want to see this inconvenient reality. Why, colleagues? Because it contradicts your perception of success. Wake up, colleagues, and see the reality. You have blindly supported nationalists and now you are getting the results, because the boomerangs are returning.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, seven stone memorandum years have been completed, during which the troika and the creditors dissolved Greek society and turned it into a vast social graveyard. The SYRIZA-ANEL government, with the third and fourth memorandum, completed the modern Armageddon memorandum that struck the impoverished Greek people. However, the Eurogroup, despite the fact that the SYRIZA-ANEL memorandum government legislated all the anti-social measures demanded by the lenders, nevertheless refused to complete the second assessment, refused to pay the installment, and rejected the coveted Greek government debt settlement. In the same vein, Draghi imposed new harsh conditions for Greece's inclusion in quantitative easing. Seibel and the troika are now intimidated, as the government trumpets "Spanish retreat". But the Greek people do not tolerate the provocative actions of the troika and the creditors and will soon throw them out of our homeland, because there is now another way for Greece.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Mr President, today, 31 May 2017, commemorates World Multiple Sclerosis Day. Multiple sclerosis is a chronic lifelong disease that affects the central nervous system. The disease is most commonly diagnosed between the ages of 20 and 40, with an average age of onset of 34, and affects twice as many women as men. The disease is highly unpredictable and the symptoms of the two patients may differ. There are more than 700,000 people with multiple sclerosis in Europe and there are big differences in access to treatment. People facing the problems of this disease deserve our support. We have already done a lot, but we need to continue. We need to increase the public funding available for the compilation and maintenance of specific patient registers. Analysis of data at European level can provide some of the answers in real life for patients required by regulators, healthcare payers, medical research and patient advocates. This can not only enable innovation through a better understanding of treatment outcomes, but also reduce the cost of healthcare systems and improve access to medicines. Let us not forget these patients and let us not remember these patients only this day.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I would like to use this one minute to inform you about the situation in the Czech Republic in the field of electronic communications law. The Czech Republic had legislation that was criticized by European experts for insufficient consumer protection in this legislation. I am glad that on 24 May this year the Chamber of Deputies adopted an amendment to this law, and that Czech citizens will finally have sufficient rights in conflict with operators, who often abuse their dominant positions, their economic forces, forcing citizens to do not withdraw from contracts or otherwise restrict them. The new legislation should already meet the criteria of European legislation and thus adequately protect consumer rights. The behavior of the operators is evidenced, for example, by the fact that in the last few days some Czech operators have restricted roaming services without a clear reason.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I dedicate this one-minute speech to denounce the direct and indirect effects of a so-called online game, Blue Whale, the cause of dozens of suicides among the youngest. Continuing to call the chilling phenomenon of the Blue Whale a game means diminishing its gravity and relegating a practice that has its roots in an adolescent and social unease that cannot and must not be underestimated to an almost playful environment. Many media continue to talk about the Blue Whale game in the wrong way: sensationalizing suicides is a mistake and risks generating emulative phenomena. We need to pay more attention because words not only describe reality, but have the power to change it. However, the main area of ​​intervention must be family and social. Because if dozens of young people think they can find their own identity by becoming protagonists of an extreme practice, if they see their value recognized only in overcoming absurd tests that lead to a tragic ending, it means that they do not see their value recognized elsewhere.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, Sinn Féin has engaged with hundreds and hundreds of groups and organisations that are all concerned about the loss of EU funding post-Brexit. It is ironic that the only money that came to the north of Ireland through Brexit was dark, shadowy and unaccountable. The Democratic Unionist Party received an envelope stuffed with the grand total of GBP 436 000 to advertise support for Brexit in Britain but not in Ireland. The unanswered question is who paid the DUP? Did anyone fumble in a greasy till? The DUP has been asked to report on the original source of this money. There are concerns that the DUP allowed the money to be siphoned to avoid British electoral law and exploit a loophole. Serious allegations by openDemocracy linked the previously unheard of Constitutional Research Council and the well-known Saudi intelligence to the cash. Whoever the donors are, we know that the DUP took the Brexit money, but we will pay the price.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: - Mr President, June 1 is Children's Day in dozens of countries in Europe and around the world. It is a time to bring a smile to children's faces, to give them hope in their dreams and to show that their future and feelings are important to us. That is why I invited today to the European Parliament a group of children from the Romanian diaspora in Belgium, whom I thank for showing me a new perspective on our activity. But things are not so simple: 26 million children in Europe are affected by poverty and social exclusion according to Eurostat. Unfortunately, Bulgaria, Romania and Hungary lead in the top of child poverty, so we need a guarantee for children at European level, to ensure their access to education, culture or proper nutrition. Children's rights are human rights, and human rights are children's rights. Children’s rights are human rights and human rights are also children’s rights. Let's respect the rights and "Happy Birthday" to all children from June 1.
